debateinfo.title: AUSTRALIAN WOOL RESEARCH AND PROMOTION ORGANISATION AMENDMENT BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Anderson, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this bill is to give wool growers greater involvement in setting the strategic direction of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation, something they have been seeking for a long time and which I believe they universally will welcome. The amendments contained in the bill will allow wool tax payers greater involvement in the work of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation and a greater opportunity to express their views on the directions of wool promotion and research and development. The bill arises from recommendations from the wool industry which were considered by an industry-government working party. I believe the thrust of the changes will be welcomed by wool growers.

The current legislative framework governing the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation allows wool tax payers (wool growers) only a minimal involvement in the organisation. These restrictions were established by the previous government as a response to the difficulties experienced with the decision making process of the old Australian Wool Corporation and its management of the reserve price scheme.

While wool growers have shown strong support for the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation—including through the recent wool tax ballot held in late 1997—these statutory arrangements have left them feeling they are, to some extent, disenfranchised from the process of setting the future directions of their industry. In practice, the extent to which the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation could interact effectively with wool growers has been limited by the existing legislation.

In summary, the bill will give the wool growing industry more involvement in the selection of members of the board of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation, and will ensure there are more wool growers with appropriate expertise on the board. It will open up the annual general meeting of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation to allow individual wool growers to put their views directly to the organisation that is responsible for spending their wool tax dollars. And it will allow greater flexibility in future ballots to set the level of wool tax.

The bill provides that the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Board be increased from nine to 11 members. This will allow the number of wool grower members on the board to be increased to four, not only reflecting the importance of this skill on the board but also greatly assisting communication on the business of the organisation with growers spread across the country.

However, the board will retain the wide range of expertise and the mix of skills and experience necessary for it to efficiently perform its functions, much of which is, of course, well beyond the farm. In addition to their wool production background, the additional grower members will be expected to have broader commercial, processing or other skills and knowledge to contribute to the board. The board will remain an independent and professional body, with appropriate skills, but with better avenues of communication with the industry it serves and, hence, greater accountability to growers.

The bill provides that the Chair of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation will be required to `have had involvement in wool production' as well as relevant board experience, and experience in the other areas of expertise outlined in the act. This will give sufficient scope to appoint a capable and independent chair suited to heading a large, commercially focused organisation.

The Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation is a statutory authority, and appointments to the board will continue to be the responsibility of the government. However, through this bill the selection process for board members will be revised, to increase the role of the industry in the process, while ensuring that board members will be selected on the basis of their expertise, not their affiliation to industry groupings.

The board selection committee will include a presiding member and another member appointed by the government, the Chair of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation, and two members nominated by the Wool Council of Australia, in consultation with the Australian Interior Textile and Carpet Wool Council.

In relation to the annual general meetings, as you will be aware, Mr Speaker, with your own knowledge and familiarity with the wool industry, at present growers are only allowed to vote on a motion approving the annual report, or if a motion of no confidence is lodged. Frankly, these restrictions are out of date and are a major contributing factor to the low levels of grower participation in the annual general meetings. Last year's turn-out was particularly low, and in that sense I think indicative of the need for these changes. This bill will allow wool tax payers to put motions to the annual general meeting, bringing forward potentially useful ideas for consideration by the board, without mandating the acceptance of these ideas. The board will then be required to explain to the industry any decision it makes regarding such motions.

Enhanced consultation with the peak industry councils during development of the corporate plan will allow the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation to draw more fully upon industry expertise and the desires of wool growers, while still maintaining the professional independence of the organisation.

This bill will remove unnecessary restrictions on the conduct of the wool tax ballot, which will also contribute to satisfying wool tax payer requests for more involvement in the direction of their industry. There is also increased flexibility in the form that the ballot may take.
Other changes

The other amendments provided for in the bill are of an administrative nature. They include clarifying situations where the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation is operating on behalf of the Australian wool industry and the government under implied, rather than express, powers. This recognises the organisation's move towards more commercial practice, such as charging for the provision of services, and the use of the Woolmark brand by licensees. This allows the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation to seek much needed additional funding to supplement the wool tax and the government's research and development support, leveraging funds available for promotion, and allowing the organisation to enhance its interaction with manufacturers and retailers. The calculation of the gross value of production of wool, which is used in calculating the government's contribution to research and development funding, is also to be amended to ensure consistency with legislation governing the other primary industry research and development authorities.
Conclusion

The amendments contained in this bill signal a further step towards curtailing unnecessary government involvement—dare I say, intervention and even interference—in the wool industry. However, I would stress that these amendments are not about enhancing grower representation within the industry or jeopardising the high standard of corporate governance already established by the board. They are about giving the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation greater access to the skills and experience that reside within the wool industry, enhancing accountability to wool taxpayers and fostering industry `ownership' of its main service provider. These changes also fit well with the organisation's continuing evolution towards a corporate structure operating along commercial lines.

All of us in this House, I know, feel very deeply for the wool producers of this country. Many of them have been losing money now for six or seven or even eight years in a row. I think last year only 10 per cent, according to some of the figures I have seen, of the nation's wool growers received what could be regarded as a respectable return on their investment. There are farm families and relevant communities across this nation that are hurting, and hurting very badly, as a result of the global decline in demand for wool and the resulting very poor returns. All of us extend our concerns to people in that industry and want to see us do what we can in this place to assist, keeping in mind that in the end, regrettably, there is little we can do to lift international prices beyond attempting to adequately fund promotion exercises and so forth in the hope that, in the long term, people will come back to wool in a substantial way.
I commend the measures contained in this bill to honourable members, and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Dr Theophanous) adjourned.

debateinfo.title: INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Moore, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

This bill amends the Industry Research and Development Act 1986 and contains provisions to streamline the administration of the research and development tax concession scheme, with the aim of reducing compliance costs for companies. It responds to the need for such measures identified in the government's industry statement Investing for Growth in December 1997.

The bill will make the registration process easier for companies that wish to claim the tax deduction. The period for making an application for registration will be increased by four months to a total of 10 months from the end of the year of income for which the company seeks registration. This will be more convenient for companies with normal accounting periods, giving them more time to prepare their applications and shifting the deadline away from busy periods on the calendar.

The bill also addresses some rigidities in the process of company registration. The proposed changes will allow the Industry Research and Development Board a limited discretion to consider some late applications for registration and to correct minor errors made by companies in their registration applications. At present, even if there are exceptional circumstances, missing a deadline or getting the company's name wrong in the application can cost a company its access to the research and development tax concession. This bill will give the board more flexibility to treat such cases based on the specific circumstances attaching to each. The discretions being given to the board will, however, be limited in such a way that they will not weaken those provisions of the act designed to prevent retrospective access to the tax concession.

In addition, this bill will give the board the flexibility to require different levels of information from different classes of applicant. This will enable the board, for example, to reduce the information requirement and, hence, the compliance cost of the scheme for companies undertaking smaller dollar amounts of research and development. Companies eligible for approval to undertake up to 10 per cent of their research and development activities overseas will also benefit from this bill. The proposed change will make the effective date for any board approval the date on which the application is received. At present, any expenditure a company incurs between the date of application and board approval—which can take some months—is not eligible for a concessional tax deduction. This bill will fix that situation.

The bill also contains a raft of minor measures aimed at improving the administra tion of the research and development tax concession scheme consistent with improving its integrity and efficacy. These minor measures include clarification of the board's powers in the areas of exploitation of R&D results and overseas expenditures on R&D; administrative improvements to the registered research agency scheme; and housekeeping matters relating to board appointments, sharing of information and recruitment of consultants.
I commend this bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Dr Theophanous) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Vaile, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

In July 1996 the government announced that the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, commonly known as CASA, would conduct a complete review of the civil aviation legislation in Australia, with the objectives of harmonising it with international standards of safety regulation and making it shorter, simpler, and easier to use and understand. This was also an election commitment in our government's Soaring into Tomorrow aviation policy statement. The Morris committee Plane Safe report and the Seaview commission of inquiry both supported the need for a review of Australian regulations and standards.
The purpose of this bill is to facilitate the findings of the review. It provides for the introduction of a new set of regulations that are harmonised with civil aviation laws internationally.

The existing act contains various references to the `civil aviation regulations'. These references will be changed to `the regulations' or `regulations made under this act' or simi lar. In recognition of the fact that the safety regulation of aviation activities should not be based fundamentally on the commercial nature of an activity, it is proposed that the term `commercial' be removed from the act by replacing `domestic commercial flight' with `regulated domestic flight'.

The amendments also provide for new powers in relation to the retention and destruction of goods seized by CASA during the course of investigating breaches of the Civil Aviation Act 1988 and regulations. The power to retain seized goods for longer than 60 days and the power to destroy seized goods are vested in courts. CASA must apply to courts for orders to retain or destroy the goods, as the case may be. The former is required to assist in prosecutions for offences against the act or regulations and is needed in cases where difficulties arise when proceedings are delayed.

The discretion to destroy dangerous goods seized is proposed because, in practice, it is not always possible to return seized goods to their owner, and the airline or Customs do not want to accept the responsibility for the goods after the matter is finalised. Unless such goods are forfeited to the state under legislation relating to property used in the commission of an offence, CASA is required to store them indefinitely. This storage is expensive and has no purpose other than to ensure that CASA does not unlawfully dispose of goods which it does not own. The amendments proposed will permit a CASA investigator to apply to a court for an order that the goods be destroyed where the owner cannot be located or has refused to take possession of the goods.

Clarification of CASA's ability to classify the fees charged by CASA under the civil aviation (fees) regulations as debts due to CASA is also included in the bill. Where regulations made under the act require the payment of a fee, and the fee is not paid by the due date, then the regulations should be able to prescribe a late payment penalty to be added to that fee. Consequently, a provision which enables the making of regulations which prescribe limited late payment penalties to be imposed is also included.

The financial impacts of the proposed amendments have been assessed as being low. The regulatory changes which the bill facilitate streamline many CASA requirements of industry and will assist in the manufacture of aircraft in Australia. The bill has no direct budgetary impact. It is envisaged, however, that the regulatory changes which will follow from the bill will reduce the costs borne by CASA in administering the civil aviation regulatory regime.

The amendments proposed in this bill will facilitate the long awaited introduction for the Australian aviation industry of a regulatory regime which is not only harmonised with international practice but clear, concise and outcome focused. The government's commitment to deliver this objective has been realised. I commend the bill to the House and table the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Dr Theophanous) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Truss, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

The National Measurement Act 1960, `the act', provides the legislative basis for the Australian national measurement system. The objective of this act is to ensure that measurements are made on a consistent basis throughout the nation and are compatible with measurements in other countries.

While trade measurement in reticulated water, electricity and gas already falls within the ambit of the act, the act does not provide a detailed measurement control system to enable traders to easily comply with its broad requirements for legal traceability. This bill amends the act to provide mandatory requirements for specified utility meters, as recom mended by the Review of Australia's Standards and Conformance Infrastructure, the Kean report.

The Kean committee recognised that the present system of utility measurement was wasteful, inadequate in today's environment and inappropriate to address the privatisation and corporatisation of utility authorities. In recommending an amendment to the National Measurement Act, the Kean committee was aware that a state and territory based solution would not effectively address the transborder nature of the utility sector which includes the national electricity grid and interstate gas pipelines.

The proposal contained in this bill has significant benefits for utility meter manufacturing industry, utility companies and consumers. National pattern approval and verification will provide local manufacturers of utility meters with the efficiencies and benefits of scale of a single national market for utility meters.

As a consequence of international harmonisation of requirements, the proposal will enhance export opportunities for local manufacturers of utility meters. While the proposal will expose local manufacturers to additional competition from imported meters, it will at the same time safeguard them against unfair competition from substandard imported meters.

The proposal contained in this bill will provide direct benefits for utility companies by eliminating multiple, inefficient testing of utility meters for pattern approval purposes that is only partially effective. The associated cost burden will be removed, and the exposure of these companies to risk arising from the purchase of substandard utility meters will be greatly reduced.

Consumer confidence in utility metering will be increased because of the independent third party approval and auditing of meters, reducing the present asymmetry of information between utility companies and consumers. This will translate into indirect benefits to utility companies because of fewer consumer complaints and a consequent reduction in transaction costs.

The proposal contained in this bill will cause additional costs for utility meter manufacturers, but these will be more than compensated for by the efficiencies and benefits of scale associated with a single national market for utility meters and the increased access to export opportunities. In addition, the proposal has clear benefits for consumers, utility authorities and state and territory regulators. However, it is not possible to quantify these benefits. There will be minor costs to the National Standards Commission associated with coordinating the system.

The bill broadens the objects of the act to embrace the verification of utility meters and extends the functions of the National Standards Commission to ensure that utility meters used for trade are verified. The bill introduces a new section 4A that defines the extent to which the amended act will exclude state and territory laws relating to utility meters used for trade. In particular, this section provides for the concurrent operation of state and territory laws relating to the re-verification of utility meters used for trade and the in-field replacement of meters that give inaccurate measurements.

The bill requires that utility meters used for trade, not prescribed as exempt in the regulations, must be verified by the National Standards Commission or a verifying authority appointed by the commission for that purpose. One of the requirements for verification is that the pattern—design—of the utility meter has been approved by the commission under the existing pattern approval provisions of the act.

Provision is made for the commission to audit the work of verifying authorities to ensure both that the meters conform to their approved pattern and that they have been correctly verified. Enforcement provisions are included to provide the commission with access to evidence in the event that offence provisions of the bill are contravened. These enforcement powers are similar to those of a trade measurement inspector in a state or territory jurisdiction.

It is intended that all classes of utility meters will initially be exempted from the application of these new provisions. Follow ing the satisfactory completion of consultations and the expiry of an agreed introductory period, the exemption will be lifted for a particular class of utility meter. Provision is made in the bill for utility meters already being used for trade to remain in use provided that they give accurate measurement.

Recommendation 6 of the Kean report, to which this bill relates, has been accepted by both the present government and the previous government. In addition, the proposal is strongly supported by the utility meter manufacturing industry. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Dr Theophanous) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Abbott, for Dr Kemp, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

The important role higher education plays in Australia's social and economic development is the rationale for the government's substantial investment in it and policies designed to ensure that we realise the greatest possible individual and collective benefits. Australia already has a good higher education system, an achievement recognised by surveys of graduates and the large numbers of overseas students choosing to pursue their studies here. But we are working in a rapidly changing environment, and there is always scope for improvement.

The government has a number of objectives which flow from this position. It aims to continue to increase access to post-secondary education, including higher education, so that all those who can benefit from it will have access. This means the higher education system must deal with a very diverse student body and offer the choice that meets varied needs. Lifelong learning is already a feature of our education system, as shown by the large numbers of people across the age groups who are participating in education, but we need to ensure a whole of life focus, which means everything from a good foundation in primary school to opportunities for reskilling later in life. These access goals will be enhanced through better teaching, and government policies are providing incentives and assistance to maintain and lift standards.

The various provisions of this bill should be seen in the context of the government's pursuit of these goals. The success of the government's higher education policies is evidenced by the unprecedented number of Australians who are able to attend university and the increased level of resources available to universities. Our policies are making this a reality.

The government has created an extra 10,000 Commonwealth funded places for undergraduate students in the past two years. In 1998 the Commonwealth will fully fund 361,925 undergraduate student places in universities. This is a record number. No government in Australia's history has provided so many undergraduate places. Not only is this government making more undergraduate places available in 1998; the number of undergraduate places will continue to increase each year to 2000. By the year 2000, the government will be fully funding nearly 366,000 undergraduate places. This compares to less than 352,000 in 1996, the last year funded by a Labor budget.

To these figures can be added enrolments in addition to those undergraduate places fully funded by the Commonwealth. To encourage universities to offer these places, the government is offering partial funding of about $2,500 a place. In 1998 the universities offered around 29,000 of these extra places. To this can be further added full fee paying undergraduate places, an innovation of this government, taking the total number of extra places, on top of those fully funded by the Commonwealth, to nearly 30,000.

This government has made access a priority, and we have delivered. Australians have never had greater opportunities to enter higher education than they have in 1998. This government has confirmed its commitment to maintain public funding levels for higher education. This year the government will spend around $5.5 billion on higher education. Commonwealth funding for each full-time equivalent student will be more than $11,400, a significant increase on 1996 funding. This level of government spending on each student is also higher than at any point since 1990.

The reality is that universities have never had more resources than they have today. The government's policies to diversify the mix between public and private funding for universities means that there will be an estimated $8.5 billion available to Australian universities this year. This policy approach will secure university funding levels into the future. It is a policy that has been, and will continue to be, successful because it is a sensible solution to the needs of our universities and right for today's circumstances.

Consistent with this government's commitment to maintaining public funding levels for higher education, the bill provides for a total net increase of $10,990,000 to 1998 funds. This funding provides supplementation for price movements and additional superannuation expenses incurred by institutions. It also includes an increase of $5,824,000 in the 1998 funding limit for special grants, offset by an equivalent underexpenditure in 1997. The bill also legislates funding levels for the years 1999 and 2000. Funding for 1999 is increased from $3,877,383,000 to $3,885,630,000 and the funding limit for 2000 is set at $3,679,500,000.

In legislating funds for 1999 and 2000, the bill confirms to higher education institutions the overall funding levels detailed in the Higher Education Funding Report for the 1998-2000 Triennium. The bill also demonstrates this government's support for the continued growth of Australia's education and training export industry. The government is providing $21 million over the next four years for international marketing and other activities to promote our education and training services overseas.

The bill amends the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 to provide funding for expenditure on the international promotion of Australian education and training services by Australian Education International. AEI was previously known as the Australian International Education Foundation. The new name reflects new funding arrangements and the new direction set for it by the government. AEI will be more fully integrated with the operations of the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, which will enable it to act as an effective link between the offshore promotion of Australian education and training and broader government objectives for foreign affairs and trade.

In 1998, AEI will receive $1,016,000. In 1999 this will rise to $2,468,000, and by 2000 AEI will be funded to the extent of $3,883,000. It will have a number of key responsibilities in the areas of marketing, government to government coordination, research, facilitating access to markets, providing information and awareness raising. AEI services are provided through its offshore network including Australian Education Centres in Bangkok, Hanoi, Hong Kong, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, New Dehli, Paris, Seoul, Taipai and Tokyo.

This measure implements the government's response to the review of the Australian International Education Foundation by maintaining and strengthening a mechanism for promoting Australia's international education and training industry. It demonstrates the government's support for this industry at a time when it is contending with major changes in the overseas environment.

Finally, the bill also amends the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 and the Employment, Education and Training Act 1988 to reflect the name change of James Cook University of North Queensland to James Cook University. The matters in this bill continue the government's objectives of fostering a higher education sector that is open, accessible and well funded. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Dr Theophanous) adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Delegation to the 99th Conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union, Windhoek, Namibia, and bilateral visits to Angola, Zimbabwe and Mozambique

talk.start.para: —by leave—I am pleased to present the report of the Australian Delegation to the 99th Conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union, Windhoek, Namibia, and bilateral visits to Angola, Zimbabwe and Mozambique between 5 and 23 April 1998.

speech.para: In the recent past, delegations to Africa have had more than their share of problems—the well-known `Out of Africa' delegation immediately springs to mind. Fortunately, this delegation was one of the hardest working, unified and focused delegations that I have had to honour to lead. I commend my fellow delegates—the deputy leader of the delegation, Clyde Holding, Bruce Reid, Senator Sue Knowles, Senator Barney Cooney and Senator Julian McGauran—for their sterling efforts and contributions.

As I have indicated, the first part of the delegation's report relates to the 99th IPU Conference held in Windhoek, Namibia, on 5 to 11 April 1998. The IPU is the `United Nations' of the world's parliaments. It provides a unique opportunity for parliamentarians to discuss, debate and present resolutions on global issues. I have led the Australian delegation to several IPU conferences, and we are well known for our commitment to the aims and objectives of the IPU and, more particularly, for the significant contribution that we make to its work.

Our contribution to the 99th conference was outstanding. The conference ran for six days. The members of the delegation not only attended every session but also contributed to specific agenda items in the following ways: Mr Holding chaired and presented a report of the Human Rights Committee of Parliamentarians; Mr Reid chaired the drafting committee on foreign debt; Senator Cooney chaired the drafting committee and presented the report on conflict resolution; Senator McGauran participated on the drafting committee on HIV/AIDS; Senator Cooney and Senator Knowles participated in the general debate; Senator Knowles participated in the meetings of women parliamentarians; and I participated in the drafting committee on the emergency item on the situation in Kosovo, which unfortunately is not resolved at this moment, and also chaired and presented the report of the committee on Palestine's admission to the IPU.

No other national group at the conference made as significant a contribution to the substantive work of the conference as did our delegation. The number of delegates that Australia sends to the conference is small compared to many other countries, and this makes the impact of our contribution even more gratifying.

On behalf of the delegation, I commend to the House the texts of the final resolutions on the prevention of conflicts and the restoration of peace and trust in countries emerging from war; the return of refugees to their countries of origin, the strengthening of democratic processes and the hastening of reconstruction; action to combat HIV/AIDS in view of its devastating human, economic and social impact; foreign debt as a factor limiting the integration of the Third World countries into the processes of globalisation; the situation in Kosovo—measures to ensure a durable and peaceful resolution of the crisis; and the report of the Human Rights Committee of Parliamentarians. These are incorporated as appendices to the delegation's report.

Following the IPU conference in Namibia, the delegation undertook three bilateral visits—to Angola, Zimbabwe and Mozambique. In each of these countries, the deleg ation went about its work in a highly professional manner, undertaking a demanding schedule of visits and meetings in sometimes difficult and challenging conditions. Angola and Mozambique are fascinating countries. Angola still has the threat of civil war in its midst, whereas Mozambique is consolidating its peace process. Both countries were Portuguese colonies, and obtained independence with governments committed to Marxist-Leninism. Both have rejected that ideology and are now looking for assistance by way of foreign investment and trade to realise their enormous potential, particularly in the resources sector.

Angola and Mozambique both see Australia as playing a welcome and positive role in their progress and development. In Angola this is happening already with BHP Petroleum and Ashton Mining. Similarly, in Mozambique, P&O Australia is investing in the port of Maputo, and this will have a further impact when the Maputo transport corridor for Southern Africa is developed. Indeed, our relations with Mozambique become even more important as Mozambique is now a member of the Commonwealth. Parliamentary democracy in Angola and Mozambique is relatively new, and the Australian parliament can play an increasing role to encourage this process not only through parliamentary visits but also by the exchange of parliamentary staff with expertise in areas such as information technology.

In Zimbabwe, the delegation met with the Speaker of the parliament and groups and committees of the parliament itself. The parliament in Zimbabwe has been a feature of the political framework since independence in 1980. It was interesting to observe that the institution is looking at ways in which it may better perform its functions as an independent institution, having particular regard to the scrutiny and accountability of government.

The delegation's program in Angola, Zimbabwe and Mozambique included several meetings with representatives of governments. In fact, during the 10 days the delegation met with the President of Angola, the Prime Minister of Angola, six senior minister in three countries, five vice-ministers, the Speak ers of the three parliaments and the members of four parliamentary committees, and also observed the proceedings of the Angolan and Mozambican national assemblies. During many of these meetings, the delegation gained at first-hand an appreciation of the enormous economic potential of the countries in Southern Africa. Australia is well placed to assist these countries to realise this potential through trade and investment.

Australia is regarded highly in the region, particularly as a result of the diplomatic positions adopted in the 1970s and 1980s in relation to apartheid and the internal armed conflict in specific countries. Australia is seen as an honest broker. As these countries now move to stabilisation and development, Australia, particularly our commercial sector, is recognised as having the knowledge and expertise that is directly relevant to the challenges being addressed.

The delegation's view on this matter is supported by recent trade statistics showing that the value of exports to Southern Africa from 1992 to 1997 increased from $A450 million to $A1.33 billion. This represents a trend growth rate for the south and east African region of 27.5 per cent. The overall growth rate for Africa is 20.1 per cent, and this compares with 13 per cent for Oceania, 8.2 per cent for Asia, 3.8 per cent for Europe and 3.7 per cent for the Americas. These statistics indicate clearly that the potential for further growth is considerable and should be encouraged and enhanced.

This in turn raises the question of Australia's diplomatic representation in Southern Africa. In its report, the delegation shares the view expressed by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in its 1995 report on Southern Africa that the costs of maintaining overseas posts are significant. However, as a general statement, Australia does not have adequate representation in Africa, and our limited presence sends an unfortunate message to many African nations. The delegation also agrees with the findings of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade that additional diplomatic representation is desirable. The delegation recommends that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) review the feasibility of increasing diplomatic representation in the Southern Africa region and, in particular, Angola. If this is not possible, the delegation endorses the view of the joint committee that the minister should explore a number of other options to enhance Australia's diplomatic presence in the area.

During its bilateral visit, the delegation also took the opportunity to be briefed on or visit Australian aid projects. Landmines are a scourge on the landscape in Angola and Mozambique. In Angola, the delegation received a briefing on the situation there from the Norwegian People's Aid Project—an organisation with funding from Australia tasked with clearing landmines in that country. Members of the delegation also visited a factory on the outskirts of the Angolan capital that makes artificial limbs for the victims of landmines. The delegation was disappointed to hear that Australian funding for this project will cease, and our report recommends that this decision be reviewed.

In Mozambique, the delegation visited the United Nations demining project in Moamba—50 kilometres west of the capital, Maputo. We observed in situ these insidious weapons. I derived considerable satisfaction when skills learned many years ago and long since forgotten re-emerged to enable me to personally detonate charges to rid Mozambique of at least two of the cruellest impediments to its progress and development. I acknowledge the splendid work of Major Peter McIntosh, Australian Army, and the continuing funding assistance that is being provided by the Australian government for this vital project.

The delegation's report rightly recognises the contribution of so many people who contribute to the work of members and senators on official duties overseas. To them we thank you for a job well done. However, I would like to conclude my comments with two special commendations. Firstly, to Mr Alan Elliott, a member of the parliament of Zimbabwe who accompanied the delegation during its visit to that country, I know all the members of the delegation appreciated the hospitality, friendship and assistance he extended during our time in Zimbabwe. We were left in no doubt that he is a true friend of our parliament and our country.

Secondly, honourable members will be aware that for the last four years Kerry Sibraa has been Australia's High Commissioner in Zimbabwe and Mozambique and accredited as Ambassador to Angola and other countries in Southern Africa. Before this posting, Mr Sibraa was chair of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and, as President of the Senate, took a keen interest in the political, social and economic situation in Africa. As High Commissioner and Ambassador in Southern Africa, he maintained this enthusiasm and commitment. In May 1998 he completed a highly successful posting.

The delegation was left in no doubt that Kerry Sibraa has done a splendid job representing Australia in this region. We thank him and his wife, Julie, for their efforts during our visit and we wish them well in the future. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: —Before calling the honourable member for Bendigo, I might just say to the honourable member for Casey and others that the Out of Africa report and delegation that was referred to, and is often referred to in this parliament, was indeed a very hardworking delegation to that part of the world. There were just a few personality differences. There has been another delegation since and many of the members who were on that original delegation were on this delegation, too. That worked very successfully and was very hardworking.

—by leave—I thank the members of the opposition. I want to support the comments made by the leader of the delegation, the Hon. Bob Halverson, and congratulate him on his excellent leadership on what was a very significant visit to Africa.

speech.para: I wish to comment particularly on the level of Australian involvement in the Inter-Parliamentary Union 99th conference at Windhoek in Namibia. Australia played a much greater role than its population numbers would credit. Australia is very well regarded by all of the nations who participate in the Inter-Parlia mentary Union. As the leader, Mr Halverson, has indicated, there was a high level of commitment by the members of the delegation. I particularly want to mention Mr Clyde Holding, who has had a long-time involvement in the Committee on the Human Rights of Parliamentarians, and his ongoing work on that committee.

I also wish to mention Mr Halverson's role in Palestine's admission to the IPU. I had the privilege to be chairman of the drafting committee on foreign debt and Senator Cooney was chairman of the drafting committee on conflict resolution. We also had participation on the drafting committee on HIV/AIDS from Senator McGauran and on the drafting committee on the emergency item on the situation in Kosovo by Mr Halverson. Also Senator Cooney and Senator Knowles were involved in a meeting of women parliamentarians.

It was particularly good that Australia had such a high involvement. Australia is seen in international terms as being able to broker and bring about satisfactory negotiations, because we do not carry some of the political baggage that some nations may have. We are seen as being independent and able to negotiate and broker some satisfactory resolutions.

I want to briefly mention the bilateral visits to Angola, Zimbabwe and Mozambique. The leader of the delegation has already indicated Australia's involvement in the Norwegian Aid Project for the demining process in Angola and Mozambique. I want to pay a particular compliment to one of the most professional young Australian people that I have ever come into contact with. That was Major Peter McIntosh, who was involved in the demining process and in the training of local people in the demining process in Mozambique. Major McIntosh is a member of the Australian Defence Force and a technical adviser. He is training the locals and performing an excellent job. One could only marvel at the wonderful commitment made by a number of young Australian people who are in those countries in Africa.

The delegates and my spouse, Jenny Reid, went to the prosthetics factory in Angola. As a trained nurse, Jenny had a great appreciation of what was being undertaken there and the help that that prosthetics factory can be to people who are unfortunate enough to be maimed or injured by mines. One of the most horrifying experiences of your life is to walk through a minefield and then to see people around the streets of Mozambique who have suffered as a result of mines. It is a horrible experience.

I also congratulate Tim Clifton, Andrew Lodge and Carlos Paiva at BHP in Angola, who were very generous in their support to us. BHP and Ashton Mining are both active in those areas. There are many opportunities for Australia in Africa and there is a need for Australia to make a greater commitment to its involvement in the southern part of Africa.

I commend and support the report. I believe that it is an excellent report and the result of a lot of hard work. We did not have any conflicts, Mr Deputy Speaker. The delegation got on extremely well. There were no personality clashes. I would also like to commend the secretary, Mr Neil Bessell, who performed an excellent job in his role, and also the leader's adviser, Mr Richard Coventry, for their assistance. I also thank Alan Elliott, the MP from Zimbabwe, who is a wonderful advocate of Australia—I look forward to his visit to Australia later this year when we can repay some of his generosity—and the Hon. Kerry Sibraa, who has done a marvellous job as High Commissioner to Zimbabwe and Mozambique, and his wife, Julie. I commend the report to the House.

debateinfo.title: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 25 June, on motion by Dr Kemp:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government:
(1) for failing to provide schools with adequate resources to cope with the expected increase of up to 27,000 students a year as a result of the introduction of the Youth Allowance;
(2) for presenting distorted and misleading figures on school funding to the Australian people; and
(3) for imposing the unfair Enrolment Benchmark Adjustment on government schools".

This bill amends the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1996 to give effect to budget measures and to make a range of other changes. Some $40 million is being provided to extend the national Asian languages and studies in Australian schools program until the end of 1999. This program was initially introduced by the federal Labor government in 1994 to support, enhance, and expand Asian language studies in all Australian schools. The languages targeted are Chinese Mandarin, Indonesian, Japanese and Korean. The opposition is pleased to support the extension of this program to the end of the decade and hopefully beyond.

The other budget measure dealt with in this bill is the provision of $20 million for the so-called full service schools initiative to help schools cope with the influx of students which will occur with the introduction of the common youth allowance. The measures in this package—$13.5 million for the job pathway program and $6.2 million for the new apprenticeships access program—simply continue programs put in place by the Labor government. The coalition plans to spend around $40 million on this package of youth allowance measures—$100 million short of what a cabinet submission prepared by DEETYA recommended to the government. We have schools around Australia effectively being short-changed by $100 million, not through any fault of their own but through this government's decision to introduce a common youth allowance without also fully resourcing the needs of schools.

The opposition has been raising concerns in this area for 12 months. The common youth allowance in itself is not opposed by opposition. There are few, if any, jobs in the new economy for unskilled teenagers, and anyone in those adolescent years wanting to look for work needs a solid skills base with which to find work. But in sending students back to school, in abolishing unemployment benefits, in placing additional pressure on our schooling system, it is incumbent upon the federal government to accept its responsibility. It is incumbent upon the federal government to recognise that 27,000 students coming back into the schools system is a serious resource question and that it requires much more than the $40 million announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) earlier this year. It requires the $140 million recommended by DEETYA in its submission to cabinet last year. Without that additional $100 million, schools will struggle.

It is not as if the impact of the 27,000 students coming back into the schools system will be spread evenly. That impact will be concentrated in areas and in schools which have a high concentration of youth unemployment. Areas with a high rate of youth unemployment will obviously have more students coming back into the schools system in their local area. So the impact will be concentrated. For some schools in disadvantaged areas there is huge concern about what is likely to happen at the beginning of the 1999 school year. Schools are genuinely concerned that they have not had the planning, the advice and the resourcing that they need to cope with the concentrated influx of students in regions and districts with high rates of youth unemployment.

Beyond that there is a problem in that the students coming back into the system, of course, are students who would, by their choice, rather not be at school. The government wants to give them new skills and the opposition supports that, but we cannot provide the skills that are needed without the resources to make it work in the schools themselves. These are students with special needs—students who by free choice would rather not be at school—who, if not given the at-risk programs, the special attention, the counselling, the mentoring, the intensive classwork, may well disrupt the studies of other students. This government has taken a short-sighted approach that is harming schools, but it is also jeopardising the study potential of existing students—students who are looking to study and work hard at school and who do not want to be disrupted by students who are not being resourced and catered for as a product of the common youth allowance.

The government really needs to make some final action to fully resource these programs. Forty million dollars is inadequate, especially when the schools affected will have a concentrated number and a high number of young people coming back onto their enrolment list with special needs. Without those resources, there is the potential for the disruption of existing studies and the normal flow of school activities.

The bill also provides for flexibility of funding allocations under the literacy and country areas programs so that the most recent ABS census data can be used for determining relative need. I understand that there is a possibility of moving away from the method of using a needs based formula for distribution of these funds to an outcomes based approach. I hope that full consultations are made with the relevant school interests and organisations before any changes are made.

In addition, this bill inserts amounts for capital funding for government and non-government schools for the year 2001: $212 million for the government sector and $73.5 million for non-government schools. I note that the capital funding for non-government schools in Labor's last year, 1996, was $113 million—$40 million more than the coalition intends to provide five years later. I know that this is an issue of major concern to non-government school authorities and the confirmation of a further decline in funding from the Commonwealth is most undesirable.

The amounts provided for recurrent and capital expenditure for 1997 and subsequent years are adjusted by this bill for the most recent round of supplementation. This gives rise to a most important point with regard to claims made by the government about expenditure on schooling. On 12 May, the minister for schools claimed that the federal budget provided $153 million extra for schools in one year, a 3.8 per cent increase on the previous year. By 24 May the claim had become an increase for government schools of only $380 million in 1998 compared with 1996. Neither of these figures reveal very much. Neither allows for true year on year comparisons because they are not real. They are not cost adjusted figures presented in all fairness to the Australian people and the schools sector.

The second one includes attributed FAGs funding which has had to be recently revised downwards from 24 per cent to 17.6 per cent. This huge drop of 6.4 percentage points raises the question of the validity of all the bodgie calculations done by this government to try to present its policies in a favourable light. The infamous $2.3 billion figure touted for months by Dr Kemp, which included attributed FAGs of 24 per cent, is now exposed as having been inflated by $400 million—$400 million out, even using the minister's double and triple counting methodology.

The opposition has been saying for 2½ years that Dr Kemp is in fact a doctorer of the figures. I think there is now a recognition around the schools sector and this Parliament House that Dr Kemp is not to be believed on any use of figures with regard to schools funding or any aspect of education funding from the Commonwealth government.

The government is very sensitive about this issue of providing expenditure figures in real terms. Of course it is. I am sure it is to the lasting embarrassment of the bureaucrats that they know that their minister is doctoring the figures. In a sense, it is not surprising that there has been an attempt to conceal the real—that is, the cost adjusted, the inflation adjusted—figures. This is because the forward estimates of detailed school funding obtained in 1996 by the opposition revealed a decline in real Commonwealth funding for government schools of $87.5 million between 1996-97 and 1999-2000.

Since then, the government has refused to provide real terms data to allow the people of Australia to see clearly what is happening in terms of school funding. So, for all the promises of the Prime Minister to lift the standard of government and public accountability in Australia, the government will not even reveal the real funding figures, the inflation adjusted funding figures, for Australian schools. For every single parent around the country this is a matter of gross and serious concern. They want to know what the Commonwealth is doing, in cost adjusted terms, for their children through the schools system. The Prime Minister, who promised open and accountable government, has sullied his record in the fundamental area of school funding.

The government's excuse, that real funding figures would allow calculation of the estimated school price index, is not credible. It is not credible because, firstly, real terms expenditure details were actually provided in 1996. Secondly, even if a calculation were made about expected movements in the cost of schooling, this would be a national figure which would reveal nothing about increases in teachers' salaries, for example, in any particular state or territory. The government has nothing to hide other than Dr Kemp's deceit. The government has nothing to hide other than Dr Kemp's continual attempts to mislead the Australian people. It should release the real funding figures and we would have a legitimate and fair debate about the Commonwealth contribution to schooling in Australia.

This is a government afraid of the truth, afraid of being exposed by the truth. With the subject of schools funding having generated major debate under the Howard government, the electorate is being denied the official information needed to judge the statistics and the evidence for themselves. The school community is simply been denied access to the facts, and in a democracy that is a very bad thing.

The government has sought to deflect criticism because of its decision to introduce an enrolment benchmark adjustment. In operation, the EBA has proved to be inequitable and unjustified, earning the government criticism from parents, teachers, state governments and the general community. Indeed, it is a moment rare in the history of Australian schools policy that the government sector and the non-government sector would be united in saying that a certain piece of public policy is bad. That is what is happening with regard to the enrolment benchmark adjustment.

Government schools are saying, quite rightly, that it is plain wrong for them to lose Commonwealth funding, even though they are enrolling more students. It is plain wrong for government schools to enrol more students and lose money out of Canberra. The non-government sector is saying that, for a relatively small part of the Commonwealth schools budget, this EBA has reopened the undesirable debate about state aid. It has given the impression in the public debate that the schools funding question is the old issue of government versus non-government schools. The non-government sector knows that that is a bad thing for the quality and fairness of the debate in Australia.

Minister Kemp, rare among Australian policy makers, has devised something so bad, so unfair and so undesirable in its impact on schools that both the government sector and the non-government sector are saying, `Abolish it. Do away with it.' The government schools are saying that it is unfair and denies them needed resources. Non-government schools are saying that it is the wrong way to consider the debate about schools funding in this country.

In 1997, almost every state and territory increased its enrolments in government schools. Every state except Tasmania was subject to the EBA. In New South Wales, for example, the Commonwealth took $1,525 for each of the 2,839 extra students enrolled in the government school system in that state—far more than the general per capita payment from the Commonwealth of $379 for each primary student and $559 for each secondary student. For New South Wales, each of those extra students became a net cost to the state of between $966 and $1,146. Nationally, the EBA charge imposed by the Commonwealth for each additional student in the government system was $1,400. This means that state governments lost between $842 and $1,022 for each of the additional 8,500 students enrolled in those government schools in 1997.

What sort of funding system is it when government schools can enrol more students and lose funding out of Canberra? This is a government that has gone absolutely mad in its determination to reopen the old debate between government and non-government schools. Kemp has no answers in education policy, so he has fallen back to the oldest trick in the political book: divide and rule; try to set the government against the non-government sector. The healthy news is that it has not worked, because government schools have seen through the folly of this approach and non-government schools know—and I pay credit to those non-government school authorities—that this is a bad bit of policy, and they are supporting the Labor Party in its determination to abolish the enrolment benchmark adjustment.
Of course, the government does not see sense in this. Senator Ellison, in self-righteous mode, said in a media release on 24 May:
Any suggestion that the Government has decreased funding to government schools is wrong.

The minister should explain to this House, to his own chamber, the Senate, and to the Australian people how giving government schools less money for more students does not reflect decreased funding. This is a government which will argue that black is white, that day is night. They will argue anything and concoct any set of statements to try to cover up the fact that government schools are worse off out of the enrolment benchmark adjustment.

How can the minister say that the government has not decreased funding for government schools when every single education authority around the country is saying that the government has? The fact that most states had more rather than fewer students last year than the year before highlights the flaw in the rationale for the EBA: that, if one or two students leave a school or a class, there is no measurable saving in terms of teacher costs or administrative overheads. The EBA is based on a comparison of average costs, which become meaningless in the practical operation of each school. When the overall level of enrolments is increasing, it becomes even more meaningless.

The EBA is nothing more than a crude grab for cash by the coalition government at the expense of young Australians—at the expense of every single school and every single educator in this country. It is one of the first things that a Beazley Labor government can do for the school sector: abolish the enrolment benchmark adjustment.

I want to turn to some other issues about school funding in this fairly broad piece of legislation. I have maintained in my 15 months as the shadow minister for education that the old debate on school funding in Australia, resurrected by this government, between government and non-government funding shares is moribund. The real and tangible variations in the standards and the quality of Australian schools do not lie in an arbitrary debate of government versus non-government sectors; the great variations lie within sectors. I have been to government schools in this country that are an absolute credit to those who run them—to the teachers, the parents and the government officials—government schools that one would regard as advanced information technology centres for the next century.

I stood in absolute amazement, absolutely gobsmacked, at the Caulfield North Public School in Melbourne watching a nine-year-old student designing software programs in a computer room that was an absolute credit to the fundraising capacity of that school. He was not just playing computer games, he was designing the software package. In this age of possibility, this age of knowledge enhancement, what a wonderful thing that we can have nine-year-olds in government schools that can access the technology needed to develop that sort of skill. It really does open one's eyes to the possibilities of education in an era of unlimited potential in learning technology. But, just the same, I have visited government schools that would be very little different from when I went to school in the 1960s or when my colleague here, the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), went to school in the 1930s.

talk.start.para: —I am still holding my age better than you.

—Did I say the 1930s? I think I meant the 1950s. I visited schools that look no different from the 1950s and 1960s, where the approach is just chalk and talk— schools without the facilities, the technology, the up-to-date learning methods that are reflected in other parts of the country. So the variations are within sectors. So too have I seen in the non-government school sector the fact that some non-government schools are so advanced and a wonderful credit to their teachers and parents. Other non-government schools are really struggling with the cost of vocational education, struggling with the limited capacity of their parents to make a private contribution, struggling on just about every single front.

speech.para: So the variations within the school sector are not so much between government and non-government schools; they are within sectors. And this just makes the point that it really is time to end the old debate. Let us abolish the enrolment benchmark adjustment, and let us abolish any perception that we need to set the funding interests of government schools against those in the non-government sector. I simply want to fund schools on the basis of need. If there is a school that needs extra resources to produce the results that we want for all young Australians, let us find the funding mechanisms that produce that result.

Dr Kemp, of course, is engaged in an arbitrary debate about choice. He is not worried so much about need; he thinks that every single parent should have an unlimited choice of schooling. For a lot of parents, the only choice available is their neighbourhood government school, or fee relief if their children go to a non-government school. So many working families in Australia are struggling with the income that they need to pay large non-government school fees. This choice agenda is limited by that simple economic reality. A government that is deregulating the labour market, a government that has run down employment and economic opportunities in Australia's regions, is running down the capacity for parents to exercise choice. If you have not got the money to pay substantial non-government school fees, the choice is limited. It is a matter of parish benevolence in the non-government sector, where there is fee relief, or the choice of a neighbourhood government school. So choice should not be the paramount priority in the way in which we fund schools; it must be on the basis of need. With some of the new technology emerging about the identification of school needs, we can make substantial advances.

I believe there is an argument now to set an effective national standard for what we want our schools to achieve. Let us set down the model of the school in Australia that we want for primary and secondary students: the sort of vocational education, the IT, the teacher-student ratio, the sort of capital facilities, and issues of curriculum. Let us set a broad national standard about what we want every single Australian school to achieve and, if there are schools below that standard, whether they are government or non-government, let us find a funding mechanism to bring them up to the appropriate standard. This can be possible. The ERI review is looking at some of the sophisticated ways of measuring school need and the funding response that might come from the Commonwealth. We can learn a lot from that process. But the most important thing is to get better cooperation between federal and state governments.

We know as a parliament that for years in Australia we have had this terrible problem of cost shifting in the health system—the states trying to push public hospital costs on to the Medicare and pharmaceutical budget of the Commonwealth government. While governments bicker and squabble about funding, patients lose out. We have now got the cost shifting problem, regrettably, happening in Australian schools. Non-government schools are being used by governments like the Victorian government as a way of shifting costs from the state budget to the Commonwealth government. Because we have the dual funding scheme in Australia whereby the Commonwealth is the primary funder for non-government schools and the states the primary funder for government schools, there is now an active incentive for governments like the Kennett administration to close down government schools and push the cost onto the opening of new non-government schools funded by the federal government.

There is the same cost shifting problem in health. While governments bicker and shift their money around and try to minimise their own budgets, students, teachers and parents lose out. We have got to do something about that; we have got to have federal-state agreement about a common funding methodology that can bring every single Australian school up to the desirable national standard. The only way we can get agreement is with leadership from the Commonwealth. But what have we had from this government in Commonwealth-state relations in education? We have had nothing but warfare, nothing but disputation and nothing but confrontation by Minister Kemp.

I am a great believer in upping the ante on Commonwealth-state relations. In all areas of Australia they have always been poor. The problem is that what we put on the Commonwealth-state agenda are 20 little items that politicians can find ways of bickering about. What we need is one big concept on the school education agenda that will bring out the best in federal and state politicians and public administrators. That is the concept of funding schools up to an appropriate national standard on the basis of need and forever doing something about a quality funding methodology for all Australian schools—up the ante, show people the big possibilities that come out of the new, sophisticated identification of school need and try to encourage the states, with acceptable funding support from the Commonwealth, to do the right thing and to reach agreement about the better way we need to fund schools in Australia. This is a wonderful opportunity that this government has totally passed over with its approach of confrontation with the states and territories.

Finally, I want to mention another important role for the Commonwealth. It is true that the federal government does not run any schools or employ any teachers in Australia, but it has a big funding responsibility and, I believe, a big policy responsibility for the way in which school education is discharged in this country. One of the problems we have got in the government sector is that we have big state departments that are centralised and monolithic and there is not a lot of capacity for ministers to make bold innovation. The New South Wales education department, for in stance, is the biggest in the world. It must be an intimidating thought for a state minister to think, `If I make a 10 per cent change to the system, the consequences might be enormous across a huge number of schools.' I suppose after the experience with Terry Metherell in New South Wales in the late 1980s, nobody is putting their hand up for innovation.

With the state government sector, I think there is an argument for the federal government to provide some seed funding, some promotion of innovation, because we live in a world of constant change, economic and social, but we have not had a lot of changes in the way in which schools are structured and curriculum is delivered. We have had so many changes in information technology and the possibilities of a learning society, but most of our schools in the government sector are still fairly well wedded to the comprehensive model that was devised in the 1950s and 1960s. There is a real need for innovation, for pilot schemes, for experiments and for innovation that will address some of the issues that are arising within the school sector in our post-industrial society.

One of the big issues is in the middle years of schooling, the problem of 13- to 16-year-olds feeling alienated from the learning process, young adolescents dropping out of school and young people saying that learning is not for them, they just do not like the school learning environment. So the middle school years has become a critical issue especially—as I am told by educators—more for males than females. This problem of alienation is critical. It is a difficult thing for teachers to handle in schools but also more difficult for policy makers because somebody dropping out of school at age 14 is the long-term youth unemployed of the future or is the young person who might turn to street crime or some undesirable social habits. We must keep every single adolescent in this country connected with the learning process. We must do something about the crisis in middle schooling in Australia.

One thing we need to acknowledge is that young people learn in a variety of ways. There is no one form of intelligence or learning inclination; there are many forms and ways of learning. So we need to cater school learning opportunities around the needs and the inclinations of every single student so we can make sure that every young Australian can have a positive learning experience through the school process. That might be in the more traditional academic or vocational areas or it might be in the areas of the creative arts, multimedia or the trades, but the positive learning experience is all important in the middle school years. There are some wonderful examples—the Launceston workshop and the Ballajura community school in the northern suburbs of Perth—where innovation according to this approach is taking place. But we need more innovation promoted by the federal government to come with up real answers to the crisis in middle schooling.

The very best thing for public policy is that every single young Australian who is successful at school is a young Australian who will not be on drugs when they get to their late teens, is a young Australian who will not be long-term unemployed and is a young Australian who will not need government training assistance in labour market programs, employment, drug prevention and crime prevention initiatives. Most of the problems are happening in the teenage years of 13 to 16, yet most of the government focus in dealing with these issues and the funding initiatives is on the ages 16 to 20. We have to move down the age ladder to the middle school years and make sure that every single young Australian has a positive learning experience and a genuine sense of social belonging, social belonging out of their school and out of their community.

So it is a big agenda arising from legislation like this, but an agenda that this government has by and large ignored. This government's main contribution to the school funding debate has been to reopen the divisive question of government versus non-government schools and it has been to ignore substantially the need for innovation and pilot programs in the middle school years. To this government's lasting shame, in its first budget it made education and training the No. 1 target for funding cuts.

Education—school education in particular—is the very best investment we can make in Australia's future. A Labor government will be making that investment and ensuring that every single school, whether government or non-government, comes up to an appropriate national standard and that every school can have the same feeling and successes of Caulfield North or the other wonderful government and non-government schools. That will come only from a Labor government giving the right public policy and the right leadership when it comes to school education in Australia.

talk.start.para: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

—I am pleased to be speaking on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1998 which is before the parliament today. At the outset I would like to say that, amongst some quite laudable things the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) said, it is regrettable that he had to rehash some of these myths that somehow the coalition has been cutting money out of education, when we have not. We are actually putting more into education, as I will come to. I was disappointed to see some of the old sectarian ideologies being rehashed about government and non-government school funding. This government stands for choice in schooling. We believe that that is the way to go.

speech.para: I congratulate the government for bringing this bill before the House. In particular I would like to congratulate the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp), who has done a magnificent job not only in primary and secondary school education but in education overall, including university education. He has a great grasp of the topic and he is putting down some quite revolutionary and visionary shifts which will benefit education in this country.

I would also like to pay tribute to the minister's 2IC, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Senator Ellison), who has proved to be a very diligent minister and is doing a great job for the children of Australia. I am particularly pleased that he has been willing to listen to many propositions that have been put to him by constituents from my electorate. In fact, this government has given education virtually the highest priority of all portfolios. I, for one, am pleased to see that. We are putting more money into schools and building better and new schools. I notice in a press release which came out in the last couple of days that the pupil-teacher radio in this country is now 18 to 1, which is close to the lowest ratio in the whole Asia-Pacific region, which includes countries such as Japan, New Zealand and the United States of America.

I am particularly pleased that this government is also wiling to pay attention to some of the small detail. In particular, I am thinking of the Isolated Children's Parents Association lobby group, the ICPA, which represents 12,000 students in rural and remote areas. Twelve thousand is a small number out of the total school population of 3.2 million but, in the two years since coming to power, we have increased the correspondence allowance for primary school children from $500 to $1,000, we have increased the allowance for secondary school children by a similar amount, and we have also increased the non-means tested boarding allowance to $2,900.

I believe we have to do a great deal more in this area, because the year 12 completion rate for children in remote areas runs at only about 52 per cent compared to the urban rate in this country of 70 per cent or more. In fact, I saw some disturbing figures for male students completing year 12. In remote areas, less than 45 per cent of male students complete year 12. Often that is because parents have very limited means. I know of cases where parents have had to pull their children out of school and send them off to shearing sheds to earn an income so that the family can continue to survive. As we approach the end of the 20th century, that is not a desirable situation. I exhort this government to do even more to resource the education of children in remote areas. I think that is taxpayers' money very well spent indeed.

There are a number of elements to this bill. One is the provision of $20 million for the introduction of what is called the full service schools program. That money is to be spent over three years from 1998 to provide additional support to schools to develop innovative programs and services that address the needs of young people returning to school following the introduction of the youth allowance and current students who are at risk of not completing year 12 or making a successful transition from school to training or employment. I think that is a very worthwhile goal indeed.

As well, $40.2 million will be provided for the extension of the previous government's national Asian languages and studies in Australian schools strategy. That strategy will take place over two years from 1998 to support the enhancement and expansion of Asian languages and Asian studies provision. I think just about everybody in Australia, with the possible exception of the One Nation Party, would support that. The full service schools program is part of a Commonwealth initiative to provide additional funding for schools. Industry and community groups will have the opportunity to provide education and training for young people as a result of the introduction of the youth allowance.

We have other measures in this program. We have provided an additional $13.5 million over the 1998-2000 period for the jobs pathways program and an additional $6.21 million over a similar period for the new apprenticeship access program. These measures are not funded under this act, but they are worth mentioning because I believe they too are excellent measures. The minister is to be congratulated for supporting them.
