Let us not send back to school some 27,000, as the member for Werriwa mentioned in his amendment, and expect the school system to cope with them, because it simply cannot.

I have talked to teachers and educational professionals right around this country who are absolutely distraught about the prospect of these kids coming back into the school system. The kids are not going to be making a contribution in class. They do not want to be there. In many cases, they have been out of the system for more than two years. What impact is that going to have on the kids in the class who do want to learn and who are interested in what is happening? What sort of disruption is this policy going to cause for them?

As the member for Werriwa has pointed out, the government has very generously allocated something like $42 million to schools in this country to deal with this problem. I think the member for Werriwa suggested that that falls short by some $100 million if you are really going to expect the school system to cater for the 27,000 kids re-entering school. But, again, this is the ideologically driven approach. This is the approach of the member for Goldstein. It is the same approach that leads to policies such as the enrolment benchmark adjustment.

The Labor Party got over its state aid debate long ago. We are committed to both a strong public system—a government based school system—and a private system. My kids go to a Catholic school—all three of them. I am proud of that. I am a product of the Catholic system myself. It is a good system and a system we need. It costs me more than $1,000 each year to send my kids to that school, and probably more than that if you take into account other costs. I am fortunate that I can afford to pay that more than $1,000, but not all Australians can.

In this country we need to ensure that, regardless of your means, you have access to a decent and quality education. But the member for Goldstein's policies—supported by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Mr Abbott), who has just arrived—are trying to force funding away from those government schools into the private sector. What does that mean? It quite clearly means a decline in educational standards in the government sector. It also means more stress on teachers working within the government sector. But this is the ideological approach.

In the regions, in electorates like my own, some state schools rely on a critical mass of students to survive. In some small government schools you need lose only one or two stu dents to render that school unviable. What the member for Goldstein wants to do is encourage this shift from the government sector to the private sector. What that will lead to in electorates like my own is the closure of government schools. In many of these areas it is not easy to access the private sector schools. Some will, but some who are already disadvantaged—and that is why they are in the government schools in the first place—will find it extremely difficult to access those private schools.

I recently attended a hook-up of a Sky Channel viewing which was intended to reach all members of the New South Wales Teachers Federation. They had a two-hour stop-work meeting to protest. They are very concerned by this government's approach to schools funding in this country. Likewise, those involved in higher education are concerned about this government's approach to higher education. They are concerned about up-front fees and the implications of those for equity of access to education. They are concerned about HECS differentials. They are concerned that this government is completely driven by the view that the private sector is good and government is bad. I do not agree. A government has a very important role to play. It raises taxes and redistributes that money to ensure that all Australians, regardless of their means, have the opportunity to access decent community services—services required by them. Just as important is the ability to access decent and quality education in this country.

As the member for Barton (Mr McClelland) pointed out, that opportunity is everything. This approach by the government will do nothing to bring down youth unemployment. They know that, and that is why already in a budget which projects more than 12 months out they have run up the white flag on unemployment. That is recognition on their part that this particular policy will fail.

talk.start.para: —We are discussing the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1998 . I propose to take a clearly jaundiced New South Wales view of this bill and the government's general ap proach to education as we view it in New South Wales. In doing so, I am supporting the amendment moved by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), which states:

speech.para: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government:
(1) for failing to provide schools with adequate resources to cope with the expected increase of up to 27,000 students a year as a result of the introduction of the Youth Allowance;
(2) for presenting distorted and misleading figures on school funding to the Australian people; and
(3) for imposing the unfair Enrolment Benchmark Adjustment on government schools".

I am greatly indebted to one of my constituents for some details relating to this particular issue. This particular constituent would be considered to be fairly close to the action as far as education in New South Wales is concerned. The New South Wales minister commissioned a report called Savaged for a surplus . In introducing the report, the minister stated:

John Howard, Peter Costello and David Kemp cannot claim to have turned a deficit into a surplus by slashing Commonwealth expenditure and then turn around to claim they have increased funding for education and training. The facts speak for themselves.

I certainly support the claims from New South Wales that this year's budget surplus has been built on the backs of students, teachers, parents, schools, TAFE colleges and universities in order to allow the Howard government to offer an electoral tax cut bribe later this year.

The New South Wales experience is that education and training funding has been massively cut again this year, and further more damaging cuts are programmed for the next year and the following years. The impact of the 1998-99 federal budget on education, training and jobs is quite awful. The report I have already referred to, Savaged for a surplus, spells that out in graphic detail, and I propose to quote at length from it because that will be the most effective method of exposing the dreadful behaviour of the Howard government. The report states:

An analysis of this year's 1998-99 federal budget again finds massive cuts to education and training funding. Students, schools, TAFE colleges and universities have been savaged for the sake of a budget surplus.
Claims by the federal government of an extra $2.3 billion for government schools are not substantiated by an analysis of their budget papers.

Even schools minister, Senator Ellison, writing to the Australian (4/5/98) acknowledged that halfway through the four-year funding period the increase for government schools was only $127 million—unadjusted for price increases and additional school enrolments.

While the federal government and a number of its ministers continue to claim Commonwealth funding for education and training is increasing, the analysis of their own official budget documents shows the contrary to be the case.

This year's budget has only a few minor new measures affecting Commonwealth funding of education and training. To the casual observer, it might be considered one where schools, TAFE and other training, higher education and student assistance have been spared from further Commonwealth cuts.
Such a view ignores the detail, all of which is available in many tables which I will not include but which are available if challenged. The report further states:

This year, savings in real terms from education—schools, TAFE/VET and higher education—total $404m or 4.5%. While an initial examination of the federal budget papers indicates that the total 1998-99 expenditure on schools is expected to grow 0.8% in real terms or $34m compared with 1997-98, the detail reveals programmed savage cuts to government school funding. The small level of total growth is due entirely to the substantial increase in funding for the non-government school sector.

Current funding of government schools declines 7.2% in real terms between 1997-98 and 2001-02, a fall of over $101m. Funding for private schools increases by over $154m or 6.8% in real terms during the same period.
Cuts in Commonwealth funding for government schools arise from the following:
The impact of the enrolment benchmark adjustment (EBA) which is estimated to require government schools to pay $92m to the Commonwealth in 2001-02;
Cuts to program funding estimated at $45m in 2001-02;
Cost shifting to the states through the common youth allowance (CYA) which is projected to have a net cost of over $168m annually; and
Cuts to the capital works program for new schools.

Policies of reduced access to student assistance by tighter targeting of the means test for the program are being implemented. Scrutiny of the impact of targeting policies is made difficult because the budget moves student assistance for under 25 year olds from education to social security and combines it with other income support arrangements under the CYA.

Between 1997-98 and 2001-02 Commonwealth outlays on education decline slightly in real terms, but significant additional funding flows to the non-government sector. This is achieved by adjusting sector shares.
The real impact of Commonwealth school education funding policies is evident in the change in sector shares of Commonwealth expenditure.

The EBA reduces Commonwealth grants for government schools where there is a transfer of students from the government to the non-government sector. This occurs despite increasing enrolments in government schools.
In the current financial year, government schools were liable to pay almost $17m to the Commonwealth, but concessions and once-off provisions that were applied reduced the payment to $11.9m.
Unless the Commonwealth modifies its policy on the EBA, government schools will pay $33.2m in 1998-99.
The CYA is projected to have a net cost to the states of over $168m annually for schools by 2001-02 when the Commonwealth will not provide any special assistance.

Just to clarify where I am in my presentation so far, I would say that I am certainly a strong supporter of the dual system of education, both the private and the government sector, but I certainly do not think one should be funded at the expense of the other. My own children went to both private and government schools. Of course, as the member for my electorate, I am very concerned with education generally in the electorate, and I want to see both systems thriving.

But it does appear in relation to the figures I have quoted so far that government schools are suffering under this current budget. I also want to refer to the common youth allowance, which, once again, I think, will possibly present extreme difficulties to both sectors of education. With it being 1 July, today is the day that the common youth allowance comes into operation. I just want to go back a bit and recap on some of the things I personally have said on the issue of the common youth allowance. I will refer to remarks I made in the debate on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill 1997 in November last year. Relating to the common youth allowance, I stated:

I am advised that within my electorate of Greenway some 308 children will be forced back into the school system. While this in itself may not seem a large figure, I am sure that, if I went to all the principals in my electorate collectively and said to them, `You have to find places for another 308 children,' they would collapse with fear. As we know, schools are already overcrowded. To take that argument a bit further, it is not only the kids who are affected but also the families. If you add to those 308 children the mothers and fathers who are also affected by this extra pressure, you are looking at close to 1,000 people who are affected directly and indirectly by this legislation within my own electorate of Greenway.

Receipt of income support should certainly be tied to a range of alternative activities—not just school education—which help young people to get work and reach their full potential. To abolish unemployment benefits while also slashing education opportunities is the wrong way to reform the welfare state. This is the negative approach of a government more concerned with winding back the role of government than creating new opportunities through the possibilities of education and training.

Young adults who are old enough to vote, to go to war, to get married—and many do the latter—and who are looking for work are clearly independent. They should not be forced by the imposition of a parental income, assets and actual means test to rely on their low income families for support. I believe young Australians who are looking for work should be encouraged to take up work opportunities by the restoration of the earnings credits scheme, mirroring the student income bank arrangements.

Having made those remarks in November last year, I come now to some immediate effects of the introduction of the common youth allowance—and I would suggest that many people who will be affected by this measure are still not aware of the damage that it will do to disadvantaged groups in our country. I have already received some representations from people in my electorate raising some concerns about how this common youth allowance will affect them personally.

I have already raised this issue in debate in the Main Committee, but I would like to repeat two cases. The first relates to a single father—Arthur, I will call him—and his daughter Melissa. Melissa sat for her higher school certificate in 1996, completed her first year Bachelor of Commerce at the University of England in 1997, but was unable to continue her studies this year due to a lack of finance. Melissa is now 19, unemployed, and did receive unemployment benefits—at least up until today—of $170 a fortnight. This young lady's income will now drop to $20 a fortnight due to the parental income assessment under the common youth allowance scheme. She will then have to rely on her father for boarding and lodging. That is one example.

The other case related to a mother, being quite concerned, who rang me. Her position was that her son had left school, again in December 1996—and here we are talking about children who have been out of school for a couple of years. Since that time, he had completed a life skills training course at TAFE. He had worked for two months in the timber industry. He had worked for seven months as a tyre fitter on $4.50 an hour. He had had other occasional casual work.

This young man is currently unemployed. He turned 18 on 30 June, and his mother had expected that he would then qualify for unemployment benefits and at least have sufficient money to enjoy a social life. But this young man, who is now 18 months out of school, has completed the TAFE course, has worked, is now unemployed, but does not qualify for unemployment benefits under the government's new scheme. The government now expects this low income family to support this particular young man. The combined income for this family is approximately $480 a week, with both parents working—the mother part time—to support four people. Another son is an apprentice and he can only contribute marginally to the family budget.

This situation has already caused tension in the family. The mother is worried that her son could leave home, as he previously has done. She is worried that he then would be exposed—as other young people in this situation could be—to falling under bad influences and be subject possibly to petty crime to obtain sufficient money to live. These two examples, I believe, give a clear indication of how this government's policy relating to the common youth allowance will hurt struggling Australians.

I now turn back to the report that I have already indicated I am referring to—the report produced by the New South Wales government, relating to the impact of the federal budget on education, training and jobs, entitled Savaged for a surplus:
The budget shows that the Commonwealth's funding commitments in literacy largely are a re-packaging of former programs for English as a second language and disadvantaged schools.
This budget puts in place the largest single cut in the program of spending cuts for higher education, announced by the former minister, Senator Amanda Vanstone.

The implications of the cuts are that they will wipe out all the funding gains made by the higher education sector over the period 1990-91 to 1994-1995. They will return higher education funding to pre 1990-91 levels.

For all of the foregoing detailed analysis, it is clear that the policy announcements by the government about education are simply a giant smokescreen. The report from New South Wales blows away the smokescreen and leaves the Howard government starkly exposed to a critical examination that leaves the government with nowhere to hide.

The minister, who has daily lectured and hectored the parliament, is now just like the emperor with his new clothes—bereft of credibility and nakedly and strangely opposed to education in general. Despite an enormous PR team and media advisers in plague proportions, the government will be unable to hide from its disgraceful policy effects upon primary schools and secondary education. For our part on this side of the House, we will ensure that, despite our limited resources, we will move to expose the government. I congratulate the New South Wales government, which has provided us and the media with just the right tools to do so.

talk.start.para: —This States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1998 , while you would not know it from listening to the debate, does two things. First, it provides $20 million for the introduction of full service schools over three years from 1998 to help schools support young people returning to school following the introduction of the youth allowance and to assist other at-risk students. The other key element in this bill is the provision of a further $40 million for an extension of the national Asian languages and studies in Australian schools strategy over two years from 1998. That is what this bill actually does.

speech.para: We have seen a series of opposition speakers engage in the kind of mindless head-banging and `we wuz robbed' lamentation which tends to get this parliament a bad name—and which deservedly gets this parliament a bad name. I was disappointed to hear the final speaker for the opposition, the member for Greenway (Mr Mossfield), talk about the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), in such contemptuous terms. The minister is a man who has devoted his life to education. David Kemp spent many years as a full professor in a university system. To suggest for a moment that David Kemp is not deeply committed to the education of everyone is quite wrong. It is utterly implausible and it brings this parliament into disrespect. I am very disappointed that the member for Greenway, a man of justifiably high standing in the community, should, of all members opposite, make this kind of cheap sneer at a minister who is doing his best to improve the Australian education system.

There were three basic points raised by the members opposite. The first was that this government had savagely cut funding to schools. That is simply untrue. In the period 1997 to 2000, total direct Commonwealth schools funding will approach $20 billion. The budget papers show that funding for schools is estimated to increase each year until 2000 at an average rate of 3.6 per cent a year. This year, close to $4 billion is specifically earmarked for school spending. In 1996, the last year governed by Labor's budget, just over $3 billion was earmarked for school spending. So on any yardstick, school spending has increased under this government.

I am perfectly prepared to admit that this government has cut a number of outlay programs, but we have not cut school education. The government has deliberately and properly insulated school spending from any cuts because we appreciate that a good school education is the foundation of every Australian's life and that so many of the social problems which ravage our country have their roots in an inadequate grounding, and that begins at school. So the last thing this government would do is cut school funding. We have not cut school funding; we will not cut school funding. It is wrong for members opposite to repeat over and over again something which is simply fanciful.

In response to the member for Greenway's reference to the New South Wales government report, let me point out that government schools in New South Wales will receive $520 million in direct Commonwealth funding in 1998. In federal Labor's last year, the New South Wales government was allocated $471 million. In other words, we have allocated almost $50 million more in 1998 than was allocated under the Labor government. The member for Greenway should go back and check his figures. I am sure he is simply repeating what he has been told by the New South Wales government, but they are telling fibs. The teachers union is perpetrating myths. I was delighted to see that the Independent Teachers Association came out recently and savagely attacked the New South Wales Teachers Federation for the myths that are being perpetrated by the federation about this government's policy.

The second critique was that this government favours private schools over government schools. That is dead wrong. This government favours good schools. This government wants all Australians, whatever school they attend, whatever choice they make, to get the best possible education. There have been no cuts whatsoever to government schools. There have been no specific boosts to private schools. We have done two things. First of all, we have ended Labor's new schools policy, which should have been called the `no new schools policy' because it effectively prevented new private schools from opening. We have ended that, and if people want to choose a non-government education for their children, why shouldn't they be able to? Why does the Labor Party want to drive kids out of perfectly good independent schools and further overload the government system? That is precisely what their policy would do.

talk.start.para: —With 20 students?

—There are many perfectly good schools with 20 students. Are you saying to the teachers and parents at those schools that there is something wrong with those schools? Are you saying that there is something wrong with those teachers or with the education? That is the trap that members opposite have fallen into—in parroting mindlessly, `Private schools are being favoured; government schools are being ripped off.' In mindlessly parroting this line, members opposite are attacking, wittingly or unwittingly, each and every youngster, each and every teacher and each and every parent who is sending their children to new private schools.

speech.para: The enrolment benchmark adjustment has been heavily demonised in this debate. The enrolment benchmark adjustment is a relatively simple mechanism for ensuring that state governments do not cost shift by, in a sense, encouraging people to take off to the private sector. We all know that every student who enters the private sector costs the federal government a great deal of money and saves the state government a great deal of money. The enrolment benchmark adjustment is saying to the state governments that, if they lose students from their schools and the Commonwealth gains them in a sense when they go to independent schools, we will take some of the money back. In 1997 the amount involved was $12 million. In a total school education budget of something like $4 billion, this is the merest drop in the ocean. For members opposite to talk about this enrolment benchmark adjustment as if it is the greatest attack on government schools is quite wrong. Again, members opposite are trying to create a climate of fear, gloom and despair that does not do anyone in this House any good and certainly does not do our country any good.

The final basic critique of members opposite is that the youth allowance, which comes into effect today, is again a savage attack on young people. Let us get the youth allowance quite clear in our minds. The youth allowance will affect 416,000 young people. Seventy thousand will gain access to rent assistance; 16,000 will gain from independence criteria; 41,000 will gain from the abolition of the $1,000 minimum rate for Austudy; 20,000 will gain from the abolition of the education leavers waiting period; and nearly 4,000 will gain from removing maintenance from the personal income test. The ALP and members opposite are saying that 153,750 young Australians who will gain from the introduction of the youth allowance today should give the money back. That is effectively what they are saying. They are saying that those 153,000 youngsters should not be getting the money.

I concede that there are a few losers under this scheme. Yes, some youngsters on unemployment benefits will lose money because of the application of the parental means test. But why should it be easier for young Australians to get the dole than to go on to education? That is what the opposition's policy implies. That is what the speeches that they have made imply—that it should be more advantageous for young people to be on the dole than in education. That is absolutely the wrong approach. We are saying that the same rules that used to apply to Austudy should apply to unemployment recipients up to the age of 21. In other words, we are asking the House to accept that the rules that the Labor government were happy to apply to Austudy should henceforth apply to unemployed people as well. If it is fair for these rules to apply to students, why is it not fair for the same rules to apply to people who are seeking work?

The member for Greenway said that there were two alternatives: welfare through the youth allowance or a life of petty crime. There is another alternative, and it is work. And that is what we want young Australians who are not engaged in the education system to be involved in. We are saying to young Australians that we want them to make a choice between gainful employment on the one hand and useful education and training on the other. That is what our changes are designed to implement; that is what they will do. We should get a little credit from members opposite for those objectives.

The sad thing about this debate has been the cloth cap proletarianism of the politics of envy that members opposite so easily lapse into. It is as if every problem in society has one simple solution, that is, the spending of massive amounts of government money. What everyone has to realise is that government does not spend a dollar that it does not get from someone else. The members opposite are saying that certain people should be getting more money for this or for that. That money comes from the general public of Australia—it comes out of their pockets. This government does not believe in robbing Peter to pay Paul. This government believes in trying to ensure that we have a system which is fair to everyone—fair to the taxpayers of Australia as well as to the beneficiaries of various government payment schemes.

We all know that when this government came into power we had a $10 billion budget black hole bequeathed to us by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley). We all know that since the election Labor frontbenchers in just about every portfolio have been promising the discontented and rancorous pressure groups of our society that they will rain money on them. That is Labor's policy—to spend money on every single problem, to appease every lobby group, to try to bribe every interest group with yet more cash and to shove cash down the mouths of everyone who is unhappy or discontented in modern society.

The shadow minister for education has promised to abolish the various changes that this government has made to the higher education contribution scheme. That alone would cost at least half a billion dollars a year. Where is that money going to come from? The constant griping about alleged cuts to public education at the school level implies massive increased funding on top of the massive amounts that we propose to spend on schools. Where is that money coming from? Has the shadow Treasurer been included? Did anyone opposite prepare speeches with reference to the shadow Treasurer, or has the shadow Treasurer yet again been confined to the netherworld of relevance deprivation syndrome? The simple truth is that we just do not have the money to spend unless we get it from the pockets of ordinary Australians, and this is not a government which is going to buy off one group by penalising another group.

We obviously have problems in Australia at the moment, but one of the reasons why the spectre of One Nation is stalking the Australian political landscape is that there has been too much mindless headbanging in this parliament. Not enough credit has been given by either side to the sincerity and the decency of the opposite side. My great disappointment with the contributions of members opposite is that there has been a constant resort to the politics of fear.

Listening to members opposite, you would think that this government was a cross between Attila the Hun and Vlad the Impaler, when this government comprises decent, ordinary Australians—in many cases outstanding Australians—who are trying to do the right thing by the Australian people in difficult circumstances. We have had far too much of the politics of fear, yet listening to members opposite one would think that there is virtually no difference, in education policies at least, between the Labor Party and the One Nation Party.

We should not be frightened of the future. Australia is a great country. We are not Albania. We are not the kind of wasteland that members opposite constantly seem to suggest. Ministers of the Crown in this government are not a combination of Stalin and Pol Pot. This is a government which is doing the right thing by the Australian education system. It is doing the right thing by the parents of Australian children. It is doing the right thing by the youngsters of Australia. We are building a better future. We are building it on the strengths of our existing government and independent school systems.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Latham's amendment) stand part of the question.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Fahey) read a third time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: New facilities for the National Museum of Australia and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies.

The National Museum of Australia was established with bipartisan political support by the National Museum of Australia Act 1980 to research Australian history, develop and maintain a national collection of historical material, create exhibitions and programs which explore our heritage and history and make them accessible to more Australians. The museum will combine the best contemporary exhibition techniques, new media technologies and live performances and will offer a range of experiences to appeal to visitors of all kinds. It will include a high definition digital theatre and electronic linkages to make it a world-class museum and distance learning centre serving schools, state museums and other cultural venues nationally and internationally.

The institute, which was originally established in 1964, is the largest research centre of its kind for information about cultures and lifestyles of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. To support its research and other functional activities, the institute maintains collections of audiovisual material, books, journals and manuscripts which it holds in trust for indigenous Australians. Co-location of the museum and institute will allow both organisations to take their place among the other national institutions located in Canberra. In addition, the ACT government intends to establish an ACT Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Cultural Centre on the site, which will contribute to the creation of a unique cultural precinct in Canberra. Future use of the Yarramundi site is yet to be decided.

Subject to parliamentary approval, construction is scheduled to commence in October 1998 and the buildings are scheduled to be ready to open on 1 January 2001 as the Commonwealth's flagship for the centenary of Federation celebrations. The proposal was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works on 30 October 1997 and the committee tabled its report on 23 June 1998, recommending that the proposal should proceed. However, the committee has raised a number of issues, including some in relation to the competition process and the proposed contractual arrangements. The committee has also requested that it be provided with reports on progress with the project.

While a formal international architectural competition was not conducted, as this would have been much more expensive and would have required an additional 12 to 18 months to conduct, international firms were invited to compete. The conditions were also tailored to enable architectural practices of all sizes to compete. The competition was conducted and judged with the benefit of expert advice, including advice from architects recommended by the Royal Australian Institute of Architects who have since commended the conduct of the competition and the selection of the winning design team.

The purpose of the competition was not to select an architect on the basis of a fully completed and costed design, but rather to select a design team that would undertake that detailed design development. The selection included consideration of the concept designs provided by the short-listed teams. These concept designs were based on the detailed functional brief which was prepared by a specialist brief writer, including indicative budgets for the project. The development of the completed design from the original concept design is now proceeding as planned.

On the basis of expert advice, the government has concluded that the method of project alliancing is the most appropriate delivery strategy for this complex project and the one most likely to achieve the project objectives relating to time, cost and quality. A project alliance involves the creation of a single, integrated high performance team working to achieve common project objectives and pre-agreed commercial outcomes for all parties. The project alliance thus focuses all parties on achieving outstanding project results and not on protecting each party's contractual position. At the same time, there are appropriate protections for the government as client, including reverting to a more traditional contracting approach at any point if necessary.

Three separate buildings will be co-located on the site. They will comply with all appropriate planning requirements in industry and environmental standards. Internal planning of the museum will allow for relatively simple future expansion. The design allows for an expansion footprint of about 2,200 square metres, which could provide up to an extra 4,400 square metres of gross floor area over two levels.

The government has approved total funding of $151.9 million for the project, comprising $133 million for capital works and $18.9 million for one-off establishment costs. On the basis of professional advice, the government is confident that the project is capable of being delivered on time and within budget. As with any project, there will be appropriate monitoring and reporting on progress but, as requested, the government will in this instance also provide progress reports to the committee. I thank the committee for its support. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

debateinfo.title: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION (COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYMENT) REPEAL AND AMENDMENT (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Fahey, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

This bill amends various pieces of legislation as a consequence of amendments included in the Superannuation Legislation (Commonwealth Employment) Repeal and Amendment Bill 1998 included in a package of three bills currently before parliament. That package of bills will, among other things, make changes to the administrative arrangements for the Commonwealth's superannuation schemes by abolishing the office of Commissioner for Superannuation. Because the commissioner has statutory responsibility as chairman of the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Authority under the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973, consequential amendments to that act are required.

The Superannuation Legislation (Commonwealth Employment—Saving and Transitional Provisions) Bill 1998, included in this package of bills, also provides that the trustees of the Commonwealth's civilian schemes use the organisation known as Commonwealth Superannuation Administration, or ComSuper, for the provision of administration services for the schemes for a period of three years. This bill includes amendments to the Military and Superannuation Benefit Act 1991 which will require the trustees of the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme to use ComSuper for the provision of administration services for that scheme for the same period.

In addition, the package of bills will repeal the Superannuation (Productivity Benefit) Act 1988, which currently provides a minimum level of superannuation in certain circumstances in relation to the Governor-General and members of the scheme provided for by the Judges' Pensions Act 1968. This bill will ensure that the minimum level of superannuation continues to become payable in those circumstances after the repeal of the Productivity Benefit Act.

The bill also makes a minor amendment to the Commonwealth Funds Management Limited Act 1991, required as a result of the sale of Commonwealth Funds Management Limited in 1996 and not included in amending legislation at that time. This bill does not involve any additional budget outlays. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the amendments be agreed to.

The amendments that have been returned following debate on this bill in the other place and that have been approved by the Senate relate to some 20 government amendments. Most are of a technical nature. They correct editing errors that were made in the original bill. These amendments refer to such things as the removal of references to exhausted votes in House of Representatives elections. The amendments restore the 24-hour period after which pre-poll voting may commence as a consequence of introducing a 24-hour period between the close and declaration of nominations. They restore the Electoral Commissioner's non-discretion to extend the deadline for the receipt of postal votes received in the mail. They allow, during the period between the issue of the writ and the close of the rolls for a referendum, the removal of electors whose enrolment has been the subject of objection action.

The government has also moved amendments to tighten disclosure of donations provisions. This issue was brought to the government's attention by the AEC's report on funding and disclosure in the 1996 federal election. I would add that we have moved swiftly to amend the appropriate legislation because the government believes in the transparency of political donations. We believe that is desirable. Our amendments will ensure that our system is more accountable.

The amendments give the Australian Electoral Commission greater power to investigate organisations, trusts, clubs or any other entities which it suspects may be associated entities of a political party. Specifically, they enable an authorised officer to issue a notice to an organisation requiring the production of documents to assist in determining whether the organisation has a financial disclosure obligation as an associated entity.

The government amendments also replace the references to Queen's dominions with a reference to the Commonwealth of Nations. They provide that, where subdivisions are proclaimed, a provisional vote cast by an elector who has moved to a different subdivision without notifying the Australian Electoral Commission can still be included in the scrutiny, provided the elector is still living in the division. They allow the High Court, sitting as the Court of Disputed Returns, to remit the whole or part of a petition to the Federal Court. They require the Court of Disputed Returns to make its decision on a petition as quickly as is reasonable in the circumstances.

The government amendments generally met with the support of all parties in the Senate. I take this opportunity to thank the parties in the Senate for their cooperation as this bill will be of great benefit to the Australian Electoral Commission in the conduct of federal elections, whenever they may occur in the future. I commend the amendments to the House.

talk.start.para: —I indicate that the opposition does agree with these particular scheduled amendments that were made by the Senate to the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1998 . The amendments I particularly want to speak to are amendments Nos 14 and 20, because they are amendments that I really do commend the government for. These amendments mean that the franchise throughout Australia is now a uniform franchise.

speech.para: As a result of scrutineering that I was involved in in the Northern Territory shortly after the last election, it became obvious that in the Northern Territory, because of the joint roll arrangement, electors were being enrolled in subdivisions but some 1,594 electors who had moved within the division from one subdivision to another were not reinstated on the roll. In all other electorates apart from Kalgoorlie, where there were two subdivisions, subdivisions have been abolished. These particular amendments restore the position so that the Electoral Commission can enrol people for those districts and subdivisions but they will not lose their voting entitlement providing they move within a division. As I say, in the last election some 1,594 electors, a lot of whom were Aboriginals, were moving from one area to another in the Northern Territory.

I do commend the government on this. This was an area that was subject to a High Court challenge in the case of Snowdon v. Dondas, where the High Court, sitting as the Court of Disputed Returns, on 10 October 1996 unanimously rejected the petition. Whilst it saw that there was a problem in terms of a legal situation, it said there was no legal remedy and it was a matter for the parliament to remedy. I made a submission to the parliamentary committee and—in fairness to the parliamentary committee—there was a unanimous recommendation to fix the situation. The government's response was to unanimously support that recommendation of the parliamentary joint committee. Because there has been a number of electoral bills, the government—to its credit—moved this as a government amendment in the Senate. I do commend the government on this. I think it shows that you can receive cross-party support for amendments aimed at improving the Electoral Act.

The thing that came through in the Snowdon v. Dondas case was that, in terms of electoral matters, the court has made it very clear that it is not going to be an interventionist court in laying down principles per se and that the right to vote and the qualifications to vote through elections will be determined by the parliament. As a result of Snowdon's case and McGinty's case, the onus is on the parliament. This is one instance where the parliament has done the right thing, and I believe in giving credit where credit is due.

For me, it is particularly pleasing because it has meant that a campaign that I launched as a result of scrutinising in the Northern Territory has reached fruition and many more indigenous Australians in the Northern Territory will be able to vote and have their vote counted when the next election is called. The main thing is the uniformity of the franchise because, until these amendments are proclaimed, the current position, particularly in the Northern Territory, is that people miss out who, if they were living anywhere else, would not.

I felt it was important to intervene and give credit to the minister and the Australian Electoral Commission. I think we have one of the best electoral commissions in the world in the Australian Electoral Commission. They are professional. I think we have one of the best voting systems in the world. I agree with compulsory voting. I agree with the full distribution of preferences. It has meant that we have had a stable democracy. It has meant that you need a majority of the votes to get elected in any particular division. I repeat that we on this side support these amendments and I, in particular, support those subdivisional amendments enthusiastically. I commend the amendments to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.para: That the amendments be agreed to.

I will briefly explain that the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1997 was last before the House on Monday, when we dealt with requests for amendments sought by the Senate. At that time, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) outlined the history of this bill and I do not intend to go over that ground again today.

We are dealing with the amendments made to the bill by the Senate. The government accepts all these amendments, which can be broken into three groups. Amendment No. 1 is consequential to various refinements which we discussed on Monday, those being to the measure granting carer payment to carers of profoundly disabled children.

Amendments Nos 2 to 9 were government amendments that clarify the measure reforming the means testing of income streams. The original intention of this measure was always that retired Australians should have access to regular, dependable income so that in their later years they could be as secure as possible. These amendments ensure that, for income streams to qualify for concessional treatment, they must offer a regular, stable income.

Finally, amendments Nos 11 to 28 all relate to the seasonal worker preclusion period. Their effect is to allow seasonal workers to be tested on taxable income rather than on gross income, to protect seasonal workers who voluntarily do not claim benefits and to ensure that seasonal workers have reasonable notice that they may be subject to preclusion periods. I commend these amendments to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 25 June, on motion by Mr Miles:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1998 is a non-controversial bill which is supported by the opposition. It provides the untied Commonwealth financial assistance to the states and territories for 1998-99. Untied assistance, of course, is that which may be spent according to the states' own priorities.

speech.para: The bill authorises payments for the funding agreed to at the 1998 Premiers Conference of $17.1 billion for 1998-99. In doing so, the government has continued the Labor practice of indexing the pool of funds on a real per capita basis—that is, increasing both for inflation and for the increase in population. This is a fair funding formula, as demand for state services such as health, education, infrastructure, et cetera is often driven by both inflation and population.

It also authorises that the revenue from the safety net arrangements introduced to make up for the state revenue shortfall arising from last year's High Court decision in the Walter Hammond case, which invalidated state business franchise fees as being uncontroversial, is also authorised—that is, $6.5 billion for 1998-99.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) likes to pretend that he is a successful federalist. He pretends that the coalition is good at cooperative relations with the states. However, his record would have to be the worst of any government's in history. There have been three Premiers Conferences with John Howard and Peter Costello, and all of them have been disastrous—a quite unparalleled effort.

Many would remember the 1996 meeting. Just prior to the meeting, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) announced an enormous new tax burden on the states, around $1.3 billion per annum. This ambushing poisoned the water for the conference, and it was a farce. In the end the Treasurer had to back down on his tax proposal, except in respect of some cars, and instead he cut over $1.5 billion from the funds available to the states over three successive years, thereby cutting much needed services to Australian families. This was the meeting where the states put on the record what they really thought about the Treasurer, and in the end the Premiers refused to meet with the Treasurer, and the Prime Minister had to meet with them alone to finally salvage an outcome.

Last year we saw a complete collapse of the COAG process which has remained completely stalled through the whole of this wasted period of office, and finally this year we had an unprecedented result where the Premiers simply walked out and went home. Without question, this government has the worst record in Commonwealth-state relations of any government.

Indeed today, 1 July, is the first day of what ought to have been the start of a new five-year Medicare agreement. Due to this government's ongoing incompetence, we do not have an agreement between the governments of this country concerning the delivery of health care to their citizens—again, an unprecedented outcome which smacks of incompetence.

One can only wonder what the Prime Minister might have in store for the states next year if he were to win the upcoming election. How would he be able to continue or better a record like the one we have seen in the last two or three years? If we look into the crystal ball of federal-state financial relations, what we might expect to see, if this government is successful in being re-elected, is a Prime Minister explaining to the states that they will face a GST, a goods and services tax, on all of their purchases, without compensation. It would be like 1996 all over again, but it would mean a much larger blow to the finances of the states than that proposed in 1996.

Notwithstanding the fact that some of the states suggest they are on board the tax cart, this will mean in turn that the services provided by the states, such as schools, hospital, police and other community services, will all be squeezed still further. Labor's very good record of cooperative reform with the states can be seen now, as it contrasts so starkly with the pathetic performance of the current government.

We need to also remember that the GST will not only adversely affect the states but also detrimentally affect the third tier of government—local government. For example, KPMG has estimated that a GST at a rate of 12.5 per cent would increase the costs on local government by over $1 billion. This would mean that everyone would face an increase in their rates bill in the order of 20 per cent—that is, the government is planning to impose a tax upon a tax, which is, of course, what rates are. That also would be unprecedented in Australia.

We would also, in all probability, see a GST imposed on other state taxes and charges. Some examples include motor vehicle registration and third party insurance costs. These are examples of the necessities of life which are not subject to wholesale sales tax, and it is Labor's view that they should not be.

We have seen quite recently more and more groups coming out and expressing concern about the way in which a goods and services tax would operate. Just in the last week or two we have seen the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission, the commission of the Australian Catholic bishops, commenting on the Queensland election outcome:
"There is nothing the Government has produced or said to date which convinces the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission that a GST is a fair and equitable plank in tax reform."
Commenting on the lack of any detailed information from the Government, Mr O'Connor—
the spokesman for the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission—

said, "The so called `tax reform debate' is an indictment on economists, big business and the Federal Government who are fixated in their belief that a GST is the panacea for the complexity and disincentives in the current tax system. These groups are putting self interest ahead of the reality that regressive taxes, like a GST, have a negative impact on the financial position of struggling families and the poor."
Mr O'Connor went on to say:

"No amount of advertising will alter the simple realities: that a GST is a regressive and unfair tax; that struggling families will be hit the hardest; that the necessity to introduce a package of compensation to vulnerable families is an admission of the unfairness of a GST and goes against the concept of good citizenship because it will treat some Australians as second class citizens worthy of a hand out."
We also saw the Australian Catholic Health Care Association expressing some similar concerns as recently as 18 June. They said:
. . . media reports that the Howard Government is planning compensation handouts to ease opposition to a GST is a frank admission that the tax is unfair . . .

It is already well established that a GST is regressive and bad news for middle and low income families. Now it appears they will need to rely on compensation funding just to keep pace with everyone else, let alone get ahead.
They went on to point out:
Compensation packages are unreliable, have been proven to not work and usually end up being dismantled over time—
and that is quite correct—
Why are these packages going to be any different?
The Catholic Health Care Association went on to say:
Let's not forget, a GST means removing taxes from big business and placing them on household budgets.

The Business Council of Australia spokesman, Stan Wallis, gave the game away when he said that we need to reduce the taxation levels on big business. That can only mean that household budgets would be subject to higher taxation levels. The Catholic Health Care Association continue:

To use a `handout mentality' to address genuine problems for struggling families is demeaning. The precarious nature of their circumstances deserves to be fully understood by Government and proponents of the GST.
They concluded by pointing out that, irrespective of the advertising campaign, the facts are as follows:
families need to purchase different goods and services at different times to meet essential needs—a GST on basic food, health, aged care housing and education will hurt many—
and I would add to this necessities like electricity, gas, water, child care and many expenses in the education area—

families with members who are chronically ill or frail and dependent will be taxed the same as healthy young individuals or prosperous high income Australians—a GST on health, medical, nursing home expenses, hospice, community aged care or nursing care will hurt many . . .
The Catholic Health Care Association conclude:

If tax reform is to be successful, let's not approach sections of the community in a patronising and demeaning fashion. If it is to be genuinely fair, let's prove that those most in need of help actually benefit in real sustainable terms.

The impact of a GST would be unfair. It would reduce taxation on luxury items and assist those who are already well off at the expense of battlers, at the expense of those who are less well off. In particular, it would adversely affect Australians who are retired and for whom it is too late to go back into the work force and earn new money at what might turn out to be lower rates of income tax. So it diminishes the savings of retired people and is regressive for that reason.

It is also an unnecessary impost on small business and would turn many small businesses in this country into unpaid tax collectors. At present, the 1.3 million small businesses that are not liable to pay GST would become unpaid tax collectors for this government.

Let me also add that it is not the answer in terms of the black economy either. It tends to encourage the avoidance of transactions and to encourage people not to report transactions, so that they can avoid the GST as well as income tax. For those reasons and many others, we will be opposing a GST at the next election. As I indicated at the outset, we are supportive of this bill and will not be opposing it.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

He will also be involved in ministerial meetings with the French government. The Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, who has been delayed just a few moments returning from Sydney, will answer questions on his behalf. The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade, Mr Tim Fischer, has just returned from Gippsland, where he has been assessing the flood situation.

subdebateinfo.title: One Nation Party: National Party Preferences

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Deputy Prime Minister. Is the Deputy Prime Minister aware of the view of his Western Australian counterpart, Deputy Premier Hendy Cowan, that One Nation should be placed last on National Party how-to-vote cards? Is he also aware of Mr Cowan's warning that the National Party should not compromise itself on this issue `for the sake of political expediency'? Deputy Prime Minister, will you show some leadership and wield your authority to ensure that One Nation is put last by the Nationals across this country?
—I am in constant contact with Hendy Cowan. I met with him twice in the last fortnight—once in Melbourne, once in Darwin—and had further talks with him and noted his further comments.
—Are you getting on with him?

—I am getting on with the important tasks of government—the federal government's interface with the Victorian state government on the Gippsland flood recovery arrangements, helping people through a very difficult situation where there has been over 400 to 500 millimetres of rain deluging the area and doing a lot of damage. In regional Australia, we are getting on with the task of helping to rebuild with the $250 million regional telecommunications infrastructure fund, getting jobs and record export figures and helping to further facilitate those export figures. You can try as many angles as you like, but I will answer when I have completed my consultations in my own electorate of Farrer, and that will be at a time further down the track. You have no right to question my approach to standing up to the Hanson agenda. I have been there all along.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, the Leader of the Opposition this morning released a policy on industrial relations. What would be the impact of this policy if it were ever to be implemented?
—I thank the member for Dunkley.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The question clearly asked for an opinion. The minister has not been asked to give an account of his government's policies.
—He asked, actually, about the effect of industrial relations policies on the whole industrial scene, and that part of the question is certainly in order.

—The Leader of the Opposition interjects about small business. In small business in the area of Frankston, in the member's seat, the fact is that this policy, if ever implemented, would be a disaster for jobs. It is anti-small business.

answer.para: Mr Beazley interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The Leader of the Opposition talks about job security. This policy, which the Labor Party announced this morning, is actually being acted out by the shoppies union in Victoria. It has got a log of claims against 30,000-odd businesses, which would cost 20,000 jobs in Victoria alone. It is claiming triple time for weekend work, and that is endorsed by the Labor Party. Why is it endorsed by the Labor Party? You only have to look at the donations made by the shoppies union to the Labor Party in the last few years to know. In 1996-97, you got $571,000 from the shoppies union. In 1995-96, you got $879,000 from the shoppies union.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. This would be relevant if it had been a question about whether or not his policies on industrial relations were dominated by having got a concessional price for a penthouse.
—The Leader of the Opposition is not now making a point of order.
—No, but I am making a relevant point.
—He can raise one specifically, but not argue the point.

—The personal comments of the Leader of the Opposition reveal how sensitive he is. You have been bought off by the shoppies union, and the people who will pay for this are the thousands of people in small business who will lose their jobs as a result. Instead of the personal remarks, why don't you have the guts to stand up and defend your policy? This policy in action, as we are seeing already in Victoria, will add 25 per cent to the cost of small business, and that will mean a lot of people will lose their jobs. This is the Labor Party's policy in action. He talks about Labor's previous policy, but the fact is that, though you are today attacking award simplification, you used to be in favour of it.

answer.para: What incredible hypocrisy. Your only objection to the fact that we have done it is that you were unable to do so. Why were you unable to do so? You have been bought off by the trade unions as usual—in dollars and cents—against the interests of the people who you claim to represent. Not only will they undo award simplification, which is a tremendous benefit to workers; they will also repeal the secondary boycott provisions of the Trade Practices Act which have given this country the lowest level of disputes since 1940. You people, before the last election, said if the coalition was elected there would be an increase in disputes. Since we have been in, we have a record low level of industrial disputes. Labor's policy means not less disputes but more industrial disputes. What will be the consequences of that? More job losses in the Australian community.

It is about time the Leader of the Opposition stood up to these trade union bosses, stood up for small business and stood up for the people who need a job. What a fascinating contrast there is between the Australian Labor Party and the Labour Party in the UK. In the UK, Tony Blair came in and he said, `We can't go back to the policies when Labour was last in office. We need a new approach,' and he abandoned the links with the trade union movement. He actually went to a trade union congress and told them that the old days of union bosses dictating policy had to be over. In conclusion, what an irony it is that Mr Beazley's biography is now being written and the foreword is to be signed off by Tony Blair, a leader who has what it takes to deal with the union movement—instead of the subservient policy which you have today released.

talk.start.para: —I remind ministers that they should direct their replies through the chair and not across the table.
—Mr Speaker—
—The Leader of the Opposition need not intrude into the debate. He will ask a question and not do otherwise.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware of the view of Mr Michael Kroger that he would prefer a Labor government to One Nation? Is the Prime Minister aware that Mr Kroger has said that this is the view of Mr Kennett and the Treasurer and the Victorian Liberals generally? In the light of this, will the Prime Minister categorically rule out ever forming a government with the political support of One Nation?

—I am not aware of those views that have been attributed to Michael Kroger. As I have found in the past, the views attributed to Australian citizens by those who sit opposite are frequently inaccurate. Our position is very clear: the party I lead will never form a government with any party other than the National Party of Australia.
—Mr Speaker, I seek leave to table the transcript of Mr Kroger's comments last night.
—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House what impact recent reforms to the Australian financial system will have for ordinary Australians and for businesses?

—I thank the honourable member for Wannon for his question, and I acknowledge the work that he has done as chairman of the parliamentary committee in this area. Today, 1 July, Australia has a new system for financial regulation. It is probably the biggest overhaul of Australia's financial regulation system ever. Today two new bodies commenced: the Australian Prudential Regulatory Authority—APRA—which, for the first time, will regulate prudential requirements across all deposit taking institutions, including banks and superannuation authorities including, as the states join the system, state based institutions. What that means is that banks will no longer have their own specific regulator. There will be a general regulator which will allow institutions the same kind of regulatory supervision that previously was available only for banks.

answer.para: Today, 1 July, a new corporate and consumer regulator is instituted—the Australian Securities and Investment Commission—which completes the twin peaks doctrine of prudential regulation and consumer regulation. This is the body which will be a one-stop shop for consumers in relation to financial products and a one-stop shop for business in relation to corporate and consumer regulation. I had the privilege of launching both APRA and ASIC in Sydney this morning.

In addition to this, the government's reforms include the passing of a company law review bill in relation to meetings and company procedures, the institution of real time gross settlement in the payments system for the Reserve Bank and legislation which has recently been passed to allow credit unions and building societies to issue their own cheques. This is a great improvement, particularly for rural and regional Australia which can have access to credit unions that can now, for the first time in Australian history, issue their own cheques and compete equally in relation to the banks.

But it does not stop there. The government's reforms include the corporate law economic reform program, which is going to revolutionise directors' duties, takeovers and fundraising and make it easier for small business to raise funds. That bill will be coming into the parliament next week. Some of the benefits that arise from this state-of-the-art leading edge financial regulation include the fact that we are now getting increased and heightened competition in the financial sector. One of the advantages of increased competition in the financial sector is the fact that, since the government has encouraged competition in the financial sector, the margin on home loans by banks and other financial institutions has fallen two per cent. That is a two per cent benefit for Australian home buyers as a result of competition. I know the Labor Party is opposed to competition and I know it is engaged now in a direct race with Ms Hanson to try to steal backward looking economic agendas. One of the great benefits of competition in the financial sector is that we have got official interest rates down from 10½ per cent as they were under Labor to 6½ per cent with a two per cent cut as a result of extra competition on mortgages. That means for the average family—since this government was elected—a saving of over $3,000 a year on the standard variable home mortgage.

I say this to the Labor Party opposite: we know that their backward looking economic policies will, as sure as night follows day, lead to higher interest rates. The Labor Party is the party that gave Australia home mort gage interest rates of 17 per cent. That was the Labor policy on home mortgage interest rates. On this side of the House, we believe in giving young home buyers a go, giving them opportunity, giving them low interest rates and giving them money back in their pockets.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, are you aware that the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Union of Australia yesterday announced plans to prosecute major clothing companies in Australia, alleging the companies have breached award conditions for Australia's most vulnerable and disadvantaged workers—namely, outworkers? Are you aware that the award conditions which have allegedly been breached—which require companies to register the outworkers they are employing—are the very same award conditions which are subject to award stripping? How can you support stripping away from awards provisions which give outworkers vital protection against exploitation?
—Once again, I will investigate the assertions that have been made.
—It's your law.

—Seven out of ten, you get the facts wrong—and that is a pretty good reason to investigate. While I am answering that question, can I remind the House that the government very strongly supports the attempts made by different sections of the community to prevent the exploitation and unfair treatment of outworkers within the Australian community. I would also remind the member for Canberra that concern about the treatment of outworkers did not commence on 2 March 1996. I can remember the first occasion I discussed this matter at length was with an officer of the relevant union. That person indicated to me that it was an issue that had been around and of concern to the union and many other people under the governments of both sides of politics in Australia. Any attempt by the member for Canberra to try and persuade the Australian public that, after them being in power for 13 years and having done nothing to stop the problem, somehow or other the problem—

—I raise a point of order on the question of relevance, Mr Speaker. My question was not about the programs which the government cancelled when they came in to deal with outworkers; it was about the award.
—The member knows he asked a long question, and the Prime Minister has every right to respond in kind.

—The member for Canberra asked me a question about the exploitation of outworkers. What I am saying to the member for Canberra is that for 13 years of Labor government outworkers were exploited. For 13 years you had an opportunity to do something about it; for 13 years you allowed it to go on. You have no moral authority to thump the table and now say the outrage started on 2 March. You did nothing about it for 13 years and you have no credentials to lecture us on this or, indeed, any other matter.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. From today, all 18- to 24-year-olds who have been unemployed for six months or more must participate in an additional approved activity in order to receive their full unemployment benefits. Why were these new requirements introduced and how will they help get young people into jobs?

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Swan for his question. Today the government puts into place two of the key elements in its comprehensive strategy to address the problem of entrenched youth unemployment. One of these is the youth allowance and the second is the new arrangements for young people on the dole. From today every young person 18 to 24 years of age who passes six months on unemployment benefit will need to do an additional activity in order to continue receiving the unemployment allowance. The base basic principle underlying this measure is, of course, the principle of mutual obligation. The community recognises a strong obligation to young people and the need to support young people on the dole. In return, the community believes it is fair that young people should do something to increase their own employment prospects and put something back into the community.

answer.para: Under the policy which commences today, young people will have the choice of activity to meet their mutual obligation requirements. They will be able to undertake voluntary activity within the community; they will be able to undertake part-time work. The government is investing some $465 million over the next four years to provide other avenues for constructive job experience. One of those is work for the dole; the other one is important literacy and numeracy training for those young people who have come out of the school system without those skills. If young people do not satisfy these requirements, their dole could be reduced. It is an obligation, but it is also an opportunity. It is an opportunity for young people to take charge of their own future and to make a choice to do something that will actually help their employment prospects.

What a fundamental change this is from the dole system that Labor favours. Labor favoured a dole system which encouraged young people to go on the dole. Labor's message to young people was that the dole was an alternative lifestyle; the dole was there as an alternative to work and to gaining useful work experience. Labor's message was it was okay to be on the dole. That is not our message. Under the Leader of the Opposition youth unemployment reached 34 per cent—135,000 unemployed teenagers. The Labor Party betrayed a generation of young people. It is up to this government to take hold of the fundamental issues which underlie youth unemployment—the lack of literacy and numeracy skills and the lack of proper opportunities for the 70 per cent who do not go on to university. Today we are putting into place the policies that will completely change the incentive on the dole for young people. Instead of the negative message from the Labor Party, we are putting in place a positive message that gives young people the chance to do something to improve their employment prospects in the future.

subdebateinfo.title: Industrial Relations: Red Cross Blood Donations

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that the Red Cross says it faces a depletion in its stocks of blood because of changes to awards that will deny employees leave during working hours to donate blood? Does the Prime Minister share this concern of Red Cross? If so, how can you support stripping away from awards a worker's right to one hour's leave to donate blood?

—This is a patently absurd question and it shows that the Labor Party has completely abandoned the many things which they themselves thought were a good idea when they were in office. I take you back—and it is not so long ago—to October 1993. The then minister, who is now your colleague sitting next to you—

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order which goes to relevance: this was a specific question related to a specific award provision related to time off for the donation of blood, which has now been stripped away from the award and the Red Cross has expressed concern about this.
—The Leader of the Opposition will not argue the case.
—That is what he should be answering.
—The minister is responding to a question with respect to an analysis of award conditions. The question related to the Red Cross and award conditions.

—This question is based on the implementation of a policy known as award simplification, which the Labor Party itself supported. The member for Kingsford-Smith, when he was the minister, said this in October 1993:

answer.para: This legislation marks the culmination of the government's break with the past . . .
And he went on to say it was specifically in respect of—

talk.start.para: —By negotiation.
—Yes, I will come to that point. You specifically said:

answer.para: The amendments are also directed at making awards more streamlined and modern, with detailed prescription about the organisation of work increasingly being a matter for agreements.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker—
—Just to finish off before the irrelevant interjections—
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: the question went straight to the Red Cross's depletion of blood supplies.
—It's a frivolous point of order.
—It is not a frivolous point of order; it is a relevant point of order. You can get away with murder in this place.
—The Leader of the Opposition will complete his point of order and not start arguing across the table.
—The point of order goes to relevance. It was a very tight, brief question related to one matter. It did not invite a generalised discussion of awards or past attitudes to them.
—The Leader of the Opposition is fully aware that the question was predicated on the change in the award conditions, and the minister is specifically referring to award conditions.

—Just to conclude—to perhaps explain the system as it was introduced by Labor to the Leader of the Opposition—the fact of the matter is that you boasted about the number of people who had agreements, in other words, whose agreements were subject to the no disadvantage test to displace the operation of the underlying award.
—Mr Speaker—
—This really is a frivolous and irrelevant point of order.
—The Leader of the Opposition has raised the point of order and, unless he has another one, I have ruled on it: the minister is in order.
—The opening remarks of the question, Mr Speaker, were: are you aware that the Red Cross says it faces a depletion in its stocks of blood because of changes to awards?

—The Leader of the Opposition has raised the point of order on relevance. As long as the minister is responding specifically with respect to the changes in award conditions affecting the specifics, he is in order. He is presently in order. I invite the minister to conclude his reply.
