—To conclude, the point I make is that in this particular respect we are doing exactly the thing that you yourself said was a good idea. And it is absolutely incredible hypocrisy for you to even put up such a question.
—I call the honourable member for La Trobe.
—Last question, Bob!
—My question without notice is to the Treasurer. And don't you worry about it being my last question. Don't you worry about my being back. The member for La Trobe will be back. You can count on it.
—The member will direct his question and not respond to interjections.
—The members of the opposition will restrain their enthusiasm and allow the member for La Trobe to direct his question.

—Anyhow, back to the Treasurer. Treasurer, can you please advise the House of the significance of the May retail trade figures? Does the survey support the budget forecast of 3.75 per cent growth for 1997-98?

—I thank the honourable member for La Trobe for his question and I say, like Douglas MacArthur, `He will return.' The seasonally adjusted retail sales rose by 0.5 per cent in May after rising 0.2 per cent in April. The rise was above market expectations and suggests continuing growth in retail trade in Australia. The outcome is consistent with budget forecasts and reflects largely strong growth in food retailing, clothing and soft goods retailing, and hospitality and services.

answer.para: The trend estimate in relation to retail trade increased in May—its 20th consecutive monthly increase—and that indicates continuing growth in retailing on a sustained basis. Housing approvals, which were also released today, point to healthy continuing economic activity. Although there was a 6.8 per cent fall in May, this followed a 12.1 per cent increase over the previous two months and the trend remains positive. Approvals have risen 8.1 per cent over the year to May. As I said at the time of the release of the March quarter national accounts, which showed exceptionally strong growth in the Australian economy of 4.9 per cent, we were not predicting 4.9 per cent over the course of the year until June 1998 and our budget forecast was 3¾, which would be consistent with the next quarter coming off the record of the March quarter.

These figures suggest that retailing is maintaining domestic strength, led principally of course by the low interest rates, which have given savings to average Australians and have come off a low inflation base, and the extent of this government's fiscal rectification of Labor's $10 billion deficit.

I make the point, as I have on a number of occasions to this House, that, if this government had not turned around Labor's $10 billion deficit, if we had not got the Australian budget back into the black and if we had not run a proper fiscal policy, we would not have been able to keep inflation low and keep interest rates down for home buyers. Nothing could affect home buyers and small businesses more than Labor's plan to run Australia back into the red and Labor's plan to get Australia back into deficit with unfunded promises and with unfunded tax policies.

It is important at a time like this that Australia continues to rectify its budget position, continues to run down and repay Labor debt, and gets the Australian accounts back into a position where we can sustain a low interest rate regime with good spending opportunities, good housing opportunities and good home buying opportunities for young Australians.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel. Minister, in light of the review `Restructuring the Army', which recommended greater reliance be placed on reserve forces, why did you allow the Workplace Relations Act to strip hundreds of awards of their Defence Force training leave provisions, which are needed to enable reservists to participate in ADF training activities? Are you aware that the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has already rejected an approach to have such leave identified as an award provision in all federal industrial awards? Minister, why has your government asked reservists to spend more time in military training at the same time as it has taken away their award leave provisions that they need in order to do the military training?

—Thank you for the question. It is timely that there is a question today regarding the reserves, because today I have literally just come from Sydney where 10,000 reservists and former members of the CMF and reserve are marching, with a great deal of pride, to honour the 50th anniversary of establishment of the reserves. Today, in case you did not know, is Reserve Forces Day. I will be in Brisbane on Sunday when reservists will also march there. The important thing about the reserves is that, yes, there is indeed a reliance on reservists forming an important part of the ADF. There is an important emphasis put by this government on liaising with employers in order that those employers can see the benefit that having a reservist in their employ gives to them.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The question was not about reserve day or the anniversary of the formation of the reserves; it was about the government decision to strip leave for reserves out of awards. The minister has not even started to address that point.

—The member is expressing an opinion, but the minister is entirely within standing orders in responding to any matter pertaining to the reserves and their terms of service. There is no requirement as long as it is relevant to the question, and the member knows that.

—I think the rest of the people in this chamber and the people who watch are getting sick to death of the carping that goes on from the likes of you. The fact of the matter is that the way you treated the defence of this nation was a disgrace. What you left behind and the mess we had to clean up—
—The minister will respond to the question.
—Mr Speaker—
—The minister will respond to the question.
—I said yesterday that the Leader of the Opposition forgets his place often, and he is doing it again today.
—The minister will ignore interventions and respond to the question.

—Very simply, this government is committed to seeing reserves having a very important role to play with the ADF. The question of leave and the question of the value of reservists to employers, which we are promoting, is a question to be negotiated between employers and their employees. Those I saw marching with a great deal of pride today show that this system is working very well. Today, Reserve Forces Day, is a time when we can all celebrate the fact that there are many Australians who give of their time, who give of their energy, to ensure that we can have people who can defend this country.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Can the minister inform the House of the notable initiatives of this government which are coming into force today and in the near future in the social security area? Can the minister contrast this with the actions of the previous Labor government?
—I point out that the last part of the question is not technically in order because the minister is not responsible for the policies of the previous government.
—I accept your injunction, Mr Speaker. In fact, I was a severe critic of those policies and would accept no responsibility for them.

answer.para: Mr Beazley interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I was shadow minister for social security, as you know. Your colleagues have had some things to say about that from time to time. We have been about introducing a fairer and simpler social security system, one which is better targeted and more consistent and which has significant and improved compliance associated with it. You have already heard from my colleague the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs about the implications of the youth allowance, which comes into operation today. I will not elaborate on that save to say that, of the 560,000 young people affected by it, 153,750 will receive more money and 361,200 will be on the same benefits.
—How many will lose?

—A very insignificant number by comparison. Overall, Australia benefits significantly by having in place a system which encourages people to upgrade their skills to be able to enter effectively into the work force instead of being encouraged to remain on benefits, as occurred under your government. But I am trying to obey your injunction, Mr Speaker, not to make those comparisons.

answer.para: We also introduced from today the deferred pension bonus plan. That is a very important new initiative. It is one that I took some personal responsibility for encouraging my parties to adopt and is one that ensures that older Australians who choose to work longer will be significantly better off. It gives them a choice, it is voluntary, but it offers them a far more secure retirement. It means that the community as a whole can be better off. Taxpayers will be better off. What it means is that women after age 61 and men after age 65, if they continue to work, will be able to receive a bonus, and if they remain in the work force for five years they will be entitled to a full pension as well as a bonus of $21,250. In the case of a couple, that could be as high as $35,450. It is tax free. It is a very substantial benefit which commences from today, and it is one that I think indicates clearly that we are about addressing issues of ageism, where previously people who had very significant skills and were able to continue in the work force were literally forced out.

This is a day when families who have children with disabilities will be considerably better off as well. We have a situation where the domiciliary nursing care benefit will rise by 29 per cent to $75.10 per fortnight. We have a situation where the carer payments will now allow carers to undertake longer absences to study, train and work without losing their benefits. We have a situation where those families with profoundly disabled children will now be able to qualify for a carer payment. We have the provision of influenza injections for pensioners, which is an important related initiative. We have a situation where the families who do not qualify for the child disability allowance but have a child with a less severe disability or a chronic medical condition may be eligible for a health care card to help with the cost of medication and other expenses. That is on top of the very significant record we have in the social security area in relation to the $1 billion family tax initiative, the parenting changes that were introduced from 20 March 1998, the jobs, education and training program, which was extended, and the families that will no longer lose family allowance when their child goes overseas. I could go on and on, but my colleagues would not encourage me to do that.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, what do you say to the Newcastle family which has just been told that their 18-year-old daughter will lose all of her unemployment benefit, her health care card and her public transport concessions due to the introduction of the youth allowance today? How do you explain to this family, where one parent has a chronic illness and the other is earning an ordinary wage, that they have to find an extra $87 a week to support their daughter? How do you explain to their daughter that she now has to pay an extra $39 for her asthma inhaler and full fare on the bus, not to mention the fees that job seekers who are not on social security now will have to pay to get help finding work?
—This is all hypothetical and I don't—

—Just restrain yourselves. The barb of the question, however, is in order. I invite the minister to respond to the consequences of changes that affect a particular individual in the manner identified.
—Mr Speaker—

—Mr Speaker, you ruled out a part of this question as hypothetical. The point of order is that, as I understand it, the example has already been read into Hansard with the appropriate details by the member for the area. There is nothing hypothetical about the example.

—I have asked the Prime Minister to respond to the question, although I still doubt the degree to which facts that are contended are necessarily realistic. The Prime Minister will respond to the question.
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I am happy to show you the correspondence privately, because names are involved, to confirm. It is not hypothetical.

—The honourable member knows there are a set of contentions which may or may not be accurate. I am suggesting that the Prime Minister respond to the substance of the question. I call the Prime Minister to do so.
—I will analyse the details of the case that has been put to me by the member for Jagajaga, as I do with all such cases, and if there is anything I can specifically say about it, I will.

answer.para: I take the opportunity afforded by the honourable member's question to say a few things about the youth allowance. I inform the House that, of the 560,000 young people covered by the youth allowance, payments for 361,200 will remain unchanged, and that is 64 per cent; payments for 153,750 will increase—I repeat: payment for 153,750 will rise—and that is 27½ per cent; and payment for 45,000 will reduce or cut out entirely, which is eight per cent.

I remind the House of the philosophy behind the youth allowance. The philosophy is about altering the incentive so that people will choose work and training rather than the dole. We had a very interesting illustration today—and I want every member of the House and those present in the gallery to listen to this very careful reflection by the member for Batman which reveals the philosophy of the Australian Labor Party towards the dole. This is what he had to say in answer to a searching question from Gareth McCray on radio station 2KY. I ask all members to listen very carefully to this. He said:
. . . and I say, you know, they—
meaning those receiving the unemployment benefits—

are entitled to see their mates now and then and it is not a question of trying to keep them at home in front of the TV, you actually want them to be out there mixing with people and being socially oriented so an employer wants to employ them.

In other words, the philosophy of the dole is that you provide them with an alternative lifestyle of living on the dole. That is what you are on about. You are on about providing people with an alternative lifestyle of living on the dole, whereas the purpose of our youth allowance is to provide an additional expenditure of $212 million. The youth allowance does not involve saving expenditure. Those who sit opposite would have you believe that the youth allowance is about cutting expenditure. The youth allowance is not about cutting expenditure; the youth allowance is about altering the attitude to the dole in the Australian community.

The youth allowance is about saying to young people, `We want you to choose staying at school, going into a job or going into training instead of going onto the dole.' Under the policies of the Labor Party, going on the dole and staying on the dole was a real live option that they actually encouraged, whereas under the philosophy of my party the purpose of the youth allowance is to do the exact opposite. I reject the claims made by those who sit opposite. The youth allowance is about altering those incentives. The youth allowance is about encouraging young people to stay at school, to train or to seek a job in preference to going on the dole.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Can the minister inform the House how today's abolition of Labor's avgas tax will benefit regional and remote Australia?

—I thank the honourable member for Wakefield for his question. I am sure that there are a lot of aviation operators and consumers in his area who are going to benefit from today's announcement by our government—that is, that the unfair avgas tax has been abolished from today, 1 July. This is the first instalment of our government's commitment to taxation reform in Australia. This was an unfair tax—a tax which levied some $17 million at a rate of about 13c a litre. The people who will benefit the most from the abolition of this tax are the people in the bush, the general aviation operators in rural and remote Australia.
—Their landing charges are going up.

—They have been paying the tax on avgas, but rarely, if ever, using Airservices Australia's services that this tax was going to pay for. That is what the member for Melbourne is interjecting about. It is important to note that the people paying this tax were not necessarily using the services it was going to pay for. So we have abolished this tax and we are going to see a much fairer regime in its place. This means real savings for farmers in the electorate of the member for Wakefield. Abolishing the avgas tax will keep down the cost of using aircraft to spread fertilisers, spray crops and muster stock. It will mean savings of up to $10,000 per plane per year to rural and remote operators of air services. For every GA operator, it is 13c per litre off their annual avgas bill forever. It has been abolished and people should recognise this.

answer.para: This decision has been welcomed by industry. I received a fax—and the Labor Party are good at quoting local constituents—interest ingly, from a company in the electorate of the member for Wakefield. It is from Loxton Engineering Works, which operates light aircraft and sells produce into regional South Australia. The fax said:
Minister, we recognise and applaud your work in eliminating the unfair Airservices avgas levy.
We operate a light aircraft in our agricultural manufacturing and sales business over much of rural Australia.
The fuel levy in the past has forced us to pay for services we did not use.
After 1 July 1998 we can select and pay only for the services we require.
Our appreciation to you and the Coalition Government.

That fax from Loxton Engineering Works in the Riverland is a sign of the understanding in rural and remote Australia of the commitment of the Howard-Fischer government to taxation reform that provides fairness to rural and remote Australia.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Deputy Prime Minister. Deputy Prime Minister, you gave as one reason why you cannot do anything about Canadian pork imports the fact that we have an 8:1 trade surplus in relation to Canada, when in fact we have a $100 million trade deficit. Under these circumstances, don't you think it is unlikely that Canada would curtail its purchase of Australian sugar when it is the best, cleanest and cheapest sugar they can get in the world? Don't you think it is most unlikely that, under those circumstances, they would act against it?

—I thank the member for Kalgoorlie for his question. He raises the difficulties being faced by the pork industry—and I might add the citrus industry. I say at the outset that the government recognises that there is no such thing as a level playing field and we deal within that parameter to help industry. In fact, taxpayers of Australia have given a $28 million leg-up for both the pork and the citrus industries by giving them help where it is needed, particularly in facilitating their longer term export strategy. The problem is the short-term, and I accept that. What have we done there? We have announced a safe guards measure under article 19, which was not activated by our predecessors but which is being activated on a generic basis with the first reference being specific to the pork industry, and the Treasurer has now signed the reference to allow that to go ahead.

answer.para: To come to the particularity of the question, it is a fact that overall trade is in balance between Australia and Canada, but on agricultural goods we enjoy a surplus with Canada of about 8:1. With regard to the world, I point out that Australian farmers are so efficient that they produce five times more than we can consume in Australia, so the economic keys of hope for our farmers are represented by viably exporting to the world the other four-fifths. The House might like to know the pig meat exports, both wild and farm, from July 1997 to February 1998 country by country—I just happen to have this with me. Some $18 million worth of pork is being exported to Japan. I was at a piggery near Corowa last week seeing containers being loaded with high quality Australian brand-marked pork going to Japan. That is an expanding trade, which I welcome. We export to China, Korea and New Zealand as well. I admire and recognise the efforts by our pork industry to boost their exports. They recognise they need to do more and they need the chance to do so more. Exports to New Zealand were $4 million. Exports to Holland in Europe were $2.4 million. Exports even to the Russian federation were $2.7 million, as that economy comes back into line. Exports to France and Germany totalled over $7 million.

My colleague John Anderson, the Prime Minister, John Howard, and I recognise fully that the pork and citrus industries are in a very difficult part of their cycle. We have no magic wands and we have no false solutions for them, but we do have specific targeted help to boost their export efforts, including from the Queensland pork industry, to the world.

Finally, it is the sugar industry itself which has voiced concern about what Canada may or may not do. I do not make any specific comment on that, other than to say that at this stage it is in essence hypothetical. We are going about this in a workman-like way so that the action that may or may not be taken based on the commission inquiry will be unchallengeable by Canada or anybody else.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. I refer the minister to suggestions by some parties that Australia adopt a zero net immigration policy. Can the minister advise the House on the implications for Australia of such a policy being adopted?

—I thank the honourable member for Kooyong for his question on this matter. His undoubted interest and expertise in this area is well known. I welcome the opportunity to have something to say about the nature and scope of the immigration program and the views that we can move to a situation which is loosely described as `net zero migration'. The first point I would make is that the immigration program we have today is about half the size that it was 10 years ago. It has been very significantly reduced. At the moment there are 68,000 in the immigration program, with 12,000 refugee places. It is a rebalanced program; one which is highly skilled. It is a program that has been—if I can coin the phrase—`de-shammed'. What happened before under our predecessors, particularly in the family reunion area, was that we had considerable scope for abuse which allowed many people to enter Australia who were not in bona fide relationships.

answer.para: Today we have a very tightly administered family reunion program. It is a program in which 70 per cent have an English language capacity before they arrive in Australia and the balance have an opportunity to obtain it under our adult migrant English training programs which are in place. Those programs are in place to meet the needs of those people who require them.
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I do not wish to invoke the Speaker's injunction, but let me make it very clear that we provided additional support for training in the adult migrant education program—
—Only in the forward estimates.

—Yes, additional support in the forward estimates. We are running forward an additional $4 million for this year, last year and another two years forward. That is to deal specifically with those who have had difficulty in obtaining entry to those programs because they have come as refugees and are not necessarily able to enter into structured education programs.

answer.para: The point I want to make is that we have significantly addressed the abuse that was in the program. We have significantly addressed the balancing of that program. Those who talk about an alternative of net zero migration need to understand that they are talking about an immigration program of 30,000 people. How do you get to a program of 30,000 people? We heard today that one way you do it—because you do not want to say that you will not welcome refugees—is that you say, `We will provide temporary entry. Wait until you want to go back. But, if your children are born in Australia, they will be Australian.' I do not know how it can be characterised as temporary entry.

talk.start.para: —That's not so.

—I was not sure who to believe, Graeme, in relation to that. I heard the honourable member for Oxley make one comment and I heard an alleged spokesman say something else. I suppose if I need an adviser sitting beside me to answer the questions, the adviser ought to be sitting in the chair. But the fact is that the adviser put one view and the member for Oxley put another. I take it that the member for Oxley has a view, and that is that refugee children ought to be Australian. That is the comment that was put. But the fact is that what she is saying is, `We won't count refugees as part of the program.' That is how we can get it down to 30,000.

answer.para: What does she say about the balance? She says 60 per cent will be `close family reunion'. That means 20,000. I have to tell you that `close family reunion'—if you include a wife, a de facto partner or a fiance—numbers 24,000 under the program that we have put down for this year. That is demand driven. If you include their dependent children you have got another 2,000. So there are at least 4,000 people in close family relationships without any of the others such as last remaining relatives, special need relatives and orphaned children—there are a range of them—who would not be able to obtain entry to Australia. She says in relation to the balance that there would be 20 per cent for business migration and 20 per cent for skilled migration. What she is saying in effect is that instead of a skilled migration program of 30,000 which is highly beneficial to Australia, she would have a program of 10,000. What she would effectively be doing is what Mr Campbell once described to me as the `deskilling of Australia'. Something of the order of 30,000 young Australians, highly trained young Australians, leave Australia each year. What she would say in relation to the immigration program is that we should make sure that, essentially, unskilled people dominate it, and that skilled people who are able to obtain work, who are able to generate additional economic activity and who would create jobs for Australians are not able to come.

talk.start.para: —I suggest the minister draw his answer to a conclusion.
—I have to tell you that not only do the figures not add up; now that we have got more detailed explanations, the situation is that the views that are being put are quite absurd as well.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, why do you want to tax Australian families with a hidden GST every time they need a routine household service? How will you compensate them when they have got to pay an extra 10 per cent when the toilet blocks up, when the TV breaks down, when the washing machine blows up and when the car needs a service? Prime Minister, what if those bills come in the same month as the phone bill, the electricity bill, the gas bill, the rates, the car insurance and registration and the household insurance? Isn't your GST going to cost Australian families hundreds of dollars a year just for basic household services?

—This is from somebody who supports a tax system that says when you go into the kitchen you tax detergent and other cleaners. Not feeling as though you should leave it at that, you tax flavoured milk, you tax fruit juice, biscuits, ice-cream, cutlery, the fridge, the dishwasher, the cooker and the microwave. They are all taxed at 12 per cent. Milk—

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order on relevance. We all know the Prime Minister is rattled at the moment, but he really ought to understand the difference between goods and services, and the question was about service.
—They've been bored by him; never rattled.

—The Deputy Leader is now not making a point of order. If you do not raise your point of order you will not make an intervention across the table. The Prime Minister will remain relevant to the question.

—The Minister for Foreign Affairs said people have been bored by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, but never ever rattled. I say to the member for Prospect that her question is all of a piece with the pattern of questions that have been asked by the opposition. I understand the little game that you are playing. The Australian public know that it is a game. The Australian public will make a judgment on our tax policy when it comes out.

answer.para: I lead a coalition that, unlike the Australian Labor Party, has the courage to tackle serious issues. I lead a coalition that does not go around scaring people. I lead a coalition that is willing to take on long-term economic reform and, despite any short-term political criticism and despite any short-term political adversity, I continue—

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 145, as to relevance. My question was very specific, Mr Prime Minister: will you or will you not tax Australian families on ordinary household services?
—The member for Prospect will resume her seat. The Prime Minister is answering the question within the ambit of the question put to him.

—I would say to the House that I do not intend to be deterred by short-term political circumstances, or by the scare tactics of the opposition, from pursuing my commitment and the commitment of my government to bring to Australian families and to the Australian community long-overdue taxation reform. We remain committed to reforming the Australian taxation system. You can run the frivolous scare campaign; you can enjoy yourselves in the luxury of asking these questions but, when the policy comes out, the Australian people will say that the coalition stands for fairness, and the Labor Party and One Nation look backward into Australia's past.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs. The minister would be aware of concern amongst the citrus, pork and paper industries about the need to have access to speedy anti-dumping provisions. Can the minister advise the House how soon it will be before Australian industries can use the government's new anti-dumping measures?

—I thank the honourable member for Parkes for his question and I commend him on his keen interest in providing a fair trading environment for primary producers and other industries within his electorate and around Australia. Last week the Senate passed the government's new anti-dumping legislation. As a result, Australian industry will now be protected from unfair dumped or subsidised products in the fastest and fairest way in the world. We have delivered on another government election promise. There will be a commitment—a final decision—in 155 days where there are complaints of dumping or subsidisation of products coming into this country, and there will be interim duties available at day 60.

answer.para: Let us contrast what this government has actually achieved with the position of the Labor Party. The honourable member for Hotham—who is very keen at giving advice on these matters—said, when he was defend ing the system introduced by Labor, that it could not be done any faster. It could not be done any faster when Labor was in government but, when they went into opposition, he accused us of being too slow at bringing this new system into place. It is now in place; this government has acted. But where is the Labor Party now? I was amazed, after all of the advice that the member for Hotham has been given, that his union masters put out a media release yesterday demanding that the government delay the introduction of this legislation. The CFMEU and the Tasmanian AMWU want the legislation delayed. So where does the member for Hotham stand now? Is it too fast or is it too slow?

I can assure the citrus growers, the pork growers and the workers in the paper industry that we will not be taking the advice of the trade union movement. We will be implementing this legislation immediately. In fact, the new anti-dumping system is open for business. If there are industries in Australia which believe that their products are being damaged by unfair imports that have been subsidised or dumped, we are ready to hear their case and to deliver appropriate and fair protection for those industries.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Will the Prime Minister admit that his new hidden GST is going to make school holidays far more expensive for Australian families? With his GST on footy tickets, food, the program, public transport and a supporters cap, won't a day at the footy cost a family of four around another $10 in tax? Won't an afternoon at the movies and McDonald's—with tickets, popcorn and the rest—cost a family almost another $10? And won't a weekend camping in a national park—with entry fees, camping permit, tent hire and so on—cost around another $20 with the new hidden GST? Prime Minister, while these amounts might not mean much to you on your salary, how can you deny that they will really hurt ordinary families?
—The member for Swan will not be exhibiting signs in the House. Nor will the member for Franklin.
—I thank the honourable member for Fremantle for her question. My reply to the honourable member is that the entire Australian community will be greatly benefited by our tax reform package.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Are you aware of intentions by the Israeli government to expand the municipal borders of the disputed boundaries of Jerusalem? What effect will this unilateral decision by the Netanyahu government have on the faltering Middle East peace process, and what is the response of the Australian government to that decision?

—I thank the honourable member for North Sydney for his question. The honourable member for North Sydney is one of many members on this side of the House who show a great deal of interest in important international issues. I do not think the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith should nod in agreement because he has not asked a question of me all year—and it is now July.

answer.para: Mr Gareth Evans interjecting—

talk.start.para: —No mock indignation from you. You are the chairman of the tactics committee and you don't ever give him a question. The Australian government is concerned at the recent announcement that the Israeli government has partially approved plans to expand the boundaries of Jerusalem, a move that could see land currently classified as being in the West Bank brought under Jerusalem's direct municipal authority. We have repeatedly expressed the view that unilateral action on the ground by either side only serves to complicate the very difficult negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians. The expansion of Jerusalem to take in Jewish settlements in the West Bank would constitute such a unilateral action of concern. The United States, the European Union and the United Nations Secretary-General himself have expressed similar concerns about the potential of such a decision to complicate negotiations.

answer.para: Our policy has been, and remains, that the status of Jerusalem should be negotiated as part of final status negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians. Again, as I did on my recent visit to the region, I urge all those involved to redouble their efforts to ensure that the Middle East peace process regains the momentum which, frankly, it has lost.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—Please proceed.

—In a newspaper article today in the Australian , written by Robert Garran, the foreign affairs writer, there was a heading `Habibie to host critic Downer'. The article said that President Habibie was a man whom I said six weeks ago would not be remotely acceptable to the Indonesian opposition. This is a distortion, to say the least, of what I actually said. In an interview on 6PR in Perth I talked about the announcement, the resignation by President Suharto and the proposals that he was putting in place. In my comments I said:

speech.para: And I am not here reflecting on the Vice President—
who was then Dr Habibie, which was of course left out of the quote in the Australian —
but I just want to make the point that I doubt those opponents of the regime, what we might call the opposition groups in Indonesia, would regard that as a remotely acceptable solution.
I went on to make the critical point:

See, they do not just want—It is not just the personality, it is the system and I think there is very much a sense now in Indonesia that there has to be reform of the system. That is to be done in a constitutional way.

talk.start.para: —The members standing in the aisles will resume their seats.
—Mr Speaker, I was about to raise a point of order and draw your atten tion to the plot meeting, but obviously you picked it up.

—Of course I did not regard the appointment of Dr Habibie himself as not remotely acceptable; I made the point that it was critically important that there be reform of the system, not just changes of personalities. I think that was very clear from the remarks I made on 6PR.
—A paper is tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members. Details of the paper will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings and Hansard .

speech.para: Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs—National report on schooling in Australia—1996.

debateinfo.title: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION (COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYMENT) REPEAL AND AMENDMENT (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) LEGISLATION

talk.start.para: —I present the explanatory memorandum to the Superannuation Legislation (Commonwealth Employment) Repeal and Amendment (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1998 .
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Should not the explanatory memorandum be tabled with the bill, not after the bill?
—A minister has the capacity to table papers at any time other than in the adjournment.
—Surely we are owed an explanation.

—I have a question for you, Mr Speaker. During question time I observed two members of the government, when the member for Fremantle was asking her question, displaying a sign. My understanding from a ruling in the other place is that, just as it is unparliamentary for a mem ber to utter certain words, it is similarly unparliamentary for a member to display unparliamentary language. Mr Speaker, would you please direct those government members accordingly?

—You might turn around and ask your colleague to desist from doing exactly the same thing. On whichever side of the House members display words, they are out of order. I identified the member for Swan for having displayed signs and the member for Franklin has just done exactly the same thing. Interjections of any sort are out of order.
—I have received a letter from the honourable member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

interjection.para: The need for tax reform which is genuinely in the interests of all Australians.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —In a few days or a few weeks or a few months—the timing, I suppose, depends on whether the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) fears his deputy the Treasurer (Mr Costello) more or the voters more—we will see, as a prelude to the election campaign, the long-delayed release of the coalition's tax package. The centrepiece of that tax package will of course be that very GST which John Howard said three years ago he would `never ever' introduce, which he said two years ago was not on the agenda—vamoose, kaput—and which just 18 months ago the Treasurer was describing as `snake oil'. We are happy to start that debate about that package at any time and wish only that the government had been honest enough to start it months ago by putting its options, its analyses and its ideas on the table for public discussion rather than playing out old political rituals of concealment and grandstanding, of which ordinary Australians are growing increasingly sick and tired.

speech.para: The Labor Party is in favour of tax reform—tax reform which is in the interests of all Australians and which is fair to all Australians. To the extent that the government's package does contain specific proposals or initiatives which are consistent with our thinking and our planning, we will happily embrace them. At the very least we will look at them with a very open mind. That is true, for example, in relation to the issue—the problem—of very high effective marginal tax rates for low and middle income earners, which are caused by the interaction of the social security and taxation systems that we are planning to fix with our own working families tax credit. To the extent that the coalition's tax package happens to contain some serious measures to address tax evasion and tax avoidance—particularly by high wealth and high income individuals through family trusts like Senator Parer's—we will certainly not be critical, rather we will be applauding it. But, given the coalition's absolutely appalling record to date on attacking tax avoidance, we will not be holding our breath.

The truth of the matter is that none of these sorts of reforms will be at the heart of the coalition's tax package. That will be the new tax, the new hidden tax—the GST which John Howard said he would never ever introduce. It is a tax unprecedented in Australia—unprecedented in the degree of unfairness it will involve for low and middle income families—and it is absolutely unredeemed by any contribution it can possibly make to the overall health and efficiency of the Australian economy.

It is also a tax about which a lot of the government's own backbenchers are getting very cold feet—because of that unfairness. Few have been more publicly honest about it than the member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Nairn). When asked in May by his local paper, the Post Examiner, whether he supported a GST, he said, `I don't know if I support a GST, but I do support a fairer based system.' But, then again, I suppose Gary Nairn's reluctance to support the GST could be because, if it comes in, he will have to charge an extra 20c on top of the $2 that he has been putting out as the requirement for pensioner morning teas.

What can we reasonably assume about the shape of the coalition's tax package on the basis of all the leaks and the massaging, and the hints dropped to favourite columnists and reporters that we have been seeing so far? It seems reasonable to assume that what we will see as the central elements in the package are these things: a flat rate GST of up to 12½ per cent; a hidden GST, with the amount of the tax not at all visible to the consumer; a GST which will inevitably rise; a GST with minimal exemptions and exclusions; a GST involving a significant shift in the tax burden, with high income individuals and big business the big winners; a GST which purports to compensate low income earners for its adverse impact upon them and to pay for tax breaks elsewhere, all of which, however little justified, will be emphasised with a huge amount of glitz and fanfare. And we can expect to see a GST plus direct tax-cut package which will probably require a significant raiding of the budget surplus in order to pay for it.

The bottling and the packaging of all this will involve the greatest concentration of snake oil seen since the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories was in its heyday. But, for all the glittering packaging and all the breathless commentary that we expect to accompany it, this will remain a snake oil package. However attractive bits of it may look at first sight, the only thing in it that will be certain will be the introduction of a GST. Everything else will be in the `perhaps' or the `maybe' or `if you're lucky' class—in particular, the stability of the rate and the effectiveness and longevity of the compensation package. The GST is the core promise; everything else will be non-core, subject to the circumstances of the time.

Why is this a snake oil package? It becomes very clear when you go through each of the elements of it that I have mentioned. It will be, for a start, a flat rate GST—and any flat rate tax is inherently regressive and unfair to lower and middle income earners. An extra $10 a day for a family day at the football or the movies might not be much of a hurt for a doctor, a lawyer, a politician or a Prime Minister, but it sure as hell hurts for a process worker's family or anyone else on a low income.

That unfairness is compounded when you realise just how much the new GST will impact on low income budgets—because of course it is the case that lower income people consume a vastly higher proportion of their income than do high income people; it is also true that very low income people consume as much as 40 per cent of their income on food, whereas the ratio for higher income earners is around 10 per cent; it is also true that lower income earners consume, on average, one-third of their income on rent, which is nothing like the case for higher income earners. That is leaving out unavoidable gas, electricity, telephone, postage and public transport costs, and all the rest.

Flattening down the present wholesale sales tax rate will be manifestly unfair as well. As we have seen in this place recently, someone buying a new top-of-the-line Mercedes under the new regime will get a $61,000 tax break, whereas a family buying a used Commodore from a caryard will have to pay out a new tax of around $300.

The second thing about the tax is that it will be hidden. The Treasurer has confirmed in recent days to this parliament that the GST will be embedded in the price of goods and services—which means nothing more or less than it will not be disclosed on price tags for consumers to see. This makes, of course, complete nonsense of one of the major arguments about the present system, the wholesale sales tax system, which is equally embedded in the price of goods. This not only takes away one of the major arguments of the government against the present system, but of course it will make it easier for the rates to be increased in the future.

That is the third thing to say about this package—it will be an inevitably rising GST. The government knows—it confirmed this week through the Attorney-General (Mr Williams)—that no Australian parliament can bind its successor, can stop it changing any law that it makes. You cannot entrench a tax rate at a particular level, and nor can you entrench any particular procedure for example to require the states to be party to any increase in the rate. In any event, the idea that the states could be the guardians of some initial GST rate begs all historical experience. They have never had difficulty agreeing if there is extra revenue involved for them, when it is collected by the Commonwealth and when they can hide behind a collective decision.

Just about every country that has had a GST—21 out of the 23 recorded OECD countries, for a start—has seen those rates rise, inevitably rise: in New Zealand, up from 10 to 12½ per cent; in the UK, from 10 to 17½ per cent; in Denmark, from 10 to 25 per cent. Any promise to hold the GST at its initial rate can only be just another non-core promise.

It will be a GST with minimum exemptions and zero rating. That has been made clear. The Treasurer has been determined from the outset to keep it that way. He has refused to identify as an exclusion even health and education services. He has not denied in this place that the GST will apply to food, clothing, rent, new houses, local government rates, community services, non-profit community organisations and to scores of other areas where huge annual costs are involved for ordinary families.

It will be a GST involving a significant shift in the tax burden. Just as `the higher a GST is, the more unfair it is', so it is the case that, the more it is used to pay for direct tax cuts, the more unfair it necessarily is. Having poor people pay at the checkout counter for income tax cuts for the rich is about as low and unfair as any tax system can descend.

At the very least there will be a shift in the tax burden from big business to households. The President of the Business Council—that well-known pauper, Stan Wallis, responsible for the $4 million ad campaign in support of the government on this issue—did not conceal the point when he said, `The GST holds out the prospect of significant reductions in the indirect tax burden currently borne by busi ness.' Since he was not advocating any overall reduction in the tax take, that can only mean that what business does not have to pay households will. There will also be a major shift in the compliance burden to small business: 75,000 collection points will increase to well over one million; average annual costs to small business will be $7,000; there will be 30 times the degree of extra burden for small business as compared with big business in making all this work.

The GST package will no doubt involve a pretence at compensation. Every time any government anywhere in the world has gone down this path, it has made such a pretence. The coalition is no exemption, floating a whole variety of ways through direct tax cuts and pension increases and goodness knows what else by which all this will occur. As Francis Sullivan, from the Australian Catholic Health Care Association, very graphically put it:
Reports that the Howard Government is planning compensation handouts to ease opposition to a GST is a frank admission that the tax is unfair.

Because it is so unfair in its impact, it needs all these measures to begin to compensate people for the extra costs involved. The big question is whether that compensation, once granted, will stay effective over time. In New Zealand, when the GST rate increased from 10 per cent to 12½ per cent, there was no new compensation package. The government subsequently made a whole series of large cuts to social security benefits, introducing user pays charges, changing and flattening the tax rates in a way that has made it there, as seen in so many other countries, horrendously unfair.

It is a tax package which will depend on the budget surplus in order for it to be fully delivered. That has become clear too from what is on the record. The government will no doubt be hanging on this Christmas tree of a GST a whole range of baubles, bangles, beads and diversions in order to take people's attention away from its basic impact—so many that the whole tree is in danger of falling over. There is every likelihood, as a result, that in order for this package to be paid for there will have to be some raid on the budget surpluses which are now projected. If they are relying on the surpluses to deliver that, then Australian taxpayers and the Australian community may once again have another think coming when it comes to the enjoyment of these so-called baubles, bangles and beads. Given the present condition of the Australian economy, the outlook in Asia, the predictions of every economist in the business as to what will happen in the future, you would be a very brave person indeed to imagine that these surpluses will survive at their present rate and be capable of generating the kinds of direct tax cuts the government is undoubtedly going to be promising.

Finally, there is the point that there is no redeeming economic justification for all of this. It is an important element in everything the government has been saying that it is somehow the responsible economic thing to be doing to be introducing this; that, whatever people's personal concerns might be about the impact of a GST upon them, they really ought to subordinate those personal concerns in the larger national economic interest and reform a tax system that, as the government claims, is hopelessly out of date. The truth of the matter is that there is nothing fundamentally wrong with the Australian tax system, nothing to make it fundamentally out of kilter with tax systems prevailing elsewhere and no reason at all for anyone to feel guilty about opposing a GST on its merits.

Let me say why. There is no relationship anywhere in the world between the presence or absence of a GST and the basic health of the economy. The United States is the healthiest economy in the world and it has no GST or anything like it. We hear from the Treasurer about Swaziland and Botswana. When do we hear about the United States? Secondly, a GST is no help at all when it comes to job creation in the services sector, where most of our hope must be for rapid future employment growth. Whatever case may be said to exist for introducing a new tax on services at a time of economic prosperity—there are many reasons why you should not, but if that case can be made—you would have to say that now is the worst possible time to be creating new discouragements to job creation.

It is also the worst possible time to be creating a new inflationary tax, with anxiety growing about the price impact of the depreciation of the Australian dollar. Professor Warren, Mr Howard's favourite economist, estimated last year that a 10 per cent GST with a comprehensive base would add 5.6 per cent to the CPI. What a time to be going down that particular path! Again, taking these economic arguments one by one, a GST would on the evidence of Treasury secretary, Ted Evans, not do anything to improve national saving—probably our basic biggest structural economic problem. Again, on the evidence of the Treasurer's own former adviser and now deputy head of his taxation task force, a GST will not have any beneficial effect on our trade. Again, there is no credible basis on which you can say that a GST would ensure better taxation of the black economy. Whatever you pick up going out is going to be well and truly outweighed by new kinds of transactions coming into the black economy, as the Canadian experience among many others amply demonstrates. To add to the mindlessness of it all, the OECD is one among many analysts now pointing to the difficulty of relying on collecting a tax in the future in an environment of exploding electronic commerce. We are having this argument at a very time when this particular kind of taxation is rapidly heading into obsolescence.

The Labor Party is an active and willing participant in the tax debate. We are in favour of tax reform. We are wholly in favour of tax reform measures that are genuinely beneficial to Australia and to the great mass of ordinary Australians who are willing to contribute their fair share. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —During the course of the last 15 minutes I have looked at the terms of the matter of public importance. I have done it time and time again. It has been submitted by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) and it reads:

speech.para: The need for tax reform which is genuinely in the interests of all Australians.

The only argument in those 15 minutes that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition put up was that there is nothing fundamentally wrong with our tax system. That is the one point that he has made in 15 minutes that made any sense. The rest was simply a stroll down memory lane. It was called `what if'. He may as well have spent 15 minutes talking about what he is going to do if it rains on Saturday, because that is all the relevance that was in the remarks that he gave in this debate.

He takes up the time of the House by suggesting that there is a need for tax reform which is in the interests of all Australians, and he makes one fundamental point; and that one fundamental point is that there is nothing fundamentally wrong with the tax system. That clearly indicates just how bereft of ideas the Labor Party are on this issue, how they want to continue to bury their head in the sand on this issue, as they did for 13 years when their union mates would not let them make any move on one or two occasions during those 13 years, particularly in 1985, when the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was one of the few people on the then government ranks who were prepared to look at a broad based indirect tax. Unfortunately, the political masters of the Labor Party said, `It is not on. Forget it. Bury it.'

It would be abundantly clear to all Australians, particularly those who watched television in the last few weeks, that there are some fundamental problems with the tax system. It is not serving this community, it is not serving the Australian people; it is simply moving to a point where it will break down hopelessly, where all of those incentives that Australians should have the right to expect in their daily lives will be stripped from them. It is fast moving to the point where it will simply collapse. With that in mind, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has advanced the need for fundamental tax reform in a very sensible, very logical and very proper manner. He has set up the options and the principles, having asked for options that blended with the principles.

It is appropriate for us to examine the principles under which the government is currently working on fundamental tax reform. The first principle is that there should be no increase in the overall tax burden. I want to contrast what this government will do with what the previous Labor government did when it increased the overall tax burden. When the union mates in 1985 knocked over the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and the then Treasurer, when they said that there was no way that they could proceed to a broad based indirect tax, the then Labor government said, `But we need more money.'

So what did we see? Firstly, we saw some changes to the tax system with fringe benefits tax introduced. Secondly, we saw a capital gains tax introduced which brought in additional revenue. We saw a $6 million advertising campaign, promotional campaign, to explain to the Australian people those new taxes which Labor introduced because they could not make fundamental change at that time. We have seen how badly those taxes, let alone the myriad other taxes that are in the present system, have served the Australian community in recent years. We know that Labor stands for new taxes, increased taxes.

In 1993, the year which shall ever be held in the halls of shame of the Labor Party for lying when they made promises to the Australian people, they said there would be no new taxes, no increase in taxes. But we know that the moment they got into government in 1993 the promises that they made about no new taxes, no increases in taxes and cuts in taxes—which they said they would entrench in l-a-w, law—changed directly, changed in backflip fashion, to there being increases in the wholesale sales tax. We saw the rate of 10 per cent increase up to 12 per cent, the rate of 20 per cent increase up to 22 per cent and the rate of 40 per cent increase up to 42 per cent. And those seven taxes, which are not understood by the Australian people and which apply to almost every item on the supermarket shelf, were dealt with, played with, again.

We then saw the Labor government decide that the time was right to strike the people of western Sydney, and the fuel excise was increased. The cost of petrol, the cost of moving, the cost of getting to your job through those roads of western Sydney and the outer suburbs of the other capital cities of Australia and the cost of moving vehicles in the country areas of Australia were increased by way of excise taxes. The exact opposite of what was promised occurred.

When we say there will be no increase in the overall tax burden, let me assure the House that that is the way in which we are undertaking this reform. That is the way in which we are asking the task force to provide us with options. We believe that it is up to governments to trim their own cloth, to live within their means, to not spend what they have not got and to not turn simply to the Australian people whenever they see that there is a demand or need—usually from a squeaky minority group, which Labor always gave in to. You cannot just find the money. When Labor could not find the money they brought in new taxes. They were not prepared to live within their means, and that is why we got ourselves into the unholy mess of debt and deficit which this government has addressed and fixed up.

The second principle under which the options are being prepared for government is that any new taxation system should involve major reductions in personal income tax, with special regard to the taxation treatment of families. Many new initiatives come in today, 1 July, that will benefit the Australian people, not the least of which are some benefits for ordinary families through savings. There are some tax deductions for savings for ordinary families, whether it be in their superannuation or in any other particular investment they might have.

We have also delivered $1 billion to families. We recognise that they are special people in the Australian community. We recognise the role that they play in making this the country that it is. Rest assured that we recognise also that people on ordinary average weekly earnings will by about 2000 or 2001 have to pay tax at the highest rate. By 2000 or 2001 they will have to pay every second dollar to the Commissioner of Taxation. That is Labor's system. That is the system we inherited. That is the system they had 13 years to fix up. They say they represent ordinary working Australians, but they sent them to work on the basis that they would pay every second dollar they earned to a government which squandered the money when they got it and which got the Australian community in debt and deficit during those 13 years.

Those people deserve some reduction in the rate of tax they pay. Those people who are not at the highest levels of income, those who would not be responsible for paying the highest level of tax, also need some relief. I assure you that the government will address the rate at which tax is paid. The government will have special regard to the taxation treatment of families. This government believe in families, and since getting here 2½ years ago all we have done has been about supporting families and recognising the contribution they make to the Australian community.

The third principle is that consideration should be given to a broad based indirect tax to replace some or all of the existing indirect taxes. We now have this absolute stupidity where you do not pay tax on caviar. That is one of the things on the supermarket shelf that you can get through the cash register without paying any additional tax. That is the way in which Labor's tax system works. You do not pay tax on caviar, you do not pay tax on antique items, you do not pay tax on fine art works, you do not pay tax on Lear jets, but you pay tax on the bulk of things that the average family uses day in and day out—but you do not know what the tax is. Let me tell you: the hidden tax that Labor—

talk.start.para: —Are you going to hide it? You're going to hide the GST.

—Let there be no mistake about it—as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition interjects—Labor's current hidden tax is as high as 42 per cent. You have a 42 per cent hidden tax on most items in the supermarket store at the present time, and you have the hide to come in here and talk about hidden taxes. You talk about hidden taxes and you have seven different rates of taxes that no-one knows about.

speech.para: This diminishing area in indirect taxes needs attention, and we really ought to have a look at when it came in. It came in in the 1930s. It came in at a time when everything that was prepared, manufactured and produced in this country was for domestic consumption. We did not have the exports in manufactured goods. We did not send those things overseas. We did not create wealth for our nation. The wealth creation in those days came out of the rural sector almost entirely. Today we have these same hidden taxes—up to 42 per cent; Labor's hidden taxes—being placed on all that we are manufacturing. Is it any wonder we have difficulty in competing with our trade partners when it comes to exporting our manufactured items? The current system of indirect taxes is discriminatory and unfair. We need a broader base that will enable us to provide other benefits for the Australian community in the way of their tax system.

The fourth principle is that there should be appropriate compensation for those deserving of special consideration. We have always recognised those deserving of special consideration. This is the government—the Howard-Fischer government—that enshrined in legislation those increases for those on pensions. For the first time in this nation's history this government has said to those on the age pension, `You will get indexation; it is legislated.' It was left up to the whim of the previous government. If they felt like it or not at any given time, they had the options to be able to crib, to renege and not to recognise those who are less fortunate than us who require that particular support when they get to those retirement years. Rest assured that not only those who are on that fixed income through the social welfare system but also those who are on a fixed income as self-funded retirees will be recognised in any tax that is brought in. The compensation will be there. It will be fair. It will recognise what it will mean in the way of additional costs to those people and, rest assured, it will be covered in the package that is brought forward.

The last principle is that we need reform of the Commonwealth-state financial relations. Of course we do. Perhaps no-one knows that better than I. I used to come down here with my begging bowl as the Premier of the state of New South Wales. On one occasion, much to my surprise, the then Prime Minister gave me everything that I asked for. It was a bit frustrating. I had to tear up the press releases that were prepared in advance because all was given on that occasion. I suffered the following year and we certainly got cut out the next year. It is a ridiculous system where in the states you do not know from one year to the next where you are going. We saw the High Court decision in respect of business franchise fees recently which simply said—what perhaps most of us always knew—that the states do not have the right to levy those taxes the Commonwealth now collects. The states play politics. They suggest we are not giving all that is there. We have to address these areas. They have uncertain taxes. They cannot do long-term planning to provide for the needs of people within the states and territories, and that particular aspect of reform cannot be ignored. It will not be in what the government will bring forward.

This government has addressed the current tax system on the basis of a genuine need for reform and a need for genuine reform. We have not buried our heads in the sand. We do not go around saying what I think will become an immortal quote from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that there is nothing fundamentally wrong with the tax system. If there is nothing fundamentally wrong with the tax system, how do Labor—should they ever be given the mandate by the Australian people—propose to play with the system in the future? I think we know. They will play with it by some sort of manipulation of the current indirect tax called the wholesale sales tax. We are seeing here a phoney debate. There is no sincerity on the part of this opposition. This government will reform. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —At the outset I remind the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey) that the subject of the matter of public importance is:

speech.para: The need for tax reform which is genuinely in the interests of all Australians.

And I would like to emphasise for the Minister for Finance and Administration the words `all Australians'. Tax reform is not just for the mates of the Liberal Party. Tax reform is not just for those peak bodies and organisations representing the top end of town—those groups with enough money to burn on expensive pro-GST advertising campaigns that mouth the government's own hidden tax agenda. Tax reform is not just for the Stan Wallises of this world.

If we are to fix the inadequacies that currently exist in the Australian taxation system, for genuine tax reform to take place Australians must be confident that they are being offered a package that treats them all equally—whatever their means, whatever their background. Tax reform must deliver security and opportunity to the average Australian. That is what Labor is about, and that is what we see as being the incontestable end result of any reform of the Australian taxation system. A tax reform package that introduces a `tax mix switch'—swapping a progressive taxation system for a regressive one—is against the interests of all Australians. A tax reform package that introduces an inherently unfair goods and services tax is quite blatantly against the interests of all Australians.

Yet these are the two objectives that we know this Howard government will be aiming for when it unveils its new tax reform policy in the coming weeks. Tax reform for the Howard government is not about meeting the economic and taxation needs of Australians into the 21st century but about putting together a package that wins it enough votes to cling to office.

This Howard government is keeping Australians in the dark until the very last moment and then attempting to blind them with enough bells and whistles that would make a dead cat seem a fresh and exciting prospect. If the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) of this country were interested in delivering genuine tax reform, we would have been debating in this chamber the intricacies of those proposals over these past months. Instead, what do we see? We have seen a ridiculous and cynical charade of a discussion by the Prime Minister and Treasurer as both gentlemen have withheld the details of their policy from the public.

The public want to know. What the Australian people have been given are a few glimps es of the broad brushstrokes of their intentions; a few flashes of skin but not too much, just like a pair of tired, old strippers. But, hide it or not, we have seen and heard enough to know what is up their sleeves, and so have the majority of average Australians.
The Liberal Party equates tax reform with a GST. Prime Minister John Howard has said as much himself. In March last year the Prime Minister said on Radio 5DN:
When you talk about aggregate tax reform, you are really talking about whether or not we are going to have a GST.

The Liberal Party is obsessed with the same ideas it had on taxation in the 1980s and the beginning of the 1990s. It wants to go back to a tax that was emphatically and energetically rejected by the Australian people in the 1993 election. This government wants to go back to a tax that leaves low and middle income earners worse off while the fat cats of this country scratch their bellies and congratulate each other on how well they will do under the system. It wants to go back to a tax that is an unfair anachronism—a hangover from European economic thinking of the sixties and seventies—and hardly the sort of thinking to lead Australia and Australians into the next millennium.

A GST is quite simply not tax reform that is in the interests of all Australians. Firstly, it is an unjust tax. Consider the fact that for the past few months we have had government members—including the Prime Minister and the Treasurer—wandering around talking about introducing a GST with compensation payments for the elderly, for home buyers and for people on lower incomes. Compensation is an explicit admission that a GST is unjust.

It is a tax that leaves people worse off; therefore they must be compensated for what effect it has on their lives. No compensation package is going to cover all Australians from the damage a GST will do to them. Secondly, a GST does not create jobs. Under a GST, in order for small businesses to remain competitive with big businesses, they will have to haemorrhage thousands of jobs. The service sector—areas like tourism where job growth has been at its strongest over the past de cade—will be nobbled by a tax that directly inhibits employment growth.
Professor Neil Warren—a key adviser to the coalition on the GST during the early 1990s—has made the GST's dead or negative affect on job growth absolutely clear. He stated:
It's a mistake to say that it—
meaning a GST—
is going to cure our foreign debt and create thousands of jobs. It's just not going to do that.

Thirdly, as we all also know, a GST is virtually guaranteed to increase within a few years of its introduction. By looking around the world at other countries that have experienced a GST or its equivalent, we can see that within five to 10 years the rate of tax increases to sometimes double the level at which it was originally set.

You cannot cap a GST. We know it and the government knows it, but they do not want to tell the Australian people. John Hewson—the man who made the mould for a GST in this country—is someone else who also knows it. He has said that a GST set below 15 per cent will invariably rise to that level. So much for the Treasurer's guarded little hints about a 10 per cent GST.

All of these aspects of a GST combine to make it a reform that is quite obviously not in the interests of all Australians. To add insult to injury, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer of this country have engaged in a level of duplicity and treachery on the GST that would leave Benedict Arnold or Tokyo Rose red-faced. Prime Minister John Howard said in May 1995:
There's no way a GST will ever be a part of our policy. Never, ever. It's dead; it was killed by the voters in the last election.
Treasurer Peter Costello said in May 1996:
In our election in 1996, we indicated we wouldn't introduce a GST. Ah, that finishes the matter. We won't.
Do you remember that quote? Prime Minister John Howard was at it again in January 1997 and still as adamant as ever. He said:
People get the idea that it's the economic elixir of Australia.
That is, a GST. He continued:
I don't think people should make the mistake of imagining that a dramatic change to the tax system is going, of itself, to transform the economy.

Both gentlemen have at various times condemned the GST to the dustbin of history. They have pilloried it and pointed out its faults for all and sundry to see. Yet now they are back to sell us this loathsome tax once again. Their deceit is only eclipsed by their gall. A GST delivers neither security nor opportunity. A GST's calling cards are crippling inequality, red tape and higher and more burdensome costs on families.

Labor's tax plans are, however, about reforming the system in the interests of all Australian families—families who, like many living in my electorate, presently have their backs to the wall. Labor's tax credit for working families will deliver tangible tax cuts to low and middle income working families by introducing a tax credit for those who work, or want to work, but who face debilitating tax bills and the loss of support payments.

Labor's tax credit system rewards work, where the current system can penalise families who increase their earnings. It will be a new tax payment which introduces a direct work incentive into the Australian tax and social security systems which has not existed before. Labor's tax credit for working families works in unison with the present social security system to deliver strongly on our objective of bringing security and opportunity to families who have been robbed of such certainties over the last few years under this Howard government.

Labor's tax reforms are about giving Australians a choice between a regressive, out-of-date and unfair package with a GST as its centrepiece and a tax package that neither penalises nor adds extra burdens for ordinary working families. Labor welcomes tax reform. We have never shied away from the idea of reforming the tax system or debating what methods could be used to achieve this objective. Labor agrees that there is an argument for tax reform that genuinely meets the interests of all Australians. However, Labor does not, and will never, agree to a GST as the solution to our tax problems.

Rather than supporting the interests of Australians, a GST will undermine them. A tax system that undermines the interests of Australians will leave us a diminished, weakened and divided nation as we enter the next century. It is a recipe for disaster and it will be soundly rejected once and for all by the Australian people at the next election—an election that will be called when this Prime Minister can find the courage. I say to him, and to the whole of his government, that if we want to talk about reform and we want to talk about how good the GST is for the country and for all Australians come into the parliament with the package. Let us debate the package. Do not keep it hidden away behind closed doors—let us see what the package is all about. And, more importantly, let us see an honest government stand up and deliver to the Australian people what they are going to take to the next election so that we have the opportunity to debate some merits of their tax package. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —One can only grin when a member of the 1993 government says, `It is your responsibility to tell us before the election what you propose to do, when in fact in 1993 we, as a government, did just that in promising l-a-w tax cuts and then turned around after the election and broke that promise.' What did they do to the poor people of Australia? They put the highest level of their tax increases on consumer goods—on leaded petrol—and they said they did that for environmental reasons. But did they send any of the revenue over to the environment? No, sir. Not one penny!

speech.para: The reality is that the Labor Party should be struck down by lightning every time they stand in this place and pontificate on the issue of honesty in tax policy. They have no credibility, and for people who were here and who placed that particular burden upon the Australian people it is arrant hypocrisy. What is more, when they took that choice, where did they apply the greatest burden? On fuel, the lifeblood of transport. If and when Australia shrinks to the size of Singapore, I will have no difficulty with taxing fuel, but I thought it was the dumbest possible policy that any government could pursue. The reality is that over the life of the previous Labor government the tax on fuel rose from 6c a litre to 36c a litre.
