Australia is a country with a small population and large resources. Its living standards exceed those of most other nations throughout the world. No-one disputes the fact that, to maintain those living standards in the environment of a highly competitive world, a nation must achieve high exports and be able to meet vigorous import competition. In that environment it would seem patently silly to have a tax system that imposed itself constantly and consistently onto the cost of production of the goods we export or that we produce to consume at home. That is a fundamental issue.

The issue of how much tax a government raises is one for this House. The issue of the incidence of the fall of tax on Australians is an issue for this House. But, in terms of this debate, it is said that our reference to paying compensation, if in our view there is a change in the incidence of taxation, is an admission that it will occur. That must stand in front of the fact that, quite clearly, when we in this parliament put up the price of leaded petrol it fell on those who were still buying old-fashioned cars. When that happened the reality was that no compensation was paid by the Labor government.

We accept the fact that we have got to give industry a go. I was concerned that the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) wanted to talk about Stan Wallis as though he would be the only beneficiary of his industries being made more efficient. I thought it might have been an incentive for his industry to go out and get more orders and employ more people and, yes, make a profit on their efforts. The reality is that we know why our businesses are in Indonesia: they can produce goods cheaper and under Labor's tariff policy export them back to Australia.

Let me give an example of how our present tax system works in the production of that icon of Australian manufacturing, a Holden Commodore. A Holden Commodore, in the Australian context, starts its life in an iron ore mine and a coal mine. The iron ore mine employers pay payroll tax. They pay very substantial quantities of wholesale sales tax, although they are exempt from some. They pay a component of fuel tax up to 100 per cent. And, of course, they pay 100 per cent of fuel tax to have the fuel delivered to the extremities of the mine site. They pay payroll tax, as I have said, and they pay financial institutions duty on very large sums of money.

But that is not the end of the story, because having paid those taxes their cost accountants then say, `This is a cost of doing business. We need a profit margin on that.' So they put it on those taxes and they disappear into the system. But then, of course, that iron ore and coal has to be freighted away from those mine sites either by rail or road, where fuel tax is paid and wholesale sales taxes are imposed. If it just happens to be by road, which is quite significant, and the means of transport happens to be a now well-recognised vehicle, a B-double, which is a sort of dual trailer unit, I got advice from the Road Transport Forum the other day which confirms my own experience in this industry that the effect of indirect taxes—fuel taxes, wholesale sales tax and these other taxes—on the operation of that truck is $1,750 a week. As these goods, yet to be made into anything, move down the road on a truck, we have got to add $1,750 per week for a 30-tonne load. Of course it is built into the freight charge, and of course a profit margin is attached to it.

Then we get to the smelting process. BHP pays payroll tax, pays sales tax, pays financial institutions duty and pays WST. By this stage, not only do its cost accountants build that into the price of their manufactured item, which is a bit of steel—a long way from a Holden—but it is going to put a profit margin on its taxes and all the taxes and profit margins on taxes paid by those who have got that product to their front door. Then, of course, we have the transport task again and another $1,750, because we are going to get to the component manufacturers. Then we are going to see them add their taxes into that cost and add another profit margin.

After that we get to the transport task yet again, because we are going to have a vehicle manufacturer and assembler who pays payroll tax, fuel tax and all those taxes I have mentioned, adds it into the price of the car and adds a profit margin to its taxes and all those taxes that were paid before. At that stage, as we roll it out the door, we actually put 22.5 per cent of real, honest, visible tax on that particular vehicle and send it off to the vehicle retailer, who pays fuel tax, who pays payroll tax, who pays financial institutions duties and who pays sales tax.

All of that is added into the cost of the car. I take you back to the vehicle manufacturer in Geelong, who produces a beautiful car today. I am sure the Holden Commodore or our locally manufactured Fords can be admired. But we say, `We can't export them, they are too dear.' The message for the Labor Party is: who have we blamed in the past? We have blamed the workers. We have said they are inefficient and lazy. It is not the workers. We are putting about $1,000 per vehicle of hidden tax costs into that construction process and telling the workers of Geelong and Elizabeth to go out and compete in the world, to go out and compete with the Europeans, who have not had that process applying to their manufactured goods for 30 years.

Might I say, in response to the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans), that on the introduction of that tax, right up to the oil shock, all those countries had rates of growth about six per cent and inflation at about four per cent. That is a matter of record. You do not have to dispute it. Go to the Parliamentary Library, as I did, and get it.

The realities are that we are asking our people to operate in a highly competitive world environment, where a lot of other difficulties like wages and so on are there for us, and we want to add an additional burden. We know that a VAT or GST, call it what you like, does not have that effect. That is beyond dispute. You charge your customer, you bank the money and you are able to use any tax collected to pay the tax that you pay to your suppliers. Within the confines of your business, there is no tax imposition on the cost of doing business. That is so necessary if we are to put ourselves on the same footing as others. We just cannot tax our workers with their jobs by a tax system that has the effect I have just identified. I could go on and say how it is costing us jobs in the financial sector. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —There is no-one in this House who doubts the need for tax reform. That tax reform clearly has to be equitable. The government puts forward the view that we have to broaden the tax base, and we do have to broaden the tax base, but there are other ways you can do it without the imposition of a GST. If you get more people working, that would certainly broaden the tax base. You could make large foreign companies pay tax. That too would broaden the tax base. These are issues which the government could easily attack.

speech.para: The GST, the goods and services tax, is called just this because this government was toying with it at the time when the government in Canada was completely routed through the introduction of this sort of tax and when this tax was very unpopular in Britain. There it is called a VAT, a value added tax. So it thought, `We will be clever, we will change the name.' A GST is not necessarily the same as a VAT, because you do not have this payment claiming process as you do with a VAT. It could be a one-off decision or it could be put at a lower level which is not claimed back. Now the government is talking about changing the name of the GST because the GST is unpopular. This sort of window-dressing is not going to fool the Australian people.

The reality is that throughout the world, wherever the GST type tax has been introduced, it has always risen. There are two exceptions to that, I might add, where it has been introduced only recently. Inevitably it will rise. That is the history throughout the world. The undisputed history throughout the world is that, where you get the introduction of a GST, the total government tax take increases. Does anyone seriously think Australia is going to be different? Of course it is not. The total government tax take will increase if you add a GST to the tax system.

The member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) was preaching the importance of exports and the export dollar. It was somewhat reminiscent of the time when I used to preach this message too. But, when you actually apply some intellectual rigour to it, you understand that any import replacement dollar has exactly the same effect on the economy as an export dollar, and in additional ways it is often more beneficial. The truth is that our current account deficit is out of control and growing, and 87 per cent of our current account deficit is now for the importation of manufactured goods, much of which we used to manufacture in Australia. It is now historic fact that Keating was responsible for deskilling this country and probably put the final nails in the coffin of our manufacturing industry. Without a return to a manufacturing industry, there are no jobs for our children and there is no end to the GST, and that is not fully appreciated by either political party.

The member for O'Connor is extremely naive if he thinks that the introduction of additional tax is going to stimulate the manufacturing industry. It will not. I am amused to hear the Business Council of Australia calling for a GST. It is obviously trying to coordinate its program with the government. It is lending a lot of its money to TV advertising preaching the benefits of the GST. Perhaps if the Business Council of Australia and all its members stopped bringing up all these tax dodges they would be paying more tax, which would broaden the tax base and make the introduction of additional revenue less necessary. I think the Business Council of Australia and its members should seriously consider their ethics in this matter.

I want to talk today about a tax that has the potential to equitably reduce the burden of taxation across the board. Australia First has said to the government, `Put all the cards on the table and let us see the figures in respect of the debit tax compared with the GST.' A debit tax postulates that if you tax every withdrawal from every financial institution, including credit cards, at 0.33 cents in the dollar, you raise enough money to entirely replace income tax plus another $50-odd billion that you can do with as you would.

Clearly it is a tax that is very easy to collect. It is collected by the banks at the end of the day and all the government does is put the software insertion into their computer system and at the end of the day they can transfer that money electronically to the government. Banks are not going to cheat because it is not their money and you simply write into legislation that they lose their bank licence if they do. I certainly would not trust banks, but in a situation like this they certainly would not cheat.

When I mentioned this to Prime Minister (Mr Howard), he said, `Oh, it has been tried in Sri Lanka. It didn't work there.' It has never been tried in Sri Lanka. That is now accepted as fact. He was simply wrong. What he was talking about was a turnover tax, which is much more akin to his GST. I spoke to the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and he said, `No, foreign companies would avoid it.' Heavens, his own taxation department is telling us that those companies avoid the present tax regime. We say it is much harder to avoid this tax. I asked the Treasurer, `How will they avoid it?' He said, `They will draw the money out of the banks in Australia and move it overseas.' Bingo, the minute they draw it out of the bank in Australia, they pay the tax.

In any case, neither the government nor the opposition sees anything wrong in deeming pensioners. If you know that your system is being rorted, you can say to these people, `We will deem you.' I guarantee that will soon bring them back into line. But I do not think business is that stupid and I do not think business would flee Australia for a safe haven in the Cook Islands, whose tax regime is two per cent, to escape this tax. The simplicity of it is enormous and is open for all to see. It is a tax which would be highly visible. We could publish the figures every month as to how much tax the government was collecting. I think people should understand how much tax they pay. This tax would encourage people to save because it is a tax only on withdrawals.

Let us have the debate. What is the government frightened of? Bring in your arguments against it. The arguments I have seen so far have been fatuous. One of the members of this House was circulating a paper prepared by the Parliamentary Library. It was palpable nonsense. Anyone who understands the tax could discredit those criticisms very easily. Let the government bring in a full-blown debate on the virtues of these two taxes. We say this tax will restore incentive to Australian people. It will be an enormous incentive. You could take out of the equation taxation on overtime. No other tax is going to do this. We believe it should be discussed.

There are opponents to this tax. Let us see who they are. Primarily, the government does not like it because it would not be in a position to offer largesse; it would not be able to give you a tax break—there will be no tax breaks to give. Big business does not like it because they do not pay tax now and they could not avoid this one. That is why they do not like it. The bureaucracy would not like it because there certainly would not be the need for the massive taxation bureaucracy, not that I am suggesting you would sack them all. There would be no need to; you could relocate a lot of them into useful things such as tracking down rorts in some other areas. I believe there would still be a case for excise duties and properly applied tariffs. Those people could be involved in that sort of monitoring.

We currently spend about $6 billion minimising our tax. If we had a debits tax, the people in the taxation industry would have to go and do something useful. I have talked to a lot of people in the tax industry and they say they would look forward to that. The competent ones say, `Yes, I look forward to doing what I was trained to do, what I spent my time at university learning, how to make businesses more efficient.' I do not think there needs to be a great concern there.

Why won't the government put the cards on the table and simply let people come forward with their criticisms? There are people around who know enough about this to be able to refute them. At the end of the day, if it is on the table, the Australian people can decide. This tax is elegant. It was not possible probably until the last 10 years with the advent of advanced computers and computer software, but it is available now.

People ask where this tax is used. I can give an example. It is used in a limited way by our states. They use the so-called BAD tax, which is a debit tax you pay the state every time you cash a cheque. The problem with that system is that it applies only to cheques and there is a cap on it. I think in New South Wales and Queensland you pay a maximum of $400 and in Western Australia it is $470. In a sense, that makes it regressive, but if it applied to all transactions, be they cheques or other financial transactions, you would broaden the base enormously.

No-one seriously complains about the BAD tax. It is a very simple situation. I have had situations in my own state where, if the government was to increase the BAD tax and reduce some of the other very selective taxes, people would be much happier. This tax must be considered. Let us put the cards on the table and have a thorough, open and honest debate on taxation, for the benefit of all Australians.

talk.start.para: —The discussion is concluded.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to join this debate to discuss the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1998 as it relates to states grants and more generally to tax reform. The bill is routine annual legislation that has two main purposes: to give effect to the Commonwealth general revenue assistance to the states and territories for 1998-99 and to extend the operation of section 90 safety net arrangements to protect state and territory revenues in 1998-99.

speech.para: The bill provides for the payment to the state and territories of general revenue assistance, estimated at $17.1 billion in 1998-99. Financial assistance grants, estimated to total $16.9 billion, comprise the major part of this assistance. The states and territories will benefit from real per capita growth in financial assistance grants in 1998-99 with these grants being distributed in accordance with the equalisation per capita relativities recommended by the Commonwealth Grants Commission.

In addition, states and territories will receive an estimated $217.2 million in competition payments to the states and territories in 1998-99. These payments and the per capita element of the real per capita growth in financial assistance grants are conditional on states and territories meeting the terms of the national competition agreement. The National Competition Council will shortly be reporting on state and territory progress in competition policy reforms.

The bill also provides for state and territories making fiscal contribution payments totalling some $313.4 million to the Commonwealth in 1998-99 and this will be the third and final instalment of these contributions which was agreed to at the 1996 Premiers Conference. The achievement by the Commonwealth of a responsible surplus in 1998-99 is central to Australia's economic interest, particularly in light of financial instability in Asia. The state fiscal contributions will make an important contribution to that surplus.

After allowing for fiscal contribution payments, total payments to the states will increase by $957 million, or 3.1 per cent, in 1998-99. A state's fiscal contribution can be paid by way of deductions from general revenue assistance, direct payments to the Commonwealth or a reduction in funding provided under a specific purpose grant. As in the previous two years, the bill provides for all or part of a state's 1998-99 fiscal contributions, including any unpaid amounts, to be deducted from general revenue assistance payments to that state.

The bill provides for payments to states in 1998-99 under the safety net arrangements requested by the states to protect their revenues following the High Court decision on 5 August 1997 on the constitutional validity of state business franchise fees. It is estimated that revenue replacement payments to the states will be around $6.5 billion in 1998-99. Revenue collections under the safety net agreements were provided for in separate legislation in 1997-98 which do not require annual amendments.

I stand before you today as a fairly proud Western Australian. I am not only proud to be a hardworking representative for the seat of Cowan but also proud to be representing the state of Western Australia. I might tell the House and those who are listening at the moment some facts about Western Australia. Western Australia has 1.8 million Australians—less than 10 per cent of the Australian population—yet it supplies almost 11 per cent of the PAYE tax collected. Western Australia has over 25 per cent of the national export income, totalling some $27 billion out of a national total of $79 billion.

Western Australia is the biggest producer of oil and gas in the nation. Western Australia is also the biggest producer and exporter of wheat in the nation. It is the biggest producer of gold in the nation, with some 78 per cent of the total, about $3.5 billion. Western Australia is also the biggest producer of nickel in the nation, about $1.25 billion. We are the biggest exporter of crayfish and abalone.

Western Australia has the biggest diamond mine in the world, covering some 38 million carats or about 38 per cent of the world's total. Western Australia is also the biggest exporter of alumina powder in the world. It is also the biggest producer of cobalt in the world with the advent of the Anaconda mine near Leonora. It is the biggest producer of iron ore in the world, producing some $3.4 billion. It is the biggest producer of lupins in the world. It has the biggest solar salt operation in the Southern Hemisphere, accounting for over one-third of the world production.

Western Australia had growth at the end of 1997 of some 7.9 per cent against the national average of 3.7 per cent. By further comparison, the US was at 3.7 per cent, the UK was at 3.2 per cent, Germany was at 2.3 per cent, Japan was at 0.9 per cent and the OECD average was at three per cent for the very same period when Western Australia had growth at 7.9 per cent.

We have 25 per cent of the national road network and one-third of the national land mass, yet we receive only 11 per cent of national road funding and in 1995-96 we received only 8.5 per cent. We do not have a direct flight to Canberra from Western Australia. We have limited defence facilities in Western Australia, in particular for our offshore gas fields and oilfields. With these points on states grants issues in mind, it is important to note that Western Australia feels a bit aggrieved about the process of states grants. That is why the Howard government, our government, is searching for tax reform. It must be pointed out that other speakers have spoken on different parts of the states grants bill in the debate on the matter of public importance today.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) set out five criteria to be followed in the tax reform process. All the discussions and debate around the country at the moment seem to focus on only one aspect. The Prime Minister talks about five components; so, too, do the rest of the government frontbench. The first component is fairness. Australians should be treated fairly when it comes to tax reform. The second component is a reduction in income tax. A lot of people are talking about income tax. No-one is actually talking about an agreement to a reduction in income tax, yet the coalition government wants this to happen.

The third component is a broad based indirect tax. There are some problems associated with such a tax. We are considering a broad based indirect tax but there have been no announcements yet. The fourth component is states and Commonwealth grants and funding. The fifth component is no increase in tax collection. There are five components, yet everyone seems to be talking about only one. Today we should also be considering the way our states are funded. This is one of the key components of the need for tax reform.

It is interesting to note that in 1901 the states created the Commonwealth of Australia—the Federation. However, since that time, the powers vested in the states at the time of Federation have been pared back through High Court and Commonwealth parliament acts. This has had a great impact on the taxing powers of the states, culminating in the 1997 franchise decision by the High Court virtually prescribing that the major revenue raising powers be vested in the Commonwealth.

It must be said that I do not necessarily oppose the many decisions over the last 97 years to reduce some of the powers of the states. However, I strongly support a review of the funding processes to the states. Funding allows the states to provide the services that the community demands. In Cowan, for instance, many projects are needed in the community—new primary schools, bus services and extra police for law and order control—yet the state government claims they have limited funds to provide these services. For the people of Cowan to receive the services they want in the community, we must have tax reform, in particular, tax reform in relation to state and Commonwealth funding.

In short, the Commonwealth raises the funds and the states have the responsibility to provide community services. The problem comes when demands from the community far outweigh the funds available. Under the current arrangements, the Commonwealth accounts for around 80 per cent of the revenue raised, yet that only accounts for around 57 per cent of the total expenditure of all governments. This is why the government wants tax reform and wants to get the balance right. This particular imbalance is commonly called a `vertical fiscal imbalance'. Even before the 1997 High Court decision, Australia had the highest vertical fiscal imbalance of any comparable federation. Surely this is a direct indicator for tax reform within our country.

The Prime Minister has assured us that tax reform will include reform to solve some of these issues. It is interesting to note that, since the imbalance has become even more acute, the state governments have moved more heavily towards social and financial taxes like FID taxes, as mentioned by the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), and gambling taxes, which are a concern of many in this place. It seems that a lot of states rely on the gambling dollar to raise funds for services. The employment restricting payroll tax is an unfair tax on the nation and has an impact on employment. The states rely more and more on this tax.

In 1978-79 the Commonwealth returned some 34 per cent to the states, yet by 1988 this proportion was down to 24 per cent. It is planned to reduce the amount to 20 per cent soon, therefore confirming an urgent need for tax reform in our country. Because of the reduced funding, the states are required to raise their own inefficient and in some cases unfair taxes. The problem is compounded when the states receive their grants from the Commonwealth. These grants are usually tied, therefore reducing flexibility for the states in providing for the community. For instance, in the early 1990s some 25 per cent of the grants provided were tied. Now the amount is almost 50 per cent. That is surely another confirmation as to why the Prime Minister wants tax reform in this important area.

Given the complex nature of vertical fiscal imbalance, it becomes very important for the states to obtain some revenue raising powers; powers that can best reflect the needs of the states and the obligation that they have to their communities. The difficulties associated with interstate trade prevent states from applying their own indirect tax system, although constitutionally the states do have the power to apply an income tax. However, this is really not the preferred option. What this country really needs is tax reform. We need to debate these issues. We need something more than a broad based indirect tax.

It seems that only two groups are speaking against tax reform in this debate. Many groups seem to be in favour of tax reform. In fact, I recently surveyed my electorate of Cowan. Some 94 per cent of residents indicated that they welcome tax reform. Major associations in the community have identified tax reform as being an urgent need. As I said, there are two groups within the country that do not want tax reform. The first group is the One Nation Party. The One Nation Party does not want tax reform. Their policy is to solve the economic problems within our country by printing more money. The other group—honourable members would be familiar with this group—is the Australian Labor Party. Honourable members may have heard the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) speaking earlier and saying that the Labor Party is in favour of tax reform and against a GST or broad based indirect tax. There was no mention in her speech of state or Commonwealth funding issues or the need for tax reform. She did say that the Labor Party was committed to tax reform.

talk.start.para: —As Deputy Speaker, I remind the member for Cowan that he is certainly straying from the bill before the House. I am sure he will come back to the context of the bill we are debating.
—I am talking about states grants, Madam Deputy Speaker. The point is that there is a need for tax reform in this particular area but no-one seems to be talking about it.

speech.para: The Labor Party have not mentioned, in any of their discussions regarding tax reform, the relationship between state and Commonwealth funding. The Labor Party do not seem to want to end vertical fiscal imbalance. There has been no mention in debates so far on tax reform about vertical fiscal imbalance. In fact, I think I have heard some members on the other side supporting the idea of abolishing the states.

I would like to put a question to all the Western Australian Labor members in this place—and there are three of them—and I would extend it to all the Labor Party candidates who are standing for Western Australian seats. Do they want a better deal for Western Australia? Do they think that vertical fiscal imbalance between state and Commonwealth funding is hurting Western Australian communities? If so, do they support tax reform in this vital area? The obvious answer for any Western Australian who is supportive of Western Australian issues is yes, they should support tax reform and, in particular, state and Commonwealth funding issues. Yet I imagine that most of their responses would be no. They would say no because they are told to say no.

We should never forget the Labor Party when they were in power. They had a chance to do tax reform, and they applied some tax reform around 1985. They brought in the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax, and they tried a few other things but they were not successful. They tried tax reform but they were not able to apply it to the benefit of the nation. They also gave us, during that period, 11 per cent unemployment. They took interest rates in Australia to over 20 per cent—in particular business interest rates—in the late 1980s. I can recall them being 23 per cent on my own accounts. They also increased foreign debt during that period. In fact, government debt increased from $16 billion to $93 billion.

In their last five years of government, the Labor Party had budget deficits which totalled over $70 billion. In the last year of their administration they told us—as they went to the election in 1996—that they were in fact in surplus. We found out after there was a change of government that we were over $10.4 billion in deficit. In 1993 they promised us they would not increase taxes, yet they did. They promised us l-a-w, law, tax cuts, yet they never delivered. They said they would not want an indirect tax, yet their own indirect tax—the wholesale sales tax—increased from 10 per cent to 12 per cent, from 20 per cent to 22 per cent, and from 30 per cent to 32 per cent. This is after they went to the election in 1993 promising not to put up taxes. They promised, yet they never delivered. They did put up taxes. They did it secretly through the back door in hidden taxes.

Labor, when they were in charge of the national accounts, were a disaster. They were a disaster in Western Australia, they were a disaster in South Australia, they were a disaster in Victoria and they are now a disaster in New South Wales. Who knows what will happen in Queensland? Nationally, for 13 years, the Labor Party in government were a disaster. They ruined our accounts, they sent us into debt, they ruined our credit, they ruined small businesses during the late 1980s and early 1990s with their policies and they ruined the hope of many Australians. The previous speaker, the member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson), said that we do not need tax reform and that we cannot apply compensation packages because they are unreliable and they do not work. By implication, he must think that the current system is working. The current system in Australia allows a family with three children on $20,000 to earn more cash in hand than a family earning $30,000. That cannot be fair. It cannot be acceptable, yet this is the tax system the Labor Party want us to have. What do they say about their own government, their own tax reform and how they approach these issues?

talk.start.para: —I am sure the member for Cowan is going to bring us back to the bill—the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1998 . I could not find any of the context of your debate in the bill, but I am sure you will enlighten me as you go along in your debate.

—The previous speaker spoke about a GST for his entire speech. I am only responding to what he said. What do the Labor Party say about their tax reform period of 13 years? Did they have a tax reform regime? The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) said, `We are a good government and we are not going to apologise.' He said that in 1996. The member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) said in 1996, `The Australian people are a pretty forgiving population. They basically threw us out on 2 March not on the basis that we were a bad government but basically related to an "It's time" factor.'
—Again, I will ask the member for Cowan to please come back to the bill before the House.

—I commend this bill to the House. There is an urgent need for tax reform within our country—tax reform which will help the states with their state grant funding and tax reform which will only ever happen under a coalition administration.

—This has been a wide-ranging debate covering a wide range of issues that relate to the strict provisions of the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1998 and matters that flow from that. Might I first repeat the words of the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles):

speech.para: The bill will amend the States Grants (General Purposes) Act 1994.
He then describes the existing act. He continues:

The bill extends for a further 12 months the provisions of the act relating to the payment of financial assistance grants and state and territory entitlements to payments under the safety net arrangements.

He goes on to specify the various amounts being made and gives some background. This debate is of a wide-ranging nature. It has had implications for the government's economic and fiscal policies. The previous speaker, the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) made beautiful reference—albeit in passing—to vertical fiscal imbalance. I would that he had gone on to explain in a bit more detail and to translate the words `vertical fiscal imbalance'. Maybe it is one of the positions of the Kama Sutra , I do not know, but I am sure that in the minds of members the public it may as well be. What he is really talking about is the expenditure burden on states and the unequal access they have to revenue to meet those expenditure outlays. It goes to the relationship between federal government and state governments on revenue, shares of revenue and responsibilities for expenditure and provision of services.

From what the member for Cowan said, you would think the Australian Labor Party was opposed to tax reform. That is completely untrue. He knows it to be untrue, as does the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and every one of his ministers, right down through the ranks of the government. The ALP is totally in support of reform, but let us define reform. The government's version of reform is shifting the tax burden from business, high income earners, family trusts and offshore tax havens—shifting what little they pay—back down to low income families, middle income families and small business. We are totally in support of tax reform, but let us put it on the table and define it.

Just under 12 months ago this Prime Minister invited Australia to accompany him on a great adventure into tax reform. But it really is blindman's buff. Whatever the adventure is that he is pursuing, he has his eyes masked. No-one can be told about what the adventure is. No-one can be told about what the provisions of the tax proposal are—

talk.start.para: —What has this got to do with the bill?

—I reminded the member for Cowan and I remind the member for Shortland that we are debating the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1998 . I believe we should confine the debate to the bill before the House.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I am responding to the matters raised by previous speakers and within the ambit of the provisions of the bill which go to federal-state financial relations, expenditure and methods of collecting revenue.

speech.para: Mrs Bishop interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Yes, I am listening very well. I think on this side of the House we are entitled to respond to those accusations that have been made and which have been allowed by the chair to proceed.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The point that needs to be made is that you were pulling up the previous government member for allegedly straying from the subject of the bill in discussing tax reform. Now you have the opposition spokesman doing exactly the same thing and you only pulled him up in response to my interjection.
—No—

—I am glad you did that. I withdraw that. But I do not think that you can allow the argument to go that, simply because the argument was put forward from the government side, your ruling can be ignored and he can go on his merry way. You have to be even-handed in this matter.

—I can assure the minister that I am even-handed. I allowed the honourable member for Cowan to go at least 15 minutes into the debate before I actually brought him back to the bill before the House. I say to the honourable member for Shortland, as I said to the honourable member for Cowan, that we do have a specific bill before the House, without going into extraneous matters. The honourable member for Shortland had informed me in the chair, and the minister at the table, that he was responding to the member for Cowan. I would ask him just to speak to the response and then to bring into detail the bill before the House.

—In doing that, I would be the only speaker in this debate to have done so. I will do my best, but I am bound to respond to those matters raised by the previous speaker, which I have taken detailed notes of.

speech.para: Mrs Bishop interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Were the minister in the chair, I would love to follow her direction. But she is not in the chair. To say that we are opposed to tax reform is false. What I have said is that we totally support tax reform, but if the government has a version of tax reform—as I hear the Prime Minister and other members enunciating—let us have the definition of it. I think that is a fair response. The member for Cowan said they are in favour of a fair tax. We are all in favour of a fair tax. But please define what you mean by `a fair tax'. He says he is from Western Australia and they do not get a fair share of taxation revenue. He referred to vertical fiscal imbalance. Each state argues that case about vertical fiscal imbalance.

speech.para: However, I do have to agree with the member for Cowan when he opposes gambling. I have raised in this House on a number of occasions the social devastation that is occurring in our community because of the pressure upon states to raise money from soft sources, the major soft source being the expansion of gambling activities and the collection of tax from gambling. People are invited into gambling establishments to part them from their money, not to give them something. If you give them some grog, put an automatic teller machine beside them and, not too far away, a poker machine they will be parted from their money and they are being parted from their money. There can be no more important social matter in this country than the damage being wrought upon Australian families and children, dependants, arising from the failure of this federal government and state governments to develop a fair set of arrangements for sharing the revenues available and for sharing the expenditure and provision of services available. There can be no more important matter, either financially or socially.

The honourable member made much play of what he purported our government's legacy was for this government. I want to remind this chamber of the legacy that I, as a member of a government, inherited from former Treasurer Howard, now Prime Minister Howard. That was the trifecta of double digit inflation, running at 12 per cent; double digit employment, close to 11 per cent; and the highest cash interest rates since the Great Depression. The first negative growth in 30 years was the achievement of Treasurer Howard. And what was the deficit we received? The deficit expressed in today's dollars was in excess of $25 billion—not $10 billion in today's money but 2.5 times that. The budget papers of 1982-83 estimated there would be a budget deficit of $4.6 billion. In today's terms, it was $25 billion.

Who can forget, from the 1977 election campaign, that tremendous advertisement in the Sydney Morning Herald. It was a quarter of a page—I cannot show newspapers in the House but I can describe it. It was that big and that wide. In the right-hand column was a fist full of $5 bills. It said, `Labor will not give you tax cuts; Liberals will give you tax cuts.' What happened to that source of revenue and tax cuts? It was given away. That was, I think, on 25 November 1997 in the Sydney Morning Herald. Come January 1978 there was the introduction of new charges for health services. The media then said, `Give with the right and take away with the left.'

Minister, it is no good complaining that this is outside the ambit of the debate because it is absolutely at the core of the debate: the collection of revenues from tax, the forgoing of revenue by giving tax cuts and then the collection of new revenues from other service charges. It goes to the very core of state grants.

The sum of $800 million is being stripped from public hospitals and the provision of services. That is what this bill is about. It is about federal-state financial relationships and the passing on to state governments of a share of the revenues from taxes gathered by federal government. In my electorate of Shortland, just south of Newcastle, what do my constituents and I see? The closing of the Belmont CES office and the denial of services, the closure of the Belmont Medicare office, and longer queues at the public hospitals, because the public hospital share of funding is being cut.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. While sitting at this table, I recalled that the member for Cowan, while speaking on this debate, was interrupted by you on at least three occasions because you thought he was straying outside the ambit of the bill. By any stretch of the imagination, the material that the member is now going into is quite clearly outside the ambit of the bill, and I am wondering why you are not interrupting him as you did the previous speaker.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I must object to the last remark. That is a reflection on the chair, and I think the minister ought to withdraw that remark.

—It is a reflection on the chair if the chair takes offence at it. Nevertheless, I thank the hon ourable member for Chifley and assure the minister that I have drawn to the notice of the honourable member for Shortland that he is to come to the contents of the bill. I again will remind the minister at the table that I allowed the member for Cowan to go for 15 minutes in debate on the bill. It was in the last five minutes that I reminded him on at least three occasions to come back to the contents of the bill.

interjection.para: I again tell the honourable member for Shortland to come back to the contents of the bill. If the minister had been listening, she would have heard reference to the fact of the state grants interfering with hospitals; that is what I understood the member for Shortland to have said. But I will remind the member for Shortland that the bill before the House for debate is the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill. I would ask all speakers to keep to the bill, notwithstanding the debate that has occurred in the past.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy Speaker, with great respect to you and to the minister—and I have spoken with you and the minister on many, many occasions—I am nonplussed as to why both you and the minister are exhibiting these attitudes. The States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill is as broad a bill as can be brought into this parliament for debate. If you go back through the Hansard , you will find it is probably the broadest of bills. If each of you would like me to come down quietly afterwards and have a private talk with you and explain it to you, I will do it. But just let me read—
—I can assure the honourable member for Shortland that it will not be necessary because you will be able to tell us all about the bill before the House.
—I am trying to do that, but both of you do not seem anxious to listen to me. But, with all due respect to the chair, the parliamentary secretary's speech reads:

speech.para: The states and territories were able to allocate the funds provided by the Commonwealth under this act according to their own budgetary priorities.

Is there anything broader than that—`according to their own budgetary priorities'? That covers the whole range of services they are providing. If the government do not want me to speak about the funds being provided by this government via this legislation for hospitals and health services and education—which also was being discussed more specifically earlier—let them get up on their hind legs and say that they do not want to talk about it.

But I am going to talk about it because the next matter I come to is the Medicare agreement. Part of the funding is provided through this legislation, and part is provided through the Medicare agreement in the bill discussed the other day. These are part—

talk.start.para: —I just want some consistency, Peter. That is all.

—Minister, knowing you as I do, far be it from me not to want to be consistent in discussions in this chamber when you are present; I would not want to be otherwise. But let us come back to the general picture about federal-state financial relations.

speech.para: I have referred to gambling. I feel very, very strongly about this issue. It is at the core of family destruction that is occurring in this country—and it starts here in this chamber. Don't let us pussyfoot around the place and try to push it off to somewhere else. That problem starts here and will only be solved here. It is because the states are being starved of funds or overloaded with responsibilities that they turn to alcohol and poker machines and automatic teller machines—a prescription for disaster, suicide, destruction.

Some people have the temerity to lecture us about young people—`Aren't they terrible, the way they stand around in clubs with a cigarette in one hand, poker machine handle in the other, a glass of beer in front of them and the automatic teller machine not too far away, and maybe they've got some money from somebody else.' I do not want to recount an experience I heard one night in the club of how one young woman was getting money to play the poker machines. That problem starts here; it does not start outside of here. So I want to repeat that and hammer that view across to members.

But then let us look at the broader area of collection of revenues. One of the major sources of general purposes revenue that go to the states in untied grants is excise on fuel. This government is budgeting this year to collect $11,043 million in excise from refined petroleum products; $67 million from crude oil excise, mainly from LPG; and $960 million from resource rent tax. The current excise on fuel—unleaded petrol and diesel—is 34.697c per litre, of which a lousy 4.97c per litre is spent on road construction and maintenance; that is one seventh.

Whether or not the government or you, Madam Deputy Speaker, want to talk about it—and, Madam Deputy Speaker, you may want to talk about it—my constituents certainly want to talk about it. They know that when they buy petrol they are paying 35c to the Treasury, and they know that about one-seventh of that is spent on improving their roads. That is a matter of concern and sharing of access to revenue and responsibility for carrying out construction and maintenance of roads. That relationship between state and federal government goes to the heart of this question of vertical fiscal imbalance—who has their hand on the till, who gets the opportunity to spend it and who has the responsibility of providing the service. But we cannot talk about that and at the same time be muzzled from discussing the alternate means of revenue.

The reality is that, every day in this parliament, ministers and members of the government talk about a goods and services tax. What is it? Essentially, it is a tax whereby, every time money changes hands, the government takes a slice. So, if you buy a bottle of water, you pay tax. If you turn the light switch on, you pay tax. If you buy bread, you pay tax. You will pay tax on everything, every good and service. But the disastrous thing about that is that it is unfair. A much higher proportion of total expenditure of total income of a middle to low income family would be spent on paying tax. So you shift the tax burden down the line onto those people, and you have the business people at the top.

I find it utterly obscene that you have big business led by Stan Wallis, the Chair of the Business Council of Australia—and I am referring to Australia's top 100 corporations; not the little business people but the real business people—

talk.start.para: —So small business isn't real.
—Small business is real. They are the real people in this country, but they are being asked to pick up the burden of collecting tax. More than a million of them—
—A total of 1.3 million.

—They are being asked to do that to make it easier for big business, for Stan Wallis and his mates, for the top 100 business corporations in this country. They employ the highest paid executives in this country and they earn more in one year than most working people in this chamber earn in a lifetime. A person on $30,000 a year over 30 years earns $900,000. Stan Wallis and his mates earn between $1,500,000 to $2,500,000 per year. Where is the equity in that?

speech.para: These people are saying to my constituents, those working and those out of work, `You ought to be paying more tax. It will be good for you, believe me.' We should be saying to Stan Wallis and his mates, `Let's close down family trusts so that you pay your fair share of personal income tax.' These top executives have available to them all the rorts, lurks and means of passing their income offshore and evading personal income tax—the euphemism is minimising; the reality is evading. They have availed themselves of family trusts to evade tax. We have 19 ministers in this government—Minister, you are not one, are you?—who have family trusts.

talk.start.para: —Order! You will address the minister at the table through the chair.

—I am sorry. I apologise to the minister because I have a great deal of respect for her. The reality is that 19 ministers in this government have family trusts. My constituents do not have family trusts. That is what I am railing about. I do not have much longer in this parliament to represent my people, but it is unfair, and a goods and services tax is going to hurt them.

speech.para: I have a great deal of regard for the small business people in my electorate. I have worked very closely with them. In fact, I came from a small business before I came here. I know what it is like. I have been there and have done that. I understand their language, and I understand the burdens and trials that they face. But a GST is a recipe for disaster for small business that will increase bankruptcies. There is nothing in it for small business, so said Ray Regan, the President of the National Tax and Accountants Association, on 9 January this year. He ought to know.

Thank you very much for the support I have received from both the minister and yourself, Madam Deputy Speaker, in the course of the debate. There are some other matters that I would have liked to have covered in more detail, but thank you to both of you. I can only say that a GST is about making life more difficult and more unfair for families on middle to low incomes and for small business. It will reduce the number of jobs, not increase jobs, and it will increase heavily the burden upon small business in my electorate.

talk.start.para: —We are discussing the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1998 , and this is the mechanism by which the federal government transfers its revenues to the states. I particularly want to devote a major portion of my time to a proposal whereby in New South Wales $10 million is going to be docked from their state grants. It is interesting that the conservatives have always touted how much they believe in state rights; that when they get into government Commonwealth-state relations will be much better, will work more smoothly and will be more effective. I think it is fair to say that the Howard government probably has the worst record of any federal government in Commonwealth-state relations, notwithstanding the fact that a majority of the states have conservative premiers. In fact, until the recent Queensland election, all but one of them were conservative state premiers. Notwithstanding this fact, this government has the worst record of any federal government.

speech.para: The three Premiers Conferences have been a disaster. There is certainly a lack of goodwill and cooperation with the states. The COAG agreements have collapsed. At the last Premiers Conference in an unprecedented way we saw a walkout by all the Premiers—not just the Labor Premier but all the Premiers and Chief Ministers. That concerned the Medicare agreements; the fact that they could not renegotiate a new satisfactory Medicare agreement. Those agreements were supposed to commence from today. That is the record of this government. It is quite surprising given all the rhetoric that goes on about it.

I said that I wanted to devote my time to one particular matter, and it is an important matter in my state and it concerns the rice industry. The rice industry is almost 99 per cent in New South Wales and within New South Wales almost wholly in the electorate of the Leader of the National Party, the Deputy Prime Minister and member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). As a result of competition policy, there has been an examination of the monopoly of the marketing arrangements of the rice industry. The rice cooperative has sole responsibility for marketing the nation's rice both domestically and internationally. In 1995-96, as part of the competition policy, a team was established to look at this industry. It included four public servants and a representative of the rice industry.

What did this report find? It found—and this is disputed by the industry—that there was a net cost to the Australian people in this monopoly arrangement, or single desk marketing arrangement, of some $5 million. It also found that the nation as a whole benefited in 1996 by $35 million to $50 million and, by the year 2000, will benefit by $70 million to $75 million. You might say, `How could that be so?' How many speeches have we heard about the fact that different representatives of the coal industry get slaughtered when they travel to overseas countries trying to renegotiate contracts? One of them sells out for a lower price and then the rest have to follow. This report—not my words—shows that Australia as a nation benefited by $35 million to $50 million in the prices that we got in 1996 and that the net benefit to be received in the year 2000 is estimated to grow to $70 million to $75 million.

What is the government doing about it? I will tell you what the government is doing via the chairman of the competition council. Because the Premier of the New South Wales government said, `We think this is a great industry. We think this industry is doing a good job. We can't see any reason why we should change the current arrangements,' the chairman of the competition council has written to the Premier saying, `We disagree with you. If you do not deregulate this industry, we will have to recommend that your state's grants be reduced by $10 million.'

You might ask: what are the National Party members doing about it? What have they said in the House about this situation? I congratulate the National Party member for Page (Mr Causley), who has certainly spoken in this House about the rice industry. The trouble is that was almost 12 months ago and he did not mention this current predicament. No other National Party member of this House has got up and spoken out against this ridiculous situation that the competition council is putting the rice industry through.

Let me tell you a little bit about the rice industry. I have got to be critical of the New South Wales Minister for Agriculture—and I make no apology for saying that he is a good friend of mine—who has claimed that there are 2,000 rice farmers in the industry. I have to tell him he is wrong. I have got one bit of evidence that suggests there are 2,130 farms and another that says that there are 2,200. And what effect do they have on direct jobs in the rice industry? Those 2,000-odd farms are responsible for 8,000 direct jobs in the rice industry. But the story is even better than that: for every direct job, there are six indirect jobs. I think that totals up to 50,000 people, directly or indirectly, in this industry.

What do the National Party members say about it? What are they doing about it? Absolutely nothing. The honour for the last speech given in this House by the National Party on the rice industry goes to the member for Page, who is not currently in the House. When he spoke about the rice industry, he did not say anything about the National Competition Council.

The rice industry is one of Australia's real success stories in agricultural production. The history of agricultural production in this country is that we tend to export bulk, undifferentiated, lowest price product. What has the rice co-op done in their marketing effort? Overwhelmingly, They sell brands into markets. Over 80 per cent of their product is exported. Isn't that a wonderful story? They spend a long time developing markets. Indeed, they were saying that you have got to spend probably 10 years in some of these Asian countries before that market opens up. We all know the wonderful success story of our rice farmers exporting to Japan.

I have got some old figures that show that over $600 million worth of rice was exported in 1994. This is a wonderful success story. Why is it that the coalition government is so hell-bent on trying to change what is an obvious success? I want to give credit to our shadow minister for primary industries, the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), for a question he asked in parliament on 23 June of the Deputy Prime Minister. Given that the overwhelming majority of the industry is located in the electorate of the Deputy Prime Minister, wouldn't you think he would have plenty to say when he was asked the question? The question was:

My question is to the Deputy Prime Minister. I ask him: are you aware that your government, through the National Competition Council, is threatening to penalise the New South Wales government $10 million per annum—
through states grants—

because the Labor Premier, Bob Carr, and his agriculture minister, Richard Amery, have decided to back the New South Wales rice growers by keeping the current marketing arrangements in place? Deputy Prime Minister, who is responsible for this competition policy madness in your government? How will you explain to rice growers in your electorate what your government has done to them?

I have read very carefully the reply of the Deputy Prime Minister. I would have thought that we would have had a spirited defence of the industry—a clear statement that he was not going to cop this ridiculous attitude of the National Competition Council. Perhaps I was too optimistic. Perhaps I had too much faith in him. Perhaps the rice growers have too much faith in him.

Even if he could not say that, you would have thought that he would have given an undertaking to really sock it to the Treasurer (Mr Costello), who has responsibility for this council. But he did not. Apart from some flattering things that he said about the rice industry—which I am happy to acknowledge—I certainly cannot understand the last paragraph of his reply. The Deputy Prime Minister says:

I do not want to see any $10 million dockage take place, but that, of course, is contingent upon some reasonable steps agreed to by stakeholders 12 months ago being advanced. They have not been advanced until 1 May. Steps are being taken to see whether they can be advanced, most notably between now and 30 June so the $10 million dockage does not take place. If the $10 million dockage takes place, it rests on the shoulders of the New South Wales state government and its underwhelming performance on the matter. It is not our decision. It is part of a package of arrangements which it has failed to comply with. I will stick up for the efficient and effective structure of the Australian rice industry.

I have just outlined to the House that the very committee that was set up to examine the rice industry concluded that there was a net cost—disputed by the industry, I agree—to consumers of some $5 million, but there was a net benefit of $35 million to all of Australia under these present arrangements. I cannot understand what the Deputy Prime Minister is talking about. The industry has been examined, the report has been presented and is favourable. And what does the National Competition Council want to do? It wants to penalise the New South Wales government. The New South Wales government position has been quite clear: if it ain't broke, don't fix it.

This is an industry that we should be very proud of. It is an industry that is exporting its pants off. It is an industry that is growing. It is an industry that is adding value. Why would we want to interfere with it? But if the Commonwealth does take up the threatened recommendation of the National Competition Council and reduces grants to the New South Wales government by $10 million, then we have no choice. We cannot afford to cut funding to hospitals, schools or policing to take up this shortfall. It is up to the Commonwealth. The Deputy Prime Minister and the National Party have to put up or shut up. Today they have shut up. They have not said one word about the National Competition Council and its threats by way of letter to the New South Wales Premier.

I can understand that maybe the Deputy Prime Minister does not want to say anything too aggressive about the National Competition Council. You would think the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) would say something—but we all know he is jumping ship before it crashes—or perhaps the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Hicks), the National Party member for New South Wales, but he is jumping ship. Perhaps John Sharp—at one stage reputed to be the Leader of the National Party—could speak up, but he is jumping ship. Perhaps the National Party member who spoke about the rice industry 12 months ago, the honourable member for Page, should come into the House and speak up on behalf of the Leader of the National Party about the madness associated with the position of the Chairman of the National Competition Council.

What is the point of having these studies if they show that Australia is benefiting by the many millions of dollars—that I have already outlined—under this single desk marketing operation? Admittedly it is a monopoly, but why would you want to go away from it if, as I have said, the nation as a whole benefited in 1996 by $35 million to $50 million and, by the year 2000, will benefit by $70 million to $75 million?

I understand the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Anthony), the Deputy Whip, will be contesting a seat in our state in the next election on behalf of the National Party. And I think the Deputy Speaker, Mr Nehl, and the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson), are recontesting their seats. We have not heard a peep out of him about the rice industry. I have no shame in speaking up on behalf of the rice industry. I thought the question that the shadow minister put to the Deputy Prime Minister was a fair question—surprise, surprise, it was not answered—and I have had great difficulty in trying to fathom exactly what the answer was supposed to mean.

I say to the coalition: please stand up for this very efficient industry. It might be centred 99 per cent in New South Wales, but it is a great export earner for Australia. It is a great showcase of what we need to do in agriculture in terms of selling branded products and in value adding. The Rice Growers Cooperative of New South Wales took over the Leeton cannery. It was closed down and the cannery was stripped out. So what are the rice co-op doing? They have rebuilt it and are setting it up to manufacture rice products similar to the instant noodles that you can buy. Some will be for the domestic market no doubt and some we will export.

Isn't this the sort of initiative that we want to encourage in agriculture? But no, the National Party is being bloody-minded about it. They are allowing the Chairman of the National Competition Council to threaten the Premier of New South Wales in this letter. If the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock), who is at the table, requires me to table this threatening letter from Graeme Samuel, the President of the National Competition Council, dated 11 June, I am more than happy to do so.

The silence from the National Party has been absolutely staggering. There are 50,000 jobs directly or indirectly involved in this industry. Why wouldn't we want to be maximising the opportunities? Why would we want to fix something that is not broken? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to raise two propositions regarding the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1998 . The first is the restructuring that is needed in the Commonwealth and state responsibilities for post-secondary education in Australia. The second is to put the case for improved national investments in education for both Commonwealth purposes and Commonwealth grants to the states.

speech.para: It is now acknowledged among policy makers that education policy needs to move much closer to the structures and funding of a learning society, that is, a society in which all citizens engage in lifelong learning. The most logical response in an era of uncertainty and insecurity is for people to develop new skills—not just to the age of 18 or 21 as has been traditional in the 1970s and 1980s in Australia, but throughout life. If we live in an era of permanent change, then people skilling themselves and preparing for change through a lifetime is the only logical response. That places a great responsibility on policy reform, because most of the education institutions in Australia have been structured around the old economy and old social structures from the 1960s and 1970s.

We have seen the incremental growth of various educational institutions in Australia. Comprehensive schooling emerged in the 1960s; universities have moved from elite structures to mass education and now a movement to almost universal education. Along the way TAFE and vocational education have emerged to provide important services for workplace skilling. Adult and community education has emerged. So we have seen within the traditional stovepipe or silo of government structure the incremental emergence of these educational institutions.

But there has never been a fully comprehensive approach to how the institutions relate to each other—how we build the institutions and funding base for lifelong learning. One of the good things about Labor policy for the next election is that we are going to conduct that sort of review. We will have Australia's first ever comprehensive review of how we build the Commonwealth and state structures needed for lifelong learning. We see the pressures and the border disputes in the education system all the time. TAFE is being pulled at from both sides—in its relationship with universities on one side and its growing involvement in schools on the other. We find the challenges of adult and community education are not receiving the attention they need, particularly from this government. Universities, as I mentioned earlier, are going through a range of challenges, not only in moving towards universal provision but also in meeting the challenges of the globalisation of the higher education sector. These are all big issues and Labor will embark on the sort of review that is needed to address them.

I mount this argument in post-secondary education: over the next decade in Australia we need to have the Commonwealth government taking all the funding and legislative responsibilities for post-secondary education. For the universities this means funding and legislation. For TAFE it means the full system moving over in a national way onto national funding responsibilities. It means national responsibility for adult and community education, ending the confusion about the resources in that sector. It means Commonwealth responsibility for vocational education.

I would maintain that only by the Commonwealth taking these responsibilities for post-secondary education will we have the policy direction and effectiveness needed in the education system to build the structures of lifelong learning. I place this on a 10-year horizon. There is a lot of commonsense in making this point. How archaic that university legislation is still determined by the states in Australia even though the states provide little of the funding that makes our universities perform. How archaic and confusing that the TAFE system has different arrangements for its recurrent and capital funding. There is an argument that we can take, in a profile system, the TAFE institutes—80 in Australia—one by one and move them onto the federal budget. There is also a good argument that, in building the structures of lifelong learning, the Commonwealth should take responsibility for adult and community education and the great work of that sector, which is now expanding into the universities of the third age. This is a 10-year agenda, but only Labor talks about the institutional structures needed for a learning society. All we get from the coalition is the running down of national investment in education and very little to improve institutional design and policy reform.

The second point I want to make is about the value of education and how we need improved national investments in this area. It is not just a matter of getting the institutional structure right for lifelong learning; it is also a matter of resourcing it so that every single Australian can engage in the reskilling and knowledge enhancement needed in their economic and social lives that allow them to deal with insecurity. If we do not give people new skills, they will always take insecurity and uncertainty more as a threat than as an opportunity in their lives. If they are threatened by the process of change, then every two-bit populist in town will try to exploit their fears and play on the worst side of human nature. We have seen that most recently in the Queensland election result. Education has a special place on the public policy agenda with regard to not only Commonwealth responsibilities but also Commonwealth grants to the states and territories.

In Australia we have traditionally undervalued the importance of education. This nation has had an ethos of wealth generation that normally associates economic activity with things that come out of the ground—agriculture and mining and property development in the postwar housing and property boom. Now we need to move the Australian economic base away from old industries to the new information base for the next century. In a world of permanent change, the only answer to insecurity lies in preparation for change—people preparing themselves for new types of work, being prepared to handle new flows of information and knowledge—thus empowering them to act in new ways with new skills ensuring that people are able to regard the change process more as an opportunity than as a threat.

This is more the case as we shift from industrial to knowledge based economic activity. Given the growing importance of information, innovation and creativity, and the declining importance of muscle power and repetitive tasks in the production process, knowledge and education matter more than ever. To change the Australian ethos—to think that we can now get so much more of our national wealth out of our minds, out of our ingenuity, out of our creativity, than necessarily out of the ground—is one of the great leadership tasks for national government.

But I worry about this proposition: education tends to be somewhat punished in the political arena because it invests in the future. During this time of insecurity and these political themes of uncertainty, we have demands in the political system for immediate answers, for governments and parties to give the appearance of having an immediate answer for every single social problem. The truth is that the only lasting answer to insecurity lies in preparing people for the change process. Education should not be punished because it invests in the future—because it invests in the future capacity of citizens to prepare themselves for change, economic and social.

We live in a world of permanent change with far fewer economic boundaries and limits on the flow of information, and the worst thing we can possibly do in the political system is meet the short-term demand for answers at the expense of the long-term investments the nation needs to make in education and knowledge enhancement. I would argue that there is no point in trying to con people that change can be halted or, with even greater deception, that change can be reversed. There are no answers in the siren song of nostalgia; no answers in the hope of turning back the hands of time to some golden era from the 1950s and 1960s. The only real political direction and purpose that Australia can take requires the development of policies and programs that help prepare people for the inevitability of change. The only lasting answer to this time of insecurity lies in improved national investments in education, research and training.

This government, of course, with its promotion of downwards envy, its very narrow political agenda, has been in the business of punishing education budgets, not because they are without answers but because they invest in the future. This is a government that has tried to give the appearance of pandering to the so-called Howard battler constituency—it is now the Hanson battler constituency, of course—and saying to people, `We are trying to give the appearance of having immediate answers,' and one of the things that suffered in that process is the national investment in education. This government is the first in our history to actively wind back the scale of national funding for education. That is reflected not just in Commonwealth purpose activities, but also in Commonwealth grants to the states and the general purpose grants that we find in this particular piece of legislation.

The important thing now for policy makers who believe in lifelong learning and who advocate a learning society is to argue and put the case for education as a public good that is available to all and where one person's use does not restrict someone else's access to the education service. I want to present three arguments why education can be argued within this framework; why we should acknowledge the power of education as an essential investment in the nation's future.

The first of those is this concern about economic sovereignty and economic growth. In the global economy, nations have been stripped down essentially to the skills and insights of their people. We now have a new economic environment where huge amounts of financial capital can move seamlessly across national boundaries. We have a new economy where even whole industries can relocate from one political jurisdiction to another. The only lasting answer, in terms of economic sovereignty, is to recognise that the nation's greatest asset does not lie in the ground and it does not lie in any other form of economic activity except for the skills and insights of the nation's people. Australia's best way of attracting investment into the future lies in the development of a highly skilled work force and population.

The best way of combating global capital is to empower a nation's citizens to be skilled and proficient so they can draw a premium off international markets on the basis of their knowledge based skills. Of course, this argument is being supported by some new economic theories. The new growth theorists are saying that economic growth and a nation's prospects are very closely linked to technological progress. The old Left in politics always argued that to get more economic growth you need to spend more. The new Right argued in their economics that for improved growth and national performance you need to save more. But the new growth theorists call on policy makers to address a nation's third deficit: not the deficit in spending or the deficit in saving on government budgets, but in R&D and knowledge enhancement.

This is the greatest folly of all: the Howard government's budget cuts to education, research and training. Australia's R&D performance is being pushed well below the 1.5 per cent level of GDP. Compare that to Japan: three per cent investments; Germany, 2.8; and the United States, with 2.7 per cent of their gross domestic product going into R&D. The Howard government is pushing our rates down to less than half those of our competitor economies in the Western world. The new growth theorists and the whole argument about economic sovereignty point to the need for improved national investments in education, research and training.

The second argument about the role of education as a public good concerns this question of social participation. We now live very much in an information rich society where citizens are bombarded with new sources of information throughout their daily activities. From the moment we wake up in the morning and turn on the radio and get the latest news, to when we might log out of a home computer or the Internet at night, we are very much an information rich society. Participation in our society now requires a higher level of information skills. It requires that we have the personal capacity to process information, to understand it, to use new forms of information for personal and social advantage. Beyond that we are all better off as citizens in dealing with information skilled people in our daily lives, whether in the workplace or socially, or in our consumer transactions. We are all better off dealing with people who can cope well with this overload of information. If we deal with highly skilled people, we are all better off in our own daily lives.

So too this question of participation relates to the new economy. There are now so few unskilled forms of work.
