At that stage, Australia's population was just seven million and Calwell stressed the need for what became the great postwar immigration program. He said:
Our first requirement is additional population. We need it for reasons of defence and for the fullest expansion of our economy.

I suspect those two reasons are just as valid today as they were when he spoke in 1944. That view was shared by both sides of politics at the time. For example, speaking in 1950, Prime Minister Menzies said:
. . . if everyone understood that migration was vital to our existence . . . then we should regard every migrant as our friend.

There has been mention in recent weeks and months of migration. It is a subject of some topical debate. I recall that, according to projections of the population by birthplace, if current immigration trends continue the percentage of the population of Australia born overseas will actually decline over the next few decades and be only 16 per cent by the year 2041. Nonetheless, we do have great diversity in this country, brought about by people bringing their great gifts from many other parts of the world.

The thing about population is that, of course, the population birthrate in this country is decreasing. When our population numbered just seven million in 1947 there were 182,000 births that year in Australia. It is interesting that now our population is 18 million, yet there are only 250,000 births a year. If we are to continue to expand, then migration is very much part of that growth.

I note that the Australian demographer Peter McDonald, surveying populations of the world, said that most Western industrialised countries will have a population of perhaps a fifth or a sixth of what they have today if current trends continue. That, of course, is a recipe for stagnation. It is a recipe for a diminution of growth rather than real growth and it would end up in a greatly less beneficial system than we have at the present time. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I think the electors of Werriwa would say that they do not give a stuff; the electors of Bradfield would be more inclined to say that they do not give a damn. I refer to the constant toing-and-froing over whether the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) has given Mr Oldfield a reference and the nature of it. On Monday night in the adjournment debate I spoke about the need for Australia to have strategic vision. One of the reasons we are in trouble is because we have failed to enunciate in clear terms what it is that we are trying to achieve as a nation, what sort of country we want to become and what values and princi ples it will be based on. I also have said on several occasions in the House and publicly in newspapers that what we have failed to do in relation to the One Nation phenomenon is to explain why changes have occurred in our country. Today I received a letter from Dr Douglas Long, who is the Executive Director of the Centre for Leadership Studies. I would like to refer to some points that have been made in his letter. He says:

speech.para: In his book Flatland: A Romance in Multiple Dimensions Edwin Abbott described a society that existed in only two dimensions. Flatlanders were either point people or line people. . . . The residents of Flatland deprived themselves of spectrums of differences, shades of variations in meanings, and recognition of the inherent changeability in life itself. `What is will always be' is the creed of the culture of Flatland.

Few issues summon the Flatlanders to battle more than such sensitive areas as race, multiculturalism, immigration and the nature of nationhood, regardless of world orders. High levels of ego involvement often produce the `either you're for me or you're against me' tendency. Flags, quotas, language, redistribution, land titles and `who belongs' versus `who are the newcomers?' stir hearts and raise tempers as honest folks shout at each other from opposing redoubts entrenched in bipolar camps. And, when life becomes too complex, we often find comfort in the simple answers—we try to return to Flatland.

A lot of the current debate has centred around culture and what it means to be an Australian, who qualifies and who does not. . . . culture is not static and the detectable patterns within cultures are not religious scripts that lock us into choices against our wills. . . . If it's time for a change then from what and, most importantly, to what? And if this is accepted then even more important is the notion that getting rid of what you don't want is not the same as getting what you do.
He goes on to say:

One Nation represents those people who are not happy with the complex world they are faced with, those who feel that the global village, fast paced consumerism, lack of respect from young people, decline in the numbers attending church and so on are responsible for the troubles they face. They believe that if we can just get back to how things used to be everything will work out. These people believe that their way is the only way, and failure to follow this path will only lead to destruction.
He goes on to say:

Those people opposed to One Nation believe that . . . there is no future in trying to return to the past. They see the policies of One Nation as naive, racist, simplistic and not capable of dealing with the complexities of today.

That is not to say either opinion is good or bad, right or wrong, as each has a legitimate view. Suppressing or repressing views which we may personally find to be repugnant doesn't mean they go away—it's a bit like dealing with boils. Until you deal with the root cause of `why' it is impossible to obtain a cure. In Australia's case this has become the boil on our backside and we cannot sit comfortably and focus on our future until it is gone.

This is so right. We as a parliament, and I believe as a government and those who profess to lead, need to explain to Australians why we run an immigration program at all; why, despite significant domestic problems and hardship, we send money to the poorest people in the world; why we are even engaged in a debate about trade and why that is important to the next generation. Dr Long says:

The main focus of the established parties appears to be to get rid of One Nation, whilst the main focus of One Nation is to get rid of what they perceive as the favouring of Aborigines over white Australians, Asian immigration and so on. But is this the same as getting what Australia wants? If there was a clear indication of where Australia was changing to, what it was trying to get, then would One Nation's rise have been so prominent? The application of deep values thinking was used to develop the framework for the unification of South Africa.

I believe that this is the kind of thinking that we in the parliament and those who are privileged to represent the people of Australia need to start to apply to the emergence of One Nation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —As the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) well knows, politics sometimes makes for odd bedfellows, and even the best of us get saddled with our own personal Judas. I do not judge the Labor Party by Mal Colston. Years ago it would have been quite improper to judge the Nationalist Party by T.J. Leahy, and the member for Werriwa should not judge me by David Oldfield.

speech.para: Today the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) released her party's immigration policy. The first question that she faced at the subsequent press conference was the use of a tax haven by One Nation Ltd's part-owner and national director, David Ettridge. She refused to take any questions on this subject, but these are the questions which One Nation's supporters across Australian want her to answer. How can the party which claims to be against tax avoidance and which claims to be against get-rich-quick scams by white shoe brigade spivs have as its national director someone who does not pay his tax and uses tax havens?

It was also noteworthy in today's press conference that David Oldfield chose to keep a low profile. The puppet master might have withdrawn behind the curtains, but he is clearly still pulling the strings, as more and more One Nation members are realising. People are getting the message that Pauline Hanson is being used by the two Davids and that David Oldfield is using Pauline Hanson as his personal Trojan horse to enter the Senate.

More and more One Nation members are getting the message. Peter Archer, their former regional director in New South Wales, said that Oldfield is in it for power, Ettridge is in it for money and Hanson is in it for ego. What is happening is that people are understanding that Oldfield, Ettridge and Hanson are engaged in a strange menage a trois. But where is it leading the nation? What type of people are running One Nation? Today we had Mr Ettridge talking to the Australian. The newspaper stated:
Mr Ettridge said membership numbers and details were kept secret from One Nation members.
"It's nobody's business but ours," he said.
It also reported:

"We don't want branches getting into the data base because it is not important for them to have it. It is quite important that they shouldn't have it," he said . . . Mr Ettridge said branch office holders had to sign a "pledge of loyalty" and an undated letter of resignation, which had been used to get rid of six members.

You have to ask yourself what kind of paranoid, halfway to Waco, Texas, world—what kind of weird existence—do the leadership of One Nation actually have. Yesterday, David Ettridge told the Australian Financial Review :

I did not receive any money from World Vision. World Vision was contracted with Global Communications. I am an overseas principal of Global Communications, which is owned by Mr Ross Boland who is an expatriate living in Vanuatu.

It is typical of David Ettridge and David Oldfield that they will use a half-truth to conceal a big lie. World Vision did in fact pay David Ettridge's company, Global Communications, but today made clear to my office that all the cheques went to PO Box 775 in Manly. World Vision did not send cheques to Vanuatu and World Vision did not know they were in some way or form paying Ross Boland. This is typical of the web of deceit woven by David Ettridge and David Oldfield.

The big question is: what is going to happen to the $500,000 in taxpayers' money that they are entitled to after the Queensland election? The registered agent of the One Nation party is presumably David Ettridge, and there is nothing at all to stop David Ettridge using this money to travel to Vanuatu, presumably to visit Ross Boland, to collect the cheques which he reckons went to a one-roomed house in a village without any electricity.

This is not a time to mince words. I say in this parliament that Oldfield and Ettridge are chronic and habitual liars, and I again call on the ASC to investigate whether David Ettridge has used the incorporation of a company in Vanuatu as a device to get around Australian bankruptcy law.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 10 March 1998:

question.para: Is it a fact that aircraft are departing Essendon Airport at 3 a.m.; if so, (a) what is being done to prevent nearby residents from being disturbed by the departures, (b) what safety precautions apply to control and monitor air traffic movements and runway use at the time and (c) will curfew restrictions not be relaxed and permission not extended to a wider range of aircraft to use the facilities than at present.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Yes.
(a) Noise abatement procedures apply between the hours of 11pm and 6am for departing aircraft as follows:

A preferred runway system is specified to minimise tracking over built-up areas ie first preference to the north on runway 35, second preference to the west on Runway 26, third preference to the south on Runway 17 and the least preferred is to the east on Runway 08. Departing aircraft are requested to maintain runway centerline heading until above 1,500 feet. Aircraft meeting the following criteria may depart Essendon between 11pm and 6am:

(i) Propeller driven aircraft of a maximum take-off weight exceeding 9,000 kg, the noise emissions of which do not exceed 90 EPNdB on take-off when measured in accordance with the methodology of Chapter 3, Part II, Volume I of ICAO Annex 16: or

(ii) Propeller driven aircraft of a maximum take-off weight not exceeding 9,000 kg, that comply with the standards in respect of noise expressed in Chapter 6 or 10, part II, Volume I of ICAO Annex 16.

(b) Outside the hours of the Essendon control tower operations, (11pm to 6am) aircraft departing and arriving at Essendon are subject to air traffic control from the Melbourne (Tullamarine) terminal area radar controllers. Procedures relating to aircraft operating requirements outside Essendon Control Tower operating hours are published in pilot documentation.

(c) The current restrictions on aircraft at Essendon Airport during the curfew period are derived from the Port Phillip Airport and Airspace Study. These restrictions will not be amended or relaxed from the current position.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 8 April 1998:

(2) Did Airservices Australia advise Mr Nally in a letter dated 17 September 1997 that clearance was refused because several IFR RPT aircraft were taxiing for or departing runway 19.

(3) Did Airservices Australia respond, in a letter dated 28 January 1998 from Mr Peter Evans, to a subsequent query for details of the aircraft referred to in part (2) by stating that all its radar and audio tape information of this kind was stored for only 14 days.

(4) Did the letter referred to in part (3) refer to a letter to Mr Nally dated 1 October 1997; if so, is it a fact that Mr Nally has twice requested copies of this letter, which he claims not to have received, but that Airservices Australia has failed to provide a copy.

(5) Will he instruct Airservices Australia (a) either to provide a copy of the letter or acknowledge that it does not exist and (b) retain radar and audio tape information relevant to a complaint until the complaint is fully resolved.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. I, and my Department on my behalf, have responded to correspondence on the issue from Ms Gambaro MP, the Member for Petrie on behalf of Mr Nally, and directly from Mr Nally.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.
(4) Yes. Airservices has advised me that a further copy of the letter has been sent to Mr Nally.

(5) (a) Airservices has provided me with a copy of the letter of 1 October 1997 to Mr Nally and advised that a further copy has also been provided to Mr Nally. I have also provided Mr Nally with a copy of the letter.

(b) Airservices Australia has been asked to retain radar and audio tape information relevant to a complaint until the complaint is fully resolved, and have sought assurances that staff who deal with complaints are adequately trained on the authority's obligations under relevant laws.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 13 May 1998:

question.para: (1) What was the total value of Australia's exports in (a) 1994-95, (b) 1995-96, (c) 1996-97 and (d) 1997-98 to the date of answering this question.
(2) What percentage by value of Australia's exports was exported by ship in (a) 1994-95, (b) 1995-96, (c) 1996-97 and (d) 1997-98 to the date of answering this question.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The total value of Australia's goods and services exports was $87.5 billion in 1994-95 ($67.1 billion for goods and $20.4 billion for services), $99.0 billion in 1995-96 ($76.1 billion for goods and $22.9 billion for services), $105.3 billion in 1996-97 ($80.9 billion for goods and $24.4 billion for services) and $85.1 billion from July 1997 to March 1998 ($65.7 billion for goods and $19.4 billion for services).

(2) The percentage of Australia's goods and services exports transported by ship was 60.6 per cent 1994-95, 60.6 per cent in 1995-96, 60.6 per cent in 1996-97 and 61.3 per cent from July 1997 to March 1998. With specific regard to goods exports, the proportion carried by sea as a proportion of total goods exported was 79.1 per cent in 1994-95, 78.9 per cent in 1995-96, 80.9 per cent in 1996-97 and 80.4 per cent from July 1997 to March 1998.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 1 June 1998:

question.para: (1) What levels of Commonwealth funding were provided to Tuggeranong Link for the provision of migrant welfare workers in (a) 1993-94, (b) 1994-95, (c) 1995-96, (d) 1996-97 and (e) 1997-98.
(2) Does the Commonwealth require non-profit community organisations to contribute to the funding of migrant welfare workers.
(3) How many migrant welfare workers are employed with Commonwealth funding in the electoral divisions of (a) Namadgi, (b) Canberra, (c) Fraser, (d) Bennelong and (e) Berowra.
(4) What is the tenure of migrant welfare workers employed in the electoral divisions of (a) Namadgi, (b) Canberra, (c) Fraser, (d) Bennelong and (e) Berowra.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The levels of funding provided to Tuggeranong Link, previously known as Tuggeranong Link of Community Houses and Centres Inc, for the provision of migrant welfare workers are as follows:
None.
The Tuggeranong Link of Community Houses and Centres Inc was awarded funding for a 3-year period for a Grant-in-Aid (GIA) worker. Funding for the first year was $44,352.
GIA funding allocated for the second year was $44,973.
GIA funding allocated for the third year was $47,596.
Tuggeranong Link did not lodge an application for worker-based funding under the Community Settlement Services (CSS) Scheme.

(2) Funded organisations are required to sign a Service or Funding Agreement with the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs before the commencement of funding. The Agreement is a legal document, which sets out the conditions for funding and imposes formal obligations upon both parties. This Agreement, signed by the organisation and authorised Departmental officers, stipulates that the organisation is required to contribute from its own resources to the facilities and services necessary to conduct the function of the worker.

(3) A migrant welfare worker is a person who is employed to perform duties which may include service delivery on an individual, group or community basis, case responsibility for clients, co-ordination of a service, supervision and counselling. The number of such workers employed with my Department's funding in the specified electoral divisions are as follows:
(a) Namadgi
A full-time generalist worker located at Woden Community Services Inc services the areas of Woden, Tuggeranong and southern ACT, which includes the electoral division of Namadgi.
(b) Canberra
There are 5 full-time equivalent worker positions distributed as follows:
. 1 generalist worker position at Woden Community Service Inc (job shared by two people);
. 0.5 Croatian community welfare worker based at the Croatian Community Welfare Centre in Civic;
. 1 humanitarian/early intervention settlement worker based at the Migrant Resource Centre (MRC) in Civic;
. 1 humanitarian settlement worker based at the MRC, Civic, servicing the division of Canberra and the Queanbeyan district;
. 1 community project officer based at the at the MRC, Civic; and
. 0.5 generalist worker based at the MRC in Civic.
(c) Fraser
There are 1.5 full-time equivalent worker positions at the Belconnen Community Service Inc: 1 generalist and 0.5 Vietnamese community welfare worker.

(4) Organisations were awarded funding in 1997-98 for 12 months for worker-based positions under the CSS Scheme. They have now been offered an extension of funding for a further 12 months to 30 September 1999.

Tenure of workers is a matter between the organisation and the worker. As a condition of funding under the current CSS Scheme Service Agreement, the Department requires that the funded organisation is the legal employer and, as such, is responsible for negotiating conditions of service with the worker, taking account of any relevant industrial conditions. This requirement is included in the Service Agreement in Section 3.3 (e):
`only employ the Worker in accordance with the appropriate award applying to the position for which he or she has been employed to fill.'
